I am hereby a nazirite when I will have a son, and a nazirite, began counting his and afterward, a son was born to him, sets aside his and counts that of his son, and afterward completes his
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Matni 'hareini nazir, v'nazir k'sheyiheyeh li ben', hitkhil moneh et shelo, v'achar kach nolad lo ben - mashlim et shelo, v'achar kach moneh et shel b'no. 'Hareini nazir k'sheyiheyeh li ben, v'nazir', hitkhil moneh et shelo v'achar kach nolad lo ben - manich et shelo, u'moneh et shel b'no, v'achar kach mashlim et shelo." English translation: "It was taught: 'Behold, I am a nazir, and a nazir when I have a son,' he begins by counting his own days of nezirut, and afterwards a son is born to him - he completes his nezirut, and then counts for his son. 'Behold, I am a nazir when I have a son, and a nazir,' he begins by counting his own days of nezirut, and afterwards a son is born to him - he suspends his nezirut, and counts for his son, and then completes his nezirut."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ בָּעֵי רָבָא: אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְאַחַר עֶשְׂרִים יוֹם, וּמֵעַכְשָׁיו מֵאָה יוֹם״, מַהוּ? כֵּיוָן דְּהָלֵין מְאָה בְּעֶשְׂרִין לָא שָׁלְמִין — לָא חָיְילִין, אוֹ דִילְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּאִית לֵיהּ גִּידּוּל שֵׂעָר לְבַסּוֹף — חָיְילִין.
human_translation: Rava asks: said: I am hereby a nazirite after twenty days, and from now one hundred days, what is since these one hundred not completed within twenty do not take effect Or perhaps, since he has hair growth at the end, take effect
llm_translation: Gemara: Rava inquired: He said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite for after twenty days, and from now one hundred days." What is the law? Since they do not complete one hundred within twenty - they are not valid, or perhaps: since there is potential for hair growth at the end - they are valid.

hebrew_text: וְתִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ נְזִירוּת מוּעֶטֶת! חֲדָא מִגּוֹ חֲדָא קָא מִיבַּעְיָא לֵיהּ:
human_translation: And let him raise dilemma a short naziriteship, He raises one dilemma as a result of the other.
llm_translation: And it requires for him a minimal Naziriteship! One from here and one from there he requires for him.

hebrew_text: אִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר נְזִירוּת מוּעֶטֶת, כֵּיוָן דְּעַשְׂרָה יוֹמִין הוּא דְּיַתִּרִין — לָא סָלֵיק לֵיהּ הָלֵין עֲשָׂרָה, וַדַּאי נְזִיר מֵאָה יוֹם, כֵּיוָן דְּאִית לֵיהּ תְּמָנִין יוֹמִין לְבַסּוֹף, סָלְקִין לֵיהּ, אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: If you say a short naziriteship since, it is ten days that are left over those ten should not be reckoned for him Certainly a nazirite one hundred days, since he has eighty days at the end, count for him or not?
llm_translation: If you want to say that the period of nezirut is minimal, since it is ten days more than the rest—ten days are not included in it, and surely a nezir is one hundred days, since he has eighty days left at the end, they are included in it, or not?

hebrew_text: וְאִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר חָיְילִי: אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְאַחַר עֶשְׂרִים יוֹם וּמֵעַכְשָׁיו נְזִיר עוֹלָם״, מַהוּ? מִי חָיְילָא עֲלֵיהּ, אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: And if you say take effect, said: I am hereby a nazirite after twenty days, and from now a permanent nazirite, what is Does take effect for him or not?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And if you should say 'Chayili,' he said, 'Behold, I am a Nazirite for another twenty days, and from now on, a Nazirite forever.' What is the law? Is he a Chayila upon it, or not?"

hebrew_text: אִם תִּמְצֵי לוֹמַר: הָכָא כֵּיוָן דְּאֶפְשָׁר לְאִיתְּשׁוֹלֵי חָיְילָא: אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִיר שִׁמְשׁוֹן לְאַחַר עֶשְׂרִים יוֹם וּמֵעַכְשָׁיו נָזִיר סְתָם״, מַהוּ? הָכָא לָא אֶפְשָׁר לְאִיתְּשׁוֹלֵי, מִי חָיְילָא, אוֹ לָא? אֲמַר ״כְּמֹשֶׁה בְּשִׁבְעָה בַּאֲדָר״, מַאי?
human_translation: If you say: Here, since is possible to request takes effect said: I am hereby a nazirite Samson after twenty days, and from now a nazirite without specification, what is here it is not possible to request does take effect or not? said: like Moses on the seventh of Adar, what
llm_translation: If you might say: here, since it is possible for the troops to stumble, he said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite like Samson for twenty days, and from now on, a regular Nazirite." What is the ruling? Here, it is not possible for the troops to stumble, is it a troop or not? He said, "Like Moses on the seventh of Adar," what is the ruling?

hebrew_text: פְּשׁוֹט מִינַּיְיהוּ קַדְמָיְיתָא: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לְאַחַר עֶשְׂרִים יוֹם וּמֵעַכְשָׁיו מֵאָה יוֹם״ — מוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרִים, וְאַחַר כָּךְ מוֹנֶה שְׁלֹשִׁים, וְאַחַר כָּךְ מוֹנֶה שְׁמוֹנִים כְּדֵי לְהַשְׁלִים נְזִירוּת רִאשׁוֹנָה.
human_translation: resolve the first of these I am hereby a nazirite after twenty days, and from now one hundred days, he counts twenty after which he counts thirty and afterward he counts eighty in order to complete first naziriteship.
llm_translation: The straightforward question from them is as follows: "Behold, I am a Nazirite for after twenty days, and from now on for one hundred days" - he counts twenty, and afterwards he counts thirty, and afterwards he counts eighty in order to complete the first Naziriteship.

hebrew_text: נִטְמָא בִּימֵי בְּנוֹ, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: סוֹתֵר. רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר.
human_translation: he became impure during the days of his son? Rabbi Yoḥanan says: negates Reish Lakish says: This does not negate
llm_translation: Talmudic text: He became impure during his son's days, Rabbi Yochanan said: he invalidates. Reish Lakish said: he does not invalidate.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר סוֹתֵר — חֲדָא נְזִירוּת אֲרִיכְתָּא הִיא, רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר — נְזִירוּת דִּידֵיהּ לְחוּד, וְדִבְרֵיהּ לְחוּד.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says negates it is one long naziriteship. Reish Lakish says it does not negate his naziriteship is discrete and that for his son is discrete
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: "One who contradicts - it is a lengthy Nazirite vow." Reish Lakish said: "He does not contradict - his own Nazirite vow is separate, and his words are separate."

hebrew_text: נִטְמָא בִּימֵי צָרַעְתּוֹ — רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: סוֹתֵר. רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר.
human_translation: became impure during the days of his leprosy. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: negates Reish Lakish says: It does not negate
llm_translation: Talmudic text: He became impure during the days of his leprosy — Rabbi Yochanan said: He invalidates it. Reish Lakish said: He does not invalidate it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר סוֹתֵר, דְּהָא בִּנְזִירוּת קָאֵי. רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר — צָרַעַת לְחוּד וּנְזִירוּת לְחוּד.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan says negates since he remains in naziriteship Reish Lakish says it does not negate leprosy is discrete and naziriteship is discrete.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said, "He contradicts, for he is standing on the issue of Naziriteship." Resh Lakish said, "He does not contradict — leprosy is separate, and Naziriteship is separate."

hebrew_text: וּצְרִיכָא, דְּאִי אִיתְּמַר בְּהָךְ קַמַּיְיתָא, בְּהַהִיא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סוֹתֵר — שֵׁם נְזִירוּת אַחַת הִיא. אֲבָל בְּהָא אֵימָא מוֹדֶה לֵיהּ לְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, דְּנָזִיר לְחוּד וְצָרַעַת לְחוּד.
human_translation: And necessary As, if it were stated in this first one, in that Rabbi Yoḥanan said it negates there is one label of naziriteship but in this say he concedes to Reish Lakish since a nazirite is discrete and leprosy is discrete.
llm_translation: And it is necessary, for if it was stated in that case before him, in that one Rabbi Yochanan said "soter" - the name of a Nazirite is one. But in this case, let us say that Reish Lakish agrees with him, that Nazirite is separate and Tzara'at is separate.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אִיתְּמַר בְּהָא, בְּהָא קָאָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, אֲבָל בְּהָךְ — אֵימָא מוֹדֶה לֵיהּ לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן, צְרִיכָא.
human_translation: And if it were stated in this in this Reish Lakish said but in that say he concedes to Rabbi Yoḥanan necessary
llm_translation: "And if it was stated in this one, in this one Reish Lakish said, but in that one — say that he agrees with Rabbi Yochanan, it is necessary."

hebrew_text: נִטְמָא בְּיוֹם גִּידּוּל שֵׂעָר. רַב אָמַר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר. אֲפִילּוּ לְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן דְּאָמַר סוֹתֵר — הָנֵי מִילֵּי הֵיכָא דְּקָאֵי בִּנְזִירוּת, גִּידּוּל שֵׂעָר מִישְׁלַם נְזִירוּת הוּא.
human_translation: who became impure on the day of hair growth. Rav said: It does not negate Even according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who says negates this statement where he remains in naziriteship, hair growth is an addition to naziriteship
llm_translation: Talmudic text: He became impure on the day of hair growth. Rav said: It does not nullify. Even according to Rabbi Yochanan who said it nullifies - those words apply where it stands in relation to Naziriteship, hair growth is a completion of Naziriteship.

hebrew_text: וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: סוֹתֵר. אֲפִילּוּ לְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ דְּאָמַר אֵין סוֹתֵר — הָתָם שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוּת, הָכָא חֲדָא נְזִירוּתָא.
human_translation: And Shmuel said: negates Even according to Reish Lakish, who says does not negate there two naziriteship, here one naziriteship,
llm_translation: Samuel said: Disputes. Even according to Resh Lakish who said disputes not. There, two Nazirites, here, one Nazirite.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: הַכֹּל מוֹדִים שֶׁאִם קִדֵּשׁ שֵׂעָר בַּדָּם — אֵין לוֹ תַּקָּנָה.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: All concede that if the hair was consecrated of the blood, he has no remedy.
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: All agree that if one sanctified hair with blood, he has no remedy.

hebrew_text: אַלִּיבָּא דְּמַאן? אִי אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר — כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר תִּגְלַחַת מְעַכֶּבֶת, תּוֹךְ מְלֹאת הִיא? וְלִסְתּוֹר! אֶלָּא אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבָּנַן — הָאָמְרִי תִּגְלַחַת לֹא מְעַכֶּבֶת! לְעוֹלָם אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבָּנַן, וּמַאי ״אֵין לוֹ תַּקָּנָה״ — אֵין לוֹ תַּקָּנָה לְמִצְוַת גִּילּוּחַ.
human_translation: In accordance with whose If in accordance with of Rabbi Eliezer, since said shaving is indispensable is within the full term but let negate Rather, in accordance with of the Rabbis; didn’t they say shaving is not indispensable Actually, in accordance with of the Rabbis, and what He has no remedy? He has no remedy for the mitzva of shaving,
llm_translation: In the matter of whom? If in the matter of Rabbi Eliezer - since he said that shaving impedes, is it not within a full measure? And to conceal! Rather, in the matter of the Rabbis - who said that shaving does not impede! Indeed, in the matter of the Rabbis. And what is "he has no acquisition"? He has no acquisition for the commandment of shaving.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: נָזִיר שֶׁכָּלוּ לוֹ יָמָיו — לוֹקֶה עַל הַטּוּמְאָה, וְאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה עַל הַתִּגְלַחַת וְלֹא עַל הַיַּיִן. מַאי שְׁנָא טוּמְאָה דְּלָקֵי — דְּאָמַר קְרָא: ״כׇּל יְמֵי הַזִּירוֹ לַה׳״, לְרַבּוֹת יָמִים שֶׁלְּאַחַר מְלֹאת כְּיָמִים שֶׁלִּפְנֵי מְלֹאת.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: A nazirite whose days are completed is flogged for the impurity but he is not flogged for the shaving, nor for the wine. What is different impurity that he is flogged as the verse states: “All the days that he has consecrated himself unto the Lord to include days after the completion like the days before completion
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, said: A Nazirite whose days are complete - he is liable for impurity, but he is not liable for shaving or for wine. What is the difference regarding impurity that he is liable - as the verse states: "All the days of his vow of separation to the Lord," to include days after completing like days before completing.

hebrew_text: אִי הָכִי, אַתִּגְלַחַת נָמֵי לִיחַיַּיב, דְּהָא אָמַר רַחֲמָנָא ״כׇּל יְמֵי נֶדֶר נִזְרוֹ תַּעַר לֹא יַעֲבֹר עַל רֹאשׁוֹ״, לַעֲשׂוֹת יָמִים שֶׁלְּאַחַר מְלֹאת כַּיָּמִים שֶׁלִּפְנֵי מְלֹאת! וְתוּ, ״כֹּל יְמֵי נִזְרוֹ מִכֹּל אֲשֶׁר יֵעָשֶׂה מִגֶּפֶן הַיַּיִן״, לַעֲשׂוֹת יָמִים שֶׁלְּאַחַר מְלֹאת כְּיָמִים שֶׁלִּפְנֵי מְלֹאת?
human_translation: If so, let him also be liable for shaving, since the Merciful One states “All the days of his vow of naziriteship there shall no razor come upon his head” render days after completion like the days before completion. And furthermore, “All the days of his naziriteship, from anything that is made of the grapevine, render days after completion like the days before completion
llm_translation: If so, you would be liable for shaving, for the Merciful One said, "All the days of his vow of separation, no razor shall pass over his head," to make the days after fulfillment like the days before fulfillment! And furthermore, "All the days of his vow, from all that is made from the grapevine," to make the days after fulfillment like the days before fulfillment?

hebrew_text: שָׁאנֵי הָכָא דְּאָמַר רַחֲמָנָא: ״וְטִמֵּא רֹאשׁ נִזְרוֹ״, מִי שֶׁנִּזְרוֹ תָּלוּי לוֹ בְּרֹאשׁוֹ. מֵיתִיבִי: נָזִיר שֶׁכָּלוּ לוֹ יָמָיו — אָסוּר לְגַלֵּחַ וְלִשְׁתּוֹת יַיִן וְלִטָּמֵא לְמֵתִים, וְאִם גִּילַּח וְשָׁתָה יַיִן וְנִטְמָא לְמֵתִים — הֲרֵי זֶה סוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: Here, it is different, as the Merciful One states “And he defile his consecrated head” one whose naziriteship is upon his head, raises an objection A nazirite whose days are completed is forbidden to shave, and to drink wine, and to contract impurity from corpses. And if he did shave, or drink wine, or contract impurity from corpses, he incurs the forty conclusive refutation
llm_translation: The case is different here, as the Merciful One said: "And he shall defile his head." The one whose hair is consecrated is dependent on it on his head. It was asked: A Nazirite who completed his days - is forbidden to shave, to drink wine, and to become impure for the dead. And if he shaved, drank wine, and became impure for the dead - he is absorbing the forty lashes. This is a refutation.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר לִכְשֶׁיְּהֵא לִי בֵּן״ וְ״נָזִיר מֵאָה יוֹם״, נוֹלַד לוֹ בֵּן עַד שִׁבְעִים — לֹא הִפְסִיד כְּלוּם. לְאַחַר שִׁבְעִים — סוֹתֵר שִׁבְעִים. שֶׁאֵין תִּגְלַחַת פָּחוֹת מִשְּׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם.
human_translation: I am hereby a nazirite when I will have a son, and a nazirite one hundred days, a son is born to him up to seventy he has not lost anything. after seventy negates seventy since shaving cannot less than thirty days.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "If one says, 'I am a Nazirite when I have a son,' and 'a Nazirite for one hundred days,' if a son is born to him within seventy days - he has not lost anything. After seventy days - he nullifies the seventy days. For the minimum period of shaving is not less than thirty days."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב: יוֹם שִׁבְעִים עוֹלֶה לְכָאן וּלְכָאן. תְּנַן: נוֹלַד לוֹ עַד שִׁבְעִים — לֹא הִפְסִיד כְּלוּם. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ עוֹלָה לְכָאן וּלְכָאן, אִיתְּגוֹרֵי מִיתְּגַר! אֶלָּא בְּדִין הוּא דְּלָא לִיתְנֵי ״עַד שִׁבְעִים״, וּמִשּׁוּם דְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא ״אַחַר שִׁבְעִים סוֹתֵר שִׁבְעִים״, קָתָנֵי רֵישָׁא ״שִׁבְעִים״.
human_translation: Rav said: The seventieth day counts for here and for there, We learned born to him up to seventy, he has not lost anything. And if it enters your mind counts for here and for there, gains Rather, by right not taught: Up to seventy but due to that it is taught the last clause After seventy it negates seventy, teaches the first clause seventy
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara said Rav: day seventy rises to here and to here. We learned: born to him until seventy — not lost anything. And if it enters your mind rises to here and to here, they clash with each other! Rather, it is a law that it does not say "until seventy," and because it teaches the end "after seventy contradicts seventy," it teaches the beginning "seventy."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע מִסֵּיפָא: נוֹלַד אַחַר שִׁבְעִים — סוֹתֵר שִׁבְעִים. מַאי ״אַחַר״? אַחַר אַחַר.
human_translation: Come hear from the last clause is born after seventy it negates seventy What is After? after, after.
llm_translation: Come and hear from the latter part: If one is born after seventy - he nullifies seventy. What is meant by "after"? After after.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל אַחַר מַמָּשׁ מַאי — הָכִי נָמֵי דְּלָא סָתַר? אִי הָכִי, מַאי אִירְיָא דְּתָנֵי נוֹלַד עַד שִׁבְעִים לֹא הִפְסִיד כְּלוּם? אֲפִילּוּ אַחַר שִׁבְעִים נָמֵי, הָא אָמְרַתְּ לָא סָתַר! אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ ״אַחַר״ מַמָּשׁ. וְכֵן מַתְנִיתִין לְרַב, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: But what actually after so too, that it does not negate If so, why specifically teach: born up to seventy he has not lost anything? even after seventy as well, didn’t you say it does not negate? Rather, learn from this After, actual and likewise the mishna for Rav. learn from this
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But after what exactly? So it is said that he did not hide? If so, what is the meaning of the teaching: "A person is not considered lost until he reaches the age of seventy"? Even after seventy, it is said that he is not considered lost! Rather, understand from it that "after" means exactly. And similarly, the Mishnah to Rav, understand from it.

hebrew_text: וְרַב כְּמַאן אַמְרַהּ לִשְׁמַעְתֵּיהּ? אִילֵּימָא כְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל, דִּתְנַן: הַקּוֹבֵר אֶת מֵתוֹ שְׁלֹשָׁה יָמִים קוֹדֶם לָרֶגֶל — בָּטְלָה מִמֶּנּוּ גְּזֵירַת שִׁבְעָה.
human_translation: And Rav, in accordance with whose he say his halakha ? If we say in accordance with Abba Shaul, as we learned one who buries his dead three days before a pilgrimage Festival, decree of seven is voided for him,
llm_translation: And Rav, according to whose opinion did she say it? Perhaps like Abba Shaul, as we learned: One who buries his deceased three days before a festival - the decree of the seven days of mourning is annulled from him.

hebrew_text: שְׁמֹנָה יָמִים קוֹדֶם לָרֶגֶל — בָּטְלָה מִמֶּנּוּ גְּזֵירַת שְׁלֹשִׁים. וּמוּתָּר לְסַפֵּר עֶרֶב הָרֶגֶל, וְאִם לֹא סִיפֵּר עֶרֶב הָרֶגֶל — אָסוּר לְסַפֵּר אַחַר הָרֶגֶל.
human_translation: eight days before a pilgrimage Festival, decree of thirty is voided for him and it is permitted to cut his hair on the eve of the pilgrimage Festival But if he did not cut his hair on the eve of the pilgrimage Festival, it is prohibited to cut his hair after the pilgrimage Festival,
llm_translation: Eight days before the festival — the decree of thirty is nullified from it. And it is permissible to count the evening of the festival, and if one did not count the evening of the festival — it is forbidden to count after the festival.

hebrew_text: אַבָּא שָׁאוּל אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ לֹא סִיפֵּר קוֹדֶם הָרֶגֶל — מוּתָּר לְסַפֵּר אַחַר הָרֶגֶל, שֶׁכְּשֵׁם שֶׁמִּצְוַת שְׁלֹשָׁה מְבַטֶּלֶת גְּזֵירַת שִׁבְעָה — כָּךְ מִצְוַת שִׁבְעָה מְבַטֶּלֶת גְּזֵירַת שְׁלֹשִׁים.
human_translation: Abba Shaul says: Even not cut his hair before the pilgrimage Festival, it is permitted to cut his hair after the pilgrimage Festival. that just as mitzva of three voids decree of seven, so mitzva of seven voids decree of thirty.
llm_translation: Abba Shaul says: Even if one did not recount before the festival, it is permitted to recount after the festival, for just as the obligation of three nullifies the decree of seven, so too the obligation of seven nullifies the decree of thirty.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּאַבָּא שָׁאוּל? לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּקָסָבַר שְׁבִיעִי עוֹלֶה לְכָאן וּלְכָאן? דִּלְמָא עַד כָּאן לָא קָאָמַר אַבָּא שָׁאוּל אֶלָּא בַּאֲבֵילוּת שִׁבְעָה דְּרַבָּנַן, אֲבָל בְּנָזִיר דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא — לָא!
human_translation: What is the rationale of Abba Shaul Isn’t it because he holds seventh counts for here and there, perhaps Abba Shaul was saying only with regard to the mourning seven by rabbinic law, but with regard to a nazirite, by Torah law, not
llm_translation: What is the reason for Abba Saul's statement? Is it not because he holds that the seventh day goes both here and there? Perhaps Abba Saul did not mean until here, but rather in the mourning of the seven days of the Rabbis, but not in the case of a Nazirite, which is a biblical law — no!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא רַב דְּאָמַר כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: שׁוֹמֶרֶת יוֹם כְּנֶגֶד יוֹם שֶׁשָּׁחֲטוּ וְזָרְקוּ עָלֶיהָ בַּשֵּׁנִי שֶׁלָּהּ,
human_translation: Rather, Rav spoke in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, as it is taught Rabbi Yosei says: A woman who observes day for day they slaughtered and sprinkled for her on her second
llm_translation: Rather, Rav said like Rabbi Yosei. As it was taught: Rabbi Yosei says: "The guardian of the day is opposite the day they slaughtered and sprinkled upon it on its second day."

hebrew_text: וְאַחַר כָּךְ רָאֲתָה — הֲרֵי זוֹ אֵינָהּ אוֹכֶלֶת, וּפְטוּרָה מִלַּעֲשׂוֹת פֶּסַח שֵׁנִי.
human_translation: And after that, she saw she may not eat but she is exempt from observing second Pesaḥ ,
llm_translation: And after that she saw — behold, this one does not eat, and she is exempt from making a second Pesach.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, לָאו מִשּׁוּם דְּקָסָבַר מִקְצָת הַיּוֹם כְּכוּלּוֹ? מִמַּאי? וְדִלְמָא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָסָבַר מִכָּאן וּלְהַבָּא הוּא מְטַמֵּא.
human_translation: What is the rationale of Rabbi Yosei Isn’t it because he holds part of the day is like of an entire From where Perhaps because holds one becomes impure from now and onward.
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Yosei's opinion, is it not because he holds that a part of the day is like the whole day? From where? Perhaps because he holds that from here and onwards it becomes impure.

hebrew_text: וּמִי סָבַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי הָכִי?
human_translation: And does Rabbi Yosei hold this
llm_translation: And who does Rabbi Yosei thus opine?

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: זָב בַּעַל שְׁתֵּי רְאִיּוֹת שֶׁשָּׁחֲטוּ וְזָרְקוּ עָלָיו בַּשְּׁבִיעִי, וְכֵן שׁוֹמֶרֶת יוֹם כְּנֶגֶד יוֹם שֶׁשָּׁחֲטוּ וְזָרְקוּ עָלֶיהָ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ רָאוּ, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁמְּטַמְּאִין מִשְׁכָּב וּמוֹשָׁב לְמַפְרֵעַ — פְּטוּרִין מִלַּעֲשׂוֹת פֶּסַח שֵׁנִי.
human_translation: But isn’t it taught Rabbi Yosei says: a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [ zav ] who has had two sightings for whom they slaughtered and sprinkled on the seventh, and similarly, a woman who observes day for a day, for whom they slaughtered and sprinkled afterward they saw although they render objects designed for lying and sitting impure retroactively, they are exempt from observing second Pesaḥ .
llm_translation: The text states: "And it was taught, Rabbi Yosei says: A man who emitted semen twice, and they slaughtered and sprinkled on him on the seventh day, and similarly a woman who observed a day corresponding to the day they slaughtered and sprinkled on her, and afterwards they saw, even though they become impure from lying and sitting, they are exempt from performing the second Passover."

hebrew_text: מַאי לְמַפְרֵעַ — מִדְּרַבָּנַן. הָכִי נָמֵי מִיסְתַּבְּרָא, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, אַמַּאי פְּטוּרִין מִלַּעֲשׂוֹת פֶּסַח שֵׁנִי?
human_translation: What retroactively? by rabbinic law. So too, it is reasonable as, if it enters your mind by Torah law, why are they exempt from observing second Pesaḥ
llm_translation: What is the reason for "lemafrea" - from the Rabbis. This is logical, for if your mind were to depart from the Torah, why are they exempt from bringing a second Passover offering?

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם אֵימָא לָךְ טוּמְאָה דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, תְּהוֹם דְּזִיבָה הִתִּירוּ.
human_translation: actually, I say to you impurity by Torah law, permitted the deep of ziva .
llm_translation: Forever say to you impure of Torah, depths of impurity they permitted.

hebrew_text: וְאַף רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא סָבַר לְמַפְרֵעַ מִדְּרַבָּנַן, דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹשַׁעְיָא אָמַר: (אֲבָל) הָרוֹאֶה זָב בַּשְּׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ — סוֹתֵר אֶת שֶׁלְּפָנָיו. וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: לָא נִסְתּוֹר אֶלָּא יוֹמוֹ.
human_translation: And even Rabbi Oshaya holds retroactively by rabbinic law As it is taught Rabbi Oshaya says: one who sees gonorrhea-like discharge on his seventh negates that preceded it And Rabbi Yoḥanan said to him that it should negate only its own day,
llm_translation: And even Rabbi Oshaya holds to be lenient from the Rabbis, as it was taught, Rabbi Oshaya said: (But) one who sees a Zav on his seventh day - he nullifies his previous days. And Rabbi Yochanan said to him: It is only his day that is concealed.

hebrew_text: מָה נַפְשָׁךְ? אִי סָתַר, כּוּלְּהוּ סָתַר. אִי לָא סָתַר — לָא נִסְתּוֹר וְלֹא יוֹמוֹ! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: לָא נִסְתּוֹר וְלָא יוֹמוֹ.
human_translation: Whichever way you If negates it should negate all If it does not negate not negate and not its own day. Rather, say not negate and not its own day,
llm_translation: "What is your soul? If it concealed, all concealed. If not concealed - not concealed and not hidden! Rather say: not hidden and not revealed."

hebrew_text: וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי קָאֵי כְּוָתָיךְ, דְּאָמַר מִכָּאן וּלְהַבָּא מְטַמֵּא. וְהָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי לְמַפְרֵעַ הוּא דְּאָמַר! מַאי לְמַפְרֵעַ — מִדְּרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: And said to Rabbi Yosei holds in accordance with your as he says becomes impure from now and onward, But didn’t Rabbi Yosei say retroactive, What is retroactively? by rabbinic law,
llm_translation: He said to him: Rabbi Yosei stands like you, for he said from here and onwards it is defiling. But Rabbi Yosei is one who is lenient, for he said! What is meant by "lenient" - according to the Rabbis.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי, מִכְּדִי סָבַר מִקְצָת הַיּוֹם כְּכוּלּוֹ, זָבָה גְּמוּרָה דְּמַיְיתָא קׇרְבָּן הֵיכִי מַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לָהּ? כֵּיוָן דְּחָזְיָא בְּפַלְגֵיהּ דְּיוֹמָא, אִידַּךְ פַּלְגֵיהּ דְּיוֹמָא סָלֵיק לַהּ לְשִׁימּוּר! אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא דְּקָא שָׁפְעָה תְּלָתָא תְּלָתָא יוֹמֵי בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי. וְאִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: דְּחָזְיָא תְּלָתָא יוֹמֵי סָמוּךְ לִשְׁקִיעַת הַחַמָּה, דְּלָא הֲוַאי שְׁהוּת דְּסָלֵיק לֵיהּ לְמִנְיָינָא.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yosei, now, he holds part of the day is like of an entire How can you find a full-fledged zava who brings an offering? Since she sees at the midpoint of the day, the other half of the day counts for her observing, If you wish, say that continuously discharges three days consecutively. And if you wish, say that she saw three days close to sunset. there was not time to be included for her counting
llm_translation: Rabbi Yosei, since he holds that part of the day is like the whole day, how does he establish a complete Zavah's blood for the offering? Once he sees half of the day, the other half of the day emerges for her to be safeguarded! If you wish, say that she discharged three discharges of three days each consecutively. And if you wish, say that she saw three days close to sunset, which is not considered part of the count.

hebrew_text: הַדְרָן עֲלָךְ הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר
llm_translation: We will return to you, behold I am a Nazir.

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״ — מְגַלֵּחַ יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים וְאֶחָד, וְאִם גִּילַּח לְיוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים — יָצָא. ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״ — אִם גִּילַּח לְיוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים לֹא יָצָא.
human_translation: One who said: I am hereby a nazirite, shaves thirty-first day And if he shaved on the thirtieth day, he has fulfilled I am hereby a nazirite thirty days, if he shaved on the thirtieth day, he has not fulfilled
llm_translation: One who said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite" - shaves on the thirty-first day, and if he shaved on the thirtieth day - he has fulfilled his obligation. "Behold, I am a Nazirite for thirty days" - if he shaved on the thirtieth day, he has not fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁנָּזַר שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוֹת — מְגַלֵּחַ אֶת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים וְאֶחָד, וְאֶת הַשְּׁנִיָּה יוֹם שִׁשִּׁים וְאֶחָד. וְאִם גִּילַּח אֶת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים — מְגַלֵּחַ אֶת הַשְּׁנִיָּה יוֹם שִׁשִּׁים, וְאִם גִּילַּח יוֹם שִׁשִּׁים חָסֵר אֶחָד — יָצָא.
human_translation: One who accepted two naziriteship shaves the first thirty-first day, and the second sixty-first day. And if he shaved the first thirtieth day, he shaves the second sixtieth day, And if he shaved day sixty less one, he has fulfilled
llm_translation: One who takes a vow of two Nazirites - shaves the first on the thirty-first day, and the second on the sixty-first day. And if he shaved the first on the thirtieth day - he shaves the second on the sixtieth day, and if he shaved on the sixtieth day lacking one - he has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: וְזוֹ עֵדוּת הֵעִיד רַבִּי פַּפְּיָיס, עַל מִי שֶׁנָּזַר שְׁתֵּי נְזִירוֹת, שֶׁאִם גִּילַּח אֶת הָרִאשׁוֹנָה יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים — מְגַלֵּחַ אֶת הַשְּׁנִיָּה לְיוֹם שִׁשִּׁים, וְאִם גִּילַּח לְיוֹם שִׁשִּׁים חָסֵר אֶחָד — יָצָא, שֶׁיּוֹם שֶׁל שְׁלֹשִׁים עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן.
human_translation: And this testimony was attested to Rabbi Pappeyas, with regard to one who vowed two naziriteship, that if he shaved the first thirtieth day, he shaves the second on the sixtieth day. And if he shaved on day sixty less one, he has fulfilled because the thirtieth day counts of his tally
llm_translation: And this is the testimony that Rabbi Pappayas testified concerning one who vowed two Nazirites, that if he shaved the first one on the thirtieth day - he shaves the second one on the sixtieth day, and if he shaved on the sixtieth day lacking one - he has fulfilled his obligation, for the thirtieth day is included in the count.

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״, נִטְמָא יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים — סוֹתֵר אֶת הַכֹּל. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר אֶלָּא שִׁבְעָה. ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״, נִטְמָא יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים — סוֹתֵר אֶת הַכֹּל. ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר מֵאָה יוֹם״, נִטְמָא יוֹם מֵאָה — סוֹתֵר אֶת הַכֹּל. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר אֶלָּא שְׁלֹשִׁים. נִטְמָא יוֹם מֵאָה וְאֶחָד — סוֹתֵר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר אֶלָּא שִׁבְעָה.
human_translation: One who said: I am hereby a nazirite, he became ritually impure thirtieth day it negates the entire Rabbi Eliezer says: It negates only seven I am hereby a nazirite thirty days, he became impure thirtieth day, it negates the entire I am hereby a nazirite one hundred days, he became impure one hundredth day, it negates the entire Rabbi Eliezer says: It negates only thirty he became impure one hundred and first day it negates thirty days, Rabbi Eliezer says: It negates only seven
llm_translation: One who says, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," becomes impure for thirty days - he nullifies everything. Rabbi Eliezer says: He nullifies only seven. "Behold, I am a Nazirite for thirty days," becomes impure for thirty days - he nullifies everything. "Behold, I am a Nazirite for one hundred days," becomes impure for one hundred days - he nullifies everything. Rabbi Eliezer says: He nullifies only thirty. If one becomes impure for one hundred and one days - he nullifies thirty days. Rabbi Eliezer says: He nullifies only seven.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מִי שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״ וְנִטְמָא יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים — סוֹתֵר אֶת הַכֹּל, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר אֶלָּא שִׁבְעָה.
human_translation: One who said: I am hereby a nazirite, became ritually impure thirtieth day, it negates the entire Rabbi Eliezer says: It negates only seven.
llm_translation: Gemara: One who says, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," and becomes impure on the thirtieth day - he nullifies everything. Rabbi Eliezer says: He nullifies only seven.

hebrew_text: קָסָבַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: כׇּל אַחַר מְלֹאת שִׁבְעָה — סוֹתֵר. ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״, וְנִטְמָא יוֹם שְׁלֹשִׁים — סוֹתֵר אֶת הַכֹּל, לָא פְּלִיג רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר דְּאָמַר שְׁלֵימִין.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer holds anyone after the completion seven negated, I am hereby a nazirite thirty days, and became impure thirtieth day, it negates the entire Rabbi Eliezer does not disagree where he said that a full
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer holds: After completing seven — he nullifies. "Behold, I am a Nazir for thirty days," and he becomes impure for thirty days — he nullifies everything, Rabbi Eliezer does not disagree, for he said they are complete.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר מֵאָה יוֹם״, וְנִטְמָא יוֹם מֵאָה — סוֹתֵר אֶת הַכֹּל, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר אֶלָּא שְׁלֹשִׁים. וְכוּלָּהּ כְּדַהֲוֵינַן בָּהּ אַלִּיבָּא דְּבַר פַּדָּא וְרַב מַתְנָא.
human_translation: I am hereby a nazirite one hundred days, and he became impure one hundredth day, it negates the entire Rabbi Eliezer says it negates only thirty. And this entire as we discussed it, in accordance with of bar Padda and Rav Mattana
llm_translation: "I behold myself as a Nazirite for one hundred days," and if he becomes impure on one of those days - he nullifies everything. Rabbi Eliezer says: He nullifies only thirty. And the entire matter is as we have explained it in the case of a matter of redemption, and Rav Matna.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁנָּזַר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, אֲפִילּוּ הָיָה שָׁם שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם — אֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וְאֵינוֹ מֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה. יָצָא וְנִכְנַס — עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וּמֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה.
human_translation: One who took a vow of naziriteship while in a cemetery, even if he was there thirty days do not count of his tally, And he does not bring offerings of impurity, he left and entered do count of his tally, and he does bring the offerings of impurity
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who takes a Nazarite vow while in a cemetery, even if he was there for thirty days - they do not count towards his vow count, and he does not bring a sacrifice for impurity. If he leaves and re-enters - the days count towards his vow count, and he brings a sacrifice for impurity.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: לֹא בּוֹ בַיּוֹם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהַיָּמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים יִפְּלוּ״, עַד שֶׁיְּהוּ לוֹ יָמִים רִאשׁוֹנִים.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: not on the very day as it is stated “But the first days shall be void” until he will have “first days”
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: Not in him in the day, as it is said: "And the former days shall be forgotten," until there are for him former days.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיתְּמַר, מִי שֶׁנָּזַר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: נְזִירוּת חָלָה עָלָיו, וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אֵין נְזִירוּת חָלָה עָלָיו. רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר נְזִירוּת חָלָה עָלָיו, סָבַר: מִיתְּלָא תַּלְיָא וְקָיְימָא, כֵּיוָן דְּמַשְׁכְּחָא טׇהֳרָה, חָיְילָא. וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: אֵין נְזִירוּת חָלָה עָלָיו. אִי הָדַר וְאָמַר — חָיְילָא עֲלֵיהּ, וְאִי לָא — לָא.
human_translation: It was stated one who vowed to be a nazirite in a cemetery. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Naziriteship takes effect for him, and Reish Lakish said: Naziriteship does not take effect for him. Rabbi Yoḥanan, said naziriteship takes effect for him, holds pending, when is found ritual purity takes effect. And Reish Lakish said naziriteship does not take effect for him if again said it takes effect for him; but if not not
llm_translation: Gemara: It was stated: One who took a Nazirite vow while in a cemetery, Rabbi Yochanan said: The Nazirite status takes effect upon him. Reish Lakish said: The Nazirite status does not take effect upon him. Rabbi Yochanan said: The Nazirite status takes effect upon him, for he holds that the hanging of the vow and its fulfillment are dependent on each other, and once purity is forgotten, the vow takes effect. Reish Lakish said: The Nazirite status does not take effect upon him. If he retracts and says, "It takes effect upon him," then it does, but if not, then it does not.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: מִי שֶׁנָּזַר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, אֲפִילּוּ הָיָה שָׁם שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם — אֵין עוֹלִין מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וְאֵינוֹ מֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה. קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה הוּא דְּלָא מַיְיתֵי, הָא מֵיחָל — חָיְילָא עֲלֵיהּ! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: אֵינוֹ בְּתוֹרַת טוּמְאָה, וְאֵינוֹ בְּתוֹרַת קׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish One who took a vow of naziriteship while in a cemetery, even if he was there thirty days do not count of the tally, And he does not bring the offerings of impurity It is the offerings of impurity that he does not bring, but taking effect, it does take effect for him. said to him: he is not in the law of ritual impurity, and he is not in the law of the offerings.
llm_translation: He raised an objection to Reish Lakish: One who takes a Nazarite vow while in a cemetery, even if he was there for thirty days - he does not count towards the number, and he does not bring a sacrifice for impurity. It is a sacrifice for impurity that he does not bring, but if he delays - he is liable! He said to him: He is not under the law of impurity, and he is not under the law of sacrifice.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: מִי שֶׁהָיָה טָמֵא וְנָזַר, אָסוּר לְגַלֵּחַ וְלִשְׁתּוֹת יַיִן וְלִיטָּמֵא לְמֵתִים. וְאִם גִּילַּח וְשָׁתָה יַיִן וְנִטְמָא לְמֵתִים — הֲרֵי זֶה סוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. אִי אָמְרַתְּ בִּשְׁלָמָא חָיְילָא — הַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דְּסוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים, אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ לָא חָיְילָא, אַמַּאי סוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים?
human_translation: raised an objection to One who was impure and took a vow of naziriteship prohibited from shaving, and from drinking wine, and from becoming impure from a corpse. And if he shaved, or drank wine, or he became impure from a corpse, he incurs [ sofeg ] the forty Granted, if you say takes effect that is the reason that he incurs the forty But if you say does not take effect why does he incur the forty
llm_translation: He raised an objection: One who was impure and took a Nazirite vow, is forbidden to shave, drink wine, and become impure through contact with the dead. And if he shaved, drank wine, and became impure through contact with the dead - he is absorbing the forty lashes. If you say it is because of the Nazirite vow - that is the reason he is absorbing the forty lashes. But if you say it is not because of the Nazirite vow, why is he absorbing the forty lashes?

hebrew_text: הָכָא בְּמַאי עָסְקִינַן — בְּיוֹצֵא וְנִכְנָס.
human_translation: With what are we dealing here With one who left and entered,
llm_translation: Here we are dealing with what? - with going out and coming in.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ: אֵין בֵּין טָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר לְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא, אֶלָּא טָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר — שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ לַמִּנְיָן, וְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא — אֵין שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ לַמִּנְיָן. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ לָא חָיְילָא, אַמַּאי עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן?
human_translation: raised objection to The difference between a ritually impure who took a vow of naziriteship and a ritually pure nazirite who became impure is only a ritually impure took a vow of naziriteship, his seventh counts of his tally But a ritually pure nazirite who became impure, his seventh does not count of his tally. And if it enters your mind does not take effect, why counts of his tally,
llm_translation: He raised an objection against him: There is no difference between an impure person who vowed to be a Nazirite and a pure Nazirite who became impure, except that an impure person who vowed to be a Nazirite - his seventh day counts towards his count, and a pure Nazirite who became impure - his seventh day does not count towards his count. And if you think it is not a valid argument, why does his count not count towards the count?

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי: מֵיחָל — כּוּלֵּי עָלְמָא לָא פְּלִיגִי דְּחָיְילָא, אֶלָּא כִּי פְּלִיגִי לְמִלְקֵי: רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן סָבַר: כֵּיוָן דְּחָיְילָא — לָקֵי. וְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ סָבַר: לָא לָקֵי, וְחָיְילָא.
human_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi said: taking effect, everyone agrees that takes effect Rather, when they disagree to being flogged, Rabbi Yoḥanan holds since takes effect, he is flogged and Reish Lakish holds that he is not flogged but does take effect
llm_translation: Mar bar Rav Ashi said: When they are silent, the entire world does not dispute the ruling of the army. Rather, when they dispute, it is regarding the kings. Rabbi Yochanan holds: Once the army is established, it is considered as if it has conquered. Resh Lakish holds: It is not considered as if it has conquered, but rather as if it is an army.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: מִי שֶׁנָּזַר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, אֲפִילּוּ הָיָה שָׁם שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם — אֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וְאֵינוֹ מֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה. קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה הוּא דְּלָא מַיְיתֵי, הָא מִילְקֵי, לָקֵי עֲלֵיהּ!
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish One who took a vow of naziriteship while in a cemetery, even if he was there thirty days do not count of his tally, And he does not bring the offerings of impurity, It is the offerings of impurity he does not bring, but flogged for
llm_translation: He raised an objection to Reish Lakish: One who takes a Nazarite vow while in a cemetery, even if he was there for thirty days - they do not count towards his vow count, and he does not bring a sacrifice for impurity. It is a sacrifice for impurity that he does not bring, but he brings milk, he brings upon it!

hebrew_text: בְּדִין הוּא דְּלִיתְנֵי ״אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה״, אֶלָּא מִשּׁוּם דְּקָא בָּעֵי לְמִיתְנֵא סֵיפָא ״יָצָא וְנִכְנַס — עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וּמֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה״, תְּנָא רֵישָׁא ״אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה״.
human_translation: by right should teach: He is not flogged, but due to wants to teach the latter clause he left and entered do count of his tally, and he does bring the offerings of impurity taught the first clause He does not bring the offerings of impurity,
llm_translation: In judgment it is that it does not teach "he is not liable," rather because it is necessary to teach the end "he went out and came in - he ascends from the count, and brings a sacrifice of impurity," a Tanna taught the beginning "he does not bring a sacrifice of impurity."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֵין בֵּין טָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר לְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא, אֶלָּא שֶׁטָּמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר — שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא — אֵין שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן. הָא לְמַלְקוּת — זֶה וָזֶה שָׁוִין! אֲמַר לֵיהּ: לָא, לְתִגְלַחַת זֶה וָזֶה שָׁוִין.
human_translation: Come hear The difference between an impure who took a vow of naziriteship and a pure nazirite who became impure is only That an impure who took a vow of naziriteship, his seventh counts of his tally But a pure nazirite who became impure, his seventh does not count of his tally. But with regard to flogging, this and that are equal. said to not to shaving this and that are equal,
llm_translation: Come and hear: There is no difference between an impure person who vowed to be a Nazirite and a pure Nazirite who became impure, except that the impure one who vowed to be a Nazirite - his seventh day counts towards completing his count, and a pure Nazirite who became impure - his seventh day does not count towards completing his count. This is a dispute: both are equal! He said to him: No, for shaving, both are equal.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל לְעִנְיַן מַלְקוֹת מַאי — זֶה לוֹקֶה וְזֶה אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה? לִיתְנְיֵיהּ! בְּתַקַּנְתֵּיהּ קָא מַיְירֵי, בְּקִלְקוּלֵיהּ לָא קָא מַיְירֵי.
human_translation: But what with regard to flogging? This is flogged, and that is not flogged? let him teach this is speaking of his remedy; it is not speaking of detrimental to him.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: But regarding the matter of lashes, what is the law - is this one liable for lashes and this one not liable for lashes? Let him teach it! He is explaining according to its strictness, he is not explaining according to its leniency.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: מִי שֶׁהָיָה טָמֵא וְנָזַר — אָסוּר לְגַלֵּחַ וְלִשְׁתּוֹת יַיִן, וְאִם גִּילַּח וְשָׁתָה יַיִן וְנִטְמָא לְמֵתִים — הֲרֵי זֶה סוֹפֵג אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים! תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: Come hear One who was ritually impure and took a vow of naziriteship prohibited from shaving and from drinking wine. And if he shaved, or he drank wine, or he became ritually impure from a corpse, he incurs the forty a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who was impure and took a Nazarite vow — it is forbidden for him to shave and to drink wine. And if he shaved and drank wine and became impure due to contact with the dead — behold, he is absorbing the forty! A refutation.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבָא: נָזִיר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, מַהוּ? בָּעֵי שְׁהִיָּיה לְמַלְקוּת, אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: Rava asks: What is a nazirite while in a cemetery: necessary delayed to lashes, or not
llm_translation: Rava asked: A Nazirite who is in a cemetery, what is the law? Does he require shaving or not?

hebrew_text: הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דְּאָמְרִי לֵיהּ ״לָא תִּינְזוֹר״, לְמָה לִי שְׁהִיָּיה? נָזִיר מַאי טַעְמָא לָא בָּעֵי שְׁהִיָּיה — דְּקָא מַתְרִי בֵּיהּ. הָכָא נָמֵי קָא מַתְרִי בֵּיהּ!
human_translation: What are the circumstances If we say that they said to him Do not take a vow of naziriteship why do I delay What is the reason a nazirite does not need to delay Because they warn him Here too, they warn him
llm_translation: How are they similar? Perhaps you will say because it says "he shall not shave," why do I need a period of being? Why does a Nazirite not require a period of being? Because he is already abstaining. Here too, he is already abstaining!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא: כְּגוֹן שֶׁנִּכְנַס בְּשִׁידָּה תֵּיבָה וּמִגְדָּל, וּבָא חֲבֵירוֹ וּפָרַע מֵעָלָיו מַעֲזִיבָה.
human_translation: Rather, where entered in a chest, box, or cabinet, and another came and removed the top [ ma’aziva ] from above him,
llm_translation: Rather: for example, if one entered into a field, a box, and a tower, and his fellow came and removed the fence from above him.

hebrew_text: כִּי גְּמִירִין שְׁהִיָּיה, בְּבֵית הַמִּקְדָּשׁ, אֲבָל אַבָּרַאי — לָא. אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא? תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: When we learned delaying to the Temple, but outside not Or perhaps it is not different, shall stand
llm_translation: When they are complete, in the Temple, but in the house of study - no. Or perhaps it is not different? They remain unresolved.

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רַב אָשֵׁי: נָזַר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, טָעוּן גִּילּוּחַ, אוֹ לָא? כִּי בָּעֵי תִּגְלַחַת טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא, דְּקָא מְטַמֵּא לִנְזִירוּתֵיהּ, אֲבָל טָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר — לָא. אוֹ דִלְמָא לָא שְׁנָא?
human_translation: Rav Ashi raises a dilemma: one took a vow of naziriteship while in a cemetery, required to shave or not? When is required to shave a ritually pure who became impure, who has defiled his naziriteship? But a ritually impure who took a vow of naziriteship, not Or perhaps it is not different.
llm_translation: Inquires Rav Ashi: If one is a Nazirite and he is in a cemetery, does he require shaving or not? For when it comes to the shaving of a pure one who became impure, it causes defilement for his Naziriteship. But for an impure one who is a Nazirite — no. Or perhaps it is not different?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: מִי שֶׁנָּזַר וְהוּא בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, אֲפִילּוּ הָיָה שָׁם שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם — אֵינוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וְאֵינוֹ מֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה. קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה הוּא דְּלָא מַיְיתֵי, אֲבָל גַּלּוֹחֵי בָּעֵי! ״מַה טַּעַם״ קָאָמַר: מַה טַּעַם אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן טוּמְאָה — מִשּׁוּם דְּלָא בָּעֵי גַּלּוֹחֵי.
human_translation: Come hear One who took a vow of naziriteship while in a cemetery, even if he was there thirty days do not count of his tally, and he does not bring the offerings of impurity. It is the offerings of impurity he does not bring, but he is required to shave. is saying: What is the reason, What is the reason he does not bring the offerings of impurity? Because he does not require shaving.
llm_translation: Come and hear: One who takes a Nazarite vow while in a cemetery, even if he was there for thirty days - he does not count towards the number, and he does not bring a sacrifice for impurity. It is a sacrifice for impurity that he does not bring, but he requires shaving! "What is the reason?" it says: What is the reason he does not bring a sacrifice for impurity - because he does not require shaving.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֵין בֵּין טָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר לְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא, אֶלָּא טָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר — שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא — אֵין שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן. מַאי לָאו, הָא לְתִגְלַחַת זֶה וָזֶה שָׁוִין? לָא: הָא לְמַלְקוּת זֶה וָזֶה שָׁוִין.
human_translation: Come hear The difference between a ritually impure who took a vow of naziriteship and a ritually pure nazirite who became impure is only an impure who took a vow of naziriteship, his seventh counts of his tally but a pure nazirite who became impure, his seventh does not count of his tally. What, is it not with regard to shaving, this and that are equal, No, It is with regard to flogging this and that are equal,
llm_translation: Come and hear: There is no difference between an impure person who vowed to be a Nazirite and a pure Nazirite who became impure, except that an impure person who vowed to be a Nazirite - his seventh day counts towards completing his count, and a pure Nazirite who became impure - his seventh day does not count towards completing his count. What is the reason? Is it not because the shaving of both is equal? No, it is because the offering of both is equal.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל תִּגְלַחַת מַאי — זֶה מְגַלֵּחַ, וְזֶה אֵינוֹ מְגַלֵּחַ? לִיתְנְיֵיהּ! תְּנָא שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ וְכׇל מִילֵּי.
human_translation: But what shaving? this shave, and that not shave? let him teach this taught: His seventh day, and all matters
llm_translation: But what is "shaving"? This one shaves, and this one does not shave? Let it teach: The seventh day is his and all matters.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: אֵין לִי אֶלָּא יְמֵי טוּמְאָתוֹ שֶׁאֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, יְמֵי חִלּוּטוֹ, מִנַּיִן? וְדִין הוּא: מָה יְמֵי טוּמְאָתוֹ מְגַלֵּחַ וּמֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן — אַף יְמֵי חִלּוּטוֹ מְגַלֵּחַ וּמֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן, וּמָה יְמֵי טוּמְאָתוֹ אֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן — אַף יְמֵי חִלּוּטוֹ אֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן.
human_translation: Come hear I have only that days of ritual impurity do not count of his tally; from where his days of confirmed And by right Just as his days of ritual impurity shaves and brings offerings, so too his days of confirmed shaves and brings offerings And Just as the days of his ritual impurity do not count of his tally, so too his days of confirmed do not count of his tally.
llm_translation: Come and hear: I have only the days of his impurity that do not count towards his count, the days of his shaving, from where? And it is a logical deduction: just as the days of his impurity he shaves and brings a sacrifice - so too the days of his shaving he shaves and brings a sacrifice, and just as the days of his impurity do not count towards his count - so too the days of his shaving do not count towards his count.

hebrew_text: לֹא, אִם אָמַרְתָּ בִּימֵי טוּמְאָתוֹ, שֶׁכֵּן מְבַטֵּל בָּהֶן אֶת הַקּוֹדְמִין — לְפִיכָךְ אֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, תֹּאמַר בִּימֵי חִלּוּטוֹ, שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְבַטֵּל אֶת הַקּוֹדְמִין — לְפִיכָךְ עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן.
human_translation: No, if you say with regard to his days of ritual impurity, because with them, the previous are negated. Therefore, do not count of his tally. you say with regard to his days of confirmed which do not negate the previous therefore they do count of his tally.
llm_translation: Not, if you say in the days of his impurity, that he nullifies the previous ones - therefore he does not ascend from the count. Say in the days of his purity, that he does not nullify the previous ones - therefore they ascend from the count.

hebrew_text: אָמַרְתָּ: וּמָה נָזִיר בְּקֶבֶר שֶׁשְּׂעָרוֹ רָאוּי לְתִגְלַחַת — אֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, יְמֵי חִלּוּטוֹ שֶׁאֵין רָאוּי לְתִגְלַחַת, לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן שֶׁאֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן?
human_translation: you can say just as a nazirite in the grave, whose hair is fit for shaving, do not count of his tally, his days of confirmed which are not fit for shaving, not all the more so that they do not count of his tally?
llm_translation: You said: And what about a Nazirite whose hair is fit for shaving in a grave - they do not count for him from the count, the days of his defilement when his hair is not fit for shaving, all the more so that they do not count for him from the count?

hebrew_text: מַאי לָאו, תִּגְלַחַת טוּמְאָה? לָא, תִּגְלַחַת טׇהֳרָה. הָכִי נָמֵי מִסְתַּבְּרָא,
human_translation: What, is it not the shaving of impurity, No, the shaving of purity, So, too, it is reasonable
llm_translation: What is "Tiglachat Tum'ah"? Not "Tiglachat Taharah." Thus it was explained.

hebrew_text: דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ תִּגְלַחַת טוּמְאָה, יְמֵי חִלּוּטוֹ מִי לָא בָּעֵי תִּגְלַחַת? לָא, תִּגְלַחַת דִּנְזִירוּת קָתָנֵי.
human_translation: as if it enters your mind shaving impurity, days of confirmed not require shaving? No, is teaching shaving of naziriteship,
llm_translation: If your intention is to shave off impurity, does one not need to shave off his Nazirite days? No, shaving off refers to minor impurity.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״וְטִמֵּא רֹאשׁ נִזְרוֹ״, בְּטָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר, שֶׁהוּא טָעוּן הַעֲבָרַת שֵׂעָר וַהֲבָאַת צִיפֳּרִין. וְלִפְטוֹר אֶת הַנָּזִיר בְּקֶבֶר — שֶׁאֵין טָעוּן הַעֲבָרַת שֵׂעָר וַהֲבָאַת צִיפֳּרִין.
human_translation: Come hear “And he defiles his consecrated head, The verse is speaking of a ritually pure who became impure, who requires hair removal and the bringing of birds to exempt a nazirite in the grave, that he does not require hair removal and the bringing of birds.
llm_translation: Come and hear: "And he shall defile the head of his consecration," the Torah speaks of a pure Nazirite who became impure, for he requires shaving of hair and bringing of offerings. And to exempt the Nazirite in the grave - for he does not require shaving of hair and bringing of offerings.

hebrew_text: וַהֲלֹא דְּבָרִים קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא — טָעוּן הַעֲבָרַת שֵׂעָר וַהֲבָאַת צִיפֳּרִין, מִי שֶׁהָיָה טָמֵא מִתְּחִלָּה — אֵינוֹ דִּין שֶׁיְּהֵא טָעוּן הַעֲבָרַת שֵׂעָר וַהֲבָאַת צִיפֳּרִין?
human_translation: And are matters, not a fortiori inference Just as a pure who became impure requires hair removal and the bringing of birds, one was impure from the outset, is it not logical that he should require hair removal and the bringing of birds?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And are not these matters a fortiori: And what pure that became impure — requires shaving of hair and bringing of birds, one who was impure from the outset — is it not logical that he does not require shaving of hair and bringing of birds?"

hebrew_text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְטִמֵּא רֹאשׁ נִזְרוֹ״, בְּמִי שֶׁהָיָה טָהוֹר וְנִטְמָא הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר, שֶׁיְּהֵא טָעוּן הַעֲבָרַת שֵׂעָר וַהֲבָאַת צִיפֳּרִין, וְלִפְטוֹר אֶת הַנָּזִיר בְּקֶבֶר. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: the verse states: “And he defiles his consecrated head,” the verse speaks of one who was a pure and became impure, that he requires hair removal and the bringing of birds. And to exempt the nazirite in a grave, Learn from this
llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "And he shall defile the head of his consecration," regarding one who was pure and became impure, the Scripture speaks, that he needs to shave his hair and bring offerings, and to release the Nazirite in a cemetery. Learn from it.

hebrew_text: מַאן תְּנָא הָא דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: אֵין בֵּין טָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר לְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא, אֶלָּא שֶׁטָּמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר — שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, וְנָזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא — אֵין שְׁבִיעִי שֶׁלּוֹ עוֹלֶה לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן?
human_translation: Who taught this that the Sages taught The difference between an impure who took a vow of naziriteship and a pure nazirite who became ritually impure is only That an impure who took a vow of naziriteship, his seventh counts of his tally But a pure nazirite who became impure, his seventh does not count of his tally.
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna that taught the following teaching of the Rabbis: There is no difference between an impure person who vowed to be a Nazirite and a pure Nazirite who became impure, except that if the impure person who vowed to be a Nazirite becomes impure, his seventh day of purification counts towards his count, whereas a pure Nazirite who became impure, his seventh day of purification does not count towards his count?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רַבִּי הִיא, דְּאָמַר רַבִּי: אֵין נְזִירוּת טׇהֳרָה חָלָה אֶלָּא עַד שְׁמִינִי. דְּאִי תֵּימָא רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, הָאָמַר נְזִירוּת דְּטׇהֳרָה מִשְּׁבִיעִי הוּא דְּחָיְילָא.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi as Rabbi said: Naziriteship of purity takes effect only from the eighth day. For if you say it Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t he say naziriteship of purity takes effect from the seventh
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Hiya, for Rabbi said: The purity of a Nazirite only becomes defiled until the eighth day. For if you were to say it is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, he said that the purity of a Nazirite becomes defiled from the seventh day onward.

hebrew_text: מַאי רַבִּי וּמַאי רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה — דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְקִדַּשׁ אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא״ — בְּיוֹם הֲבָאַת קׇרְבְּנוֹתָיו, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי. רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: בְּיוֹם תִּגְלַחְתּוֹ.
human_translation: What is Rabbi and what is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, As it is taught “And he shall sanctify his head on that day” on the day of the bringing of his offerings, the statement of Rabbi Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: on the day of his shaving,
llm_translation: What is the opinion of Rabbi and what is the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda? As it was taught: "And he shall consecrate his head on that day" - on the day of bringing his sacrifices, the words of Rabbi. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: on the day of his shaving.

hebrew_text: וְהָא דִּתְנַן: נָזִיר שֶׁנִּטְמָא טוּמְאוֹת הַרְבֵּה — אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא אֶלָּא קׇרְבָּן אֶחָד, מַאן תַּנָּא? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, דְּאָמַר: נְזִירוּת טׇהֳרָה מִשְּׁבִיעִי חָיְילָא. וּמַשְׁכַּחַתְּ לַהּ כְּגוֹן שֶׁנִּטְמָא בַּשְּׁבִיעִי, וְחָזַר וְנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁבִיעִי. (וּמַנִּי, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא) כֵּיוָן דְּלֹא יָצָא שָׁעָה הָרְאוּיָה לְהָבִיא קׇרְבָּן — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא קׇרְבָּן אֶחָד.
human_translation: And that which we learned a nazirite became impure many impurities, he brings only one offerings. Who taught Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who said naziriteship of purity takes effect from the seventh And you find this, where he became ritually impure on the seventh and, again became ritually impure on the seventh And whose It is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. Since appropriate time to bring an offering had not arrived, he is obligated bring only one offerings.
llm_translation: And this that we learned: A Nazirite who became impure with many impurities - he only brings one offering, who taught this? Rav Ḥisdah said: It is Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: "Naziriteship of purity from the seventh day is a severe matter." And you find an example of one who became impure on the seventh day, and then returned and became impure on the seventh day again. (And who is it? Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda) Since the proper time to bring the offering has not passed - he is only obligated to bring one offering.

hebrew_text: דְּאִי תֵּימָא רַבִּי הִיא, אִי דְּנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁבִיעִי, וְחָזַר וְנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁבִיעִי (וְחָזַר וְנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁבִיעִי) — כּוּלְּהוּ טוּמְאָה אֲרִיכְתָּא הִיא. וְאִי דְּנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁמִינִי, וְחָזַר וְנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁמִינִי — הֲרֵי יָצְתָה שָׁעָה שֶׁרְאוּיָה לְהָבִיא קׇרְבָּן.
human_translation: For if you say it Rabbi If who became ritually impure on the seventh and, again became ritually impure on the seventh and, again became ritually impure on the seventh all these are long ritual impurity, And if who became ritually impure on the eighth and, again became ritually impure on the eighth appropriate time to bring an offering had arrived,
llm_translation: If you say it is Rabbi Hiya, if he became impure on the seventh day, and then became impure again on the seventh day (and then became impure again on the seventh day) - all of them are considered one long period of impurity. But if he became impure on the eighth day, and then became impure again on the eighth day - a moment has arrived that is fitting to bring a sacrifice.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי? אָמַר קְרָא ״וְכִפֶּר עָלָיו מֵאֲשֶׁר חָטָא עַל הַנָּפֶשׁ״, וַהֲדַר ״וְקִדַּשׁ אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ״. וְרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה: אִם כֵּן — לֵימָא קְרָא: ״וְקִדַּשׁ אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ״.
human_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi The verse states: and make atonement for him, for he sinned by the soul” and again “And he shall sanctify his head.” And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, If so, let the verse state: “And he shall sanctify his head,”
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi's opinion? The verse says, "and he shall make atonement for him for the soul that he sinned against," and then it says, "and he shall sanctify his head." And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, if so - let the verse say, "and he shall sanctify his head."

hebrew_text: ״בְּיוֹם הַהוּא״ לְמָה לִי? אִם אֵינוֹ עִנְיָן לִשְׁמִינִי, תְּנֵהוּ עִנְיָן לִשְׁבִיעִי. וְרַבִּי נָמֵי, הָכְתִיב ״בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא״? אָמַר לְךָ רַבִּי: הָהוּא לְהָכִי הוּא דַּאֲתָא — לוֹמַר לָךְ: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֵבִיא קׇרְבְּנוֹתָיו.
human_translation: Why do I “on that day” if it does not to the matter eighth apply it to the matter of seventh And Rabbi also, isn’t it written “on that day”? Rabbi said to you: That comes for this to tell you even though he did not bring his offerings,
llm_translation: "On that day" - why do I need it? If it is not relevant for the eighth day, give it relevance for the seventh. And Rabbi Nami, is it written "on that day"? Rabbi said to you: That phrase comes to teach you that even though he did not bring his sacrifices.

hebrew_text: וְרַב חִסְדָּא, מַאי דּוּחְקֵיהּ לְאוֹקֹמַיהּ כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה? לוֹקְמַהּ כְּגוֹן דְּנִטְמָא דְּחַזְיָא בְּלֵיל שְׁמִינִי, וְרַבִּי הִיא!
human_translation: And what forced Rav Ḥisda to establish in accordance with Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda? Let him establish it where became impure by seeing, on the night the eighth And it is Rabbi
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda, what is the reason that he was distressed to establish it like Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda? He established it, for example, like the case of the impure one who saw on the eighth night, and it is Rabbi Hiya!

hebrew_text: מִדְּלָא מוֹקֵים לַהּ כְּרַבִּי, לֵימָא קָסָבַר לֵילְיָא לָאו מְחוּסַּר זְמַן הוּא?
human_translation: Since he did not establish it in accordance with Rabbi shall we say that holds night is not premature?
llm_translation: From the fact that he does not establish it like Rabbi, let us say: Does he hold that nighttime is not considered a lacking of time?

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב אַדָּא בַּר אַהֲבָה: הָא בְּהָא תַּלְיָא. אִי אָמְרַתְּ לֵילְיָא מְחוּסַּר זְמַן, אֵימַת מִיחְזֵי לְקׇרְבָּן — לְצַפְרָא, נְזִירוּת נָמֵי לָא חָיְילָא עַד צַפְרָא. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ לֵילְיָא אֵינוֹ מְחוּסַּר זְמַן — נְזִירוּת טׇהֳרָה חָיְילָא מֵאוּרְתָּא.
human_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava said: depend on each other: If you say night is premature, when is fit to offerings? in the morning. naziriteship also does not take effect until the morning. And if you say night is not premature, naziriteship of purity takes effect from the evening,
llm_translation: Rav Adda bar Ahava said: This depends on that condition. If you say it is nighttime and there is insufficient time, when will he see the offering? - In the morning, the Nazirites do not have the ability until the morning. And if you say it is not nighttime and there is no lack of time - the purity of the Nazirites is more significant than the light.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא: נִטְמָא בַּשְּׁבִיעִי, וְחָזַר וְנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁבִיעִי — אֵינוֹ מֵבִיא אֶלָּא קׇרְבָּן אֶחָד. נִטְמָא בַּשְּׁמִינִי, וְחָזַר וְנִטְמָא בַּשְּׁמִינִי — מֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן עַל כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד. מַתְחִיל וּמוֹנֶה מִיָּד, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר.
human_translation: the itself: became impure on the seventh and again became impure on the seventh he brings only one offerings. he became impure on the eighth and again became impure on the eighth he brings offerings for each and every begins counting immediately the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.
llm_translation: Body: Becomes impure on the seventh, and then became impure on the seventh - he brings only one offering. Becomes impure on the eighth, and then became impure on the eighth - he brings an offering for each and every one. He begins and counts immediately, the words of Rabbi Eliezer.

hebrew_text: וַחֲכָמִים אוֹמְרִים: קׇרְבָּן אֶחָד עַל הַכֹּל, עַד שֶׁיָּבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ. הֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ וְנִטְמָא, וְהֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ וְנִטְמָא — מֵבִיא קׇרְבָּן עַל כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד. הֵבִיא חַטָּאתוֹ וְלֹא הֵבִיא אֲשָׁמוֹ — מוֹנֶה.
human_translation: And the Rabbis say: one offerings for all until he has brought his sin-offering brought his sin-offering and became impure, and brought his sin-offering and became impure, he brings offerings for each and every one. If he brought his sin-offering and did not bring his guilt-offering, count
llm_translation: The Sages say: "One offering for everything, until he brings his sin offering. He brought his sin offering and became impure, and he brought his sin offering and became impure - he brings an offering for each and every one. He brought his sin offering but did not bring his guilt offering - he counts."

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן בְּרוֹקָה אוֹמֵר: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁחַטָּאתוֹ עִיכְּבַתּוּ, כֵּן אֲשָׁמוֹ מְעַכְּבוֹ.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: Just as his sin-offering precludes him so his guilt-offering precludes him
llm_translation: Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yochanan ben Baroka, says: Just as his sin delays him, so too does his guilt delay him.

hebrew_text: בִּשְׁלָמָא לְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, אָמַר קְרָא ״וְקִדַּשׁ אֶת רֹאשׁוֹ בַּיּוֹם הַהוּא״ — אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֵבִיא קׇרְבְּנוֹתָיו. וְרַבָּנַן: ״הַהוּא״ — אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֵבִיא אֲשָׁמוֹ.
human_translation: Granted, according to Rabbi Eliezer, the verse states: “And he shall sanctify his head on that day” Even though he has not brought his offerings, And the Rabbis that even though he has not brought his guilt-offering,
llm_translation: In peace to Rabbi Eliezer, it was said: Scripture says, "And he shall consecrate his head on that day" — even though he did not bring his sacrifices. And the Rabbis say: "On that day" — even though he did not bring his guilt offering.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל, ״הָהוּא״ לְמָה לִי? אָמַר לָךְ: ״הַהוּא״ — אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֵבִיא עוֹלָתוֹ. וְרַבָּנַן: עוֹלָה לָא בָּעֵי מִיעוּטָא — דּוֹרוֹן בְּעָלְמָא הוּא.
human_translation: But Rabbi Yishmael, why do I that said to you: that even though he has not brought his burnt-offering, And the Rabbis A burnt-offering does not require a limitation it is merely a gift
llm_translation: Rather Rabbi Yishmael, "that one" what to me? He said to you: "that one" - even though he did not bring his burnt offering. And the sages: a burnt offering does not require a minimal amount - it is merely a voluntary offering.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמַיְיהוּ דְּרַבָּנַן? דְּתַנְיָא: ״וְהִזִּיר לַה׳ אֶת יְמֵי נִזְרוֹ וְהֵבִיא כֶּבֶשׂ בֶּן שְׁנָתוֹ לְאָשָׁם״, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר? לְפִי שֶׁמָּצִינוּ שֶׁכׇּל אֲשָׁמוֹת שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה שֶׁהֵן מְעַכְּבִין, יָכוֹל אַף זֶה מְעַכְּבוֹ —
human_translation: What is the reason of the Rabbis As it is taught “And he shall consecrate to the Lord the days of his naziriteship, and he shall bring a lamb in its first year for a guilt-offering” What does this teach? since we have found that all guilt-offerings that are in the Torah are indispensable might this also precludes him
llm_translation: What is the reason of the Rabbis? For it was taught: "And he shall consecrate to the Lord the days of his Naziriteship, and shall bring a male lamb in its first year for a guilt offering." What is the Talmud to say? Because we have found that all guilt offerings in the Torah, which delay, might this one also delay—

hebrew_text: תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהִזִּיר ... וְהֵבִיא״, אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא הֵבִיא — הִזִּיר. רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן בְּרוֹקָה אוֹמֵר: ״וְהִזִּיר ... וְהֵבִיא״, אֵימָתַי הִזִּיר — בִּזְמַן שֶׁהֵבִיא.
human_translation: the verse states: “And he shall consecrate and he shall bring Even though he has not brought he has consecrated naziriteship. Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, The verse states: “And he shall consecrate and he shall bring,” When has he consecrated naziriteship, when he has brought
llm_translation: The Talmud teaches: "And he shall sprinkle ... and bring," even though he did not bring — he shall sprinkle. Rabbi Yishmael, the son of Rabbi Yochanan ben Brokah, says: "And he shall sprinkle ... and bring," when shall he sprinkle? When he has brought.

hebrew_text: מַאן תְּנָא לְהָא דְּתָנוּ רַבָּנַן: אִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר וְנִטְמְאָה, וְאַחַר כָּךְ הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעֲלָהּ — מְבִיאָה חַטַּאת הָעוֹף, וְאֵינָהּ מְבִיאָה עוֹלַת הָעוֹף.
human_translation: Who taught this that the Sages taught: a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and became ritually impure, and afterward her husband nullified for her, she brings the bird sin-offering and she does not bring the bird burnt-offering?
llm_translation: Who is the Tanna that taught this that the Rabbis taught: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite and became impure, and afterwards her husband annulled it for her - she brings a sin offering of a bird, but she does not bring a burnt offering of a bird.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל הִיא.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yishmael,
llm_translation: Said Rav Hisda: Rabbi Yishmael is he.

hebrew_text: מַאי קָסָבַר? אִי קָסָבַר בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר — חַטַּאת הָעוֹף נָמֵי לָא לַיְיתֵי. אִי קָסָבַר בַּעַל מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז, עוֹלַת הָעוֹף נָמֵי לַיְיתֵי! לְעוֹלָם קָסָבַר בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר, וְרַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל סָבַר לַהּ כְּרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר.
human_translation: What does he hold? If he holds husband uproots she should not bring the bird sin-offering, if he holds husband severs she should also bring the bird burnt-offering, Actually, he holds husband uproots and Rabbi Yishmael holds in accordance with Rabbi Elazar HaKappar.
llm_translation: What does he hold? If he holds that the Ba'al Mi'akar uprooted, the sin offering of a bird should not be brought. If he holds that the Ba'al Migaz gayez, the burnt offering of a bird should be brought! Rather, he holds that the Ba'al Mi'akar uprooted, and Rabbi Yishmael holds like Rabbi Elazar HaKappar.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר בְּרַבִּי אוֹמֵר: מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״וְכִפֶּר עָלָיו מֵאֲשֶׁר חָטָא עַל הַנָּפֶשׁ״? וְכִי בְּאֵיזוֹ נֶפֶשׁ חָטָא זֶה? אֶלָּא שֶׁצִּיעֵר עַצְמוֹ מִן הַיַּיִן. וְקַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה זֶה שֶׁלֹּא צִיעֵר עַצְמוֹ אֶלָּא מִן הַיַּיִן נִקְרָא חוֹטֵא, הַמְצַעֵר עַצְמוֹ מִכׇּל דָּבָר עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה.
human_translation: As it is taught Rabbi Elazar HaKappar, the esteemed one, says: What the verse states “And make atonement for him, for he sinned by the soul” And with which soul did this sin Rather, afflicting himself from wine, And an a fortiori Just as this afflicting himself only from wine, is called a sinner, one who afflicts himself from everything, all the more so
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Elazar HaKappar, son of Rabbi says: What is the Talmud teaching us by stating, "and he shall make atonement for him for that which he sinned against the soul"? In what soul did he sin? Rather, he afflicted himself with wine. And a fortiori: If one who did not afflict himself except with wine is called a sinner, how much more so one who afflicts himself with anything at all.

hebrew_text: וְהָא בְּנָזִיר טָמֵא כְּתִיב, וַאֲנַן אֲפִילּוּ נָזִיר טָהוֹר קָאָמְרִינַן! קָסָבַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר נָזִיר טָהוֹר נָמֵי חוֹטֵא הוּא, וְהַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דִּכְתִיב בְּנָזִיר טָמֵא — הוֹאִיל וְשָׁנָה בַּחֵטְא.
human_translation: But this is written with regard to an impure nazirite, and we are saying even a pure nazirite Rabbi Elazar HaKappar holds a pure nazirite is also a sinner. And this is the reason that is written to an impure nazirite Since he repeated his sin,
llm_translation: And this, in the case of a Nazirite who is impure, it is written, yet we say even if a Nazirite is pure! Rabbi Elazar HaKappar holds that a pure Nazirite is also considered a sinner, and this is the reason it is written regarding an impure Nazirite - since he has changed through sin.

hebrew_text: יָצָא וְנִכְנַס — עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן. קָתָנֵי עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן. מִשּׁוּם דְּיָצָא חָל עֲלֵיהּ נְזִירוּת? אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כְּגוֹן שֶׁיָּצָא וְהִזָּה וְשָׁנָה וְטָבַל.
human_translation: left and entered do count of his tally teaches: They do count of his tally. Does naziriteship take effect for him because he left Shmuel said: where he left and sprinkling and again and immersed,
llm_translation: He went out and came back - they count him in the tally. The Mishnah teaches: they count him in the tally. Because he went out, did a vow fall upon him? Shmuel said: For example, if he went out, shaved, changed, and immersed.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא נִכְנַס הוּא דְּעוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן, לֹא נִכְנַס אֵין עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן?! לָא מִיבַּעְיָא קָאָמַר: לָא מִיבַּעְיָא יָצָא, אֶלָּא אֲפִילּוּ נִכְנַס — עוֹלִין לוֹ מִן הַמִּנְיָן.
human_translation: however, entered count of his tally, not enter, do not count of his tally? is speaking It is not necessary, It is not necessary left but even if he entered count of his tally,
llm_translation: Rather, he who has guests coming to him from the count, if he did not enter, do not enter for him from the count?! Not that he is asking: not that he is asking he went out, rather, even if he entered - enter for him from the count.

hebrew_text: אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ רַב כָּהֲנָא וְרַב אַסִּי לְרַב: מַאי טַעְמָא לָא מְפָרְשַׁתְּ לַן כְּהָלֵין מִילֵּי? אָמַר לְהוֹן: אָמֵינָא דִּלְמָא לָא צְרִיכִיתוּ.
human_translation: Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: What is the reason you did not explain to us with these words He said to them: I said perhaps you do not require that
llm_translation: They said to him, Rav Kahana and Rav Assi said to Rav: What is the reason that you did not explain to us these matters? He said to them: I thought perhaps you did not need it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: לֹא בּוֹ בְּיוֹם — שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהַיָּמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים יִפְּלוּ״ — עַד שֶׁיִּהְיוּ יָמִים רִאשׁוֹנִים. אָמַר עוּלָּא: לָא אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אֶלָּא בְּטָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר, אֲבָל בַּנָּזִיר טָהוֹר שֶׁנִּטְמָא — אֲפִילּוּ יוֹם אֶחָד סוֹתֵר.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: not on that very day as it is stated “But the first days shall be void” unless he had “first days” Ulla said: Rabbi Eliezer said only with regard to an impure who took a vow of naziriteship, but a pure nazirite who became impure, even one day it negates
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: Not in him on the day - as it is said: "And the former days shall be forgotten" - until they are former days. Ulla said: Rabbi Eliezer only said this regarding a defiled Nazirite, but regarding a pure Nazirite who became impure - even one day nullifies.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? אָמַר קְרָא: ״כִּי טָמֵא נִזְרוֹ״ — מִשּׁוּם דִּבְטוּמְאָה נְזַר.
human_translation: Rava said: What is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer, The verse states: because his consecration was ritually impure” because he took a vow of naziriteship, when in ritual impurity.
llm_translation: Rava said: What is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer's opinion? The verse says: "For his separation is defiled" - because a nazirite vow is defiled.

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר מֵאָה יוֹם״, וְנִטְמָא בִּתְחִלַּת מֵאָה, יָכוֹל יְהֵא סוֹתֵר, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהַיָּמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים יִפְּלוּ״ — עַד שֶׁיְּהוּ לוֹ יָמִים רִאשׁוֹנִים, וְזֶה אֵין לוֹ רִאשׁוֹנִים.
human_translation: Abaye raised an objection to I am hereby a nazirite one hundred days, and he became ritually impure at the beginning one hundred might it should negate The verse states: “But the first days shall be void” until he will have “first days” and this does not have first
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Abaye: "Behold, I am a Nazirite for one hundred days," and he became impure at the beginning of one hundred days, can he possibly annul? The verse teaches us: "And the former days shall be void" - until he has former days, and this one does not have former days.

hebrew_text: נִטְמָא בְּסוֹף מֵאָה, יָכוֹל יְהֵא סוֹתֵר, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהַיָּמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים יִפְּלוּ״ — מִכְּלָל דְּאִיכָּא אַחֲרוֹנִים, וְזֶה אֵין לוֹ אַחֲרוֹנִים. נִטְמָא בְּיוֹם מֵאָה חָסֵר אַחַת, יָכוֹל לֹא יְהֵא סוֹתֵר, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְהַיָּמִים הָרִאשׁוֹנִים יִפְּלוּ״ — מִכְּלָל דְּאִיכָּא אַחֲרוֹנִים, וְזֶה יֵשׁ לוֹ רִאשׁוֹנִים וְאַחֲרוֹנִים.
human_translation: became ritually impure at the end of one hundred might it should negate The verse states: “But the first days shall be void,” by inference that there are last while this does not have last he became impure on the one hundredth day less one, might it should not negate Therefore, the verse states: “But the first days shall be void,” by inference that there are last and this has first and last
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If he became impure at the end of one hundred, can he possibly annul? The Scripture says: "And the former days shall be forgotten" - implying that there are latter days, and this one does not have latter days. If he became impure on the day of one hundred lacking one, can he possibly not annul? The Scripture says: "And the former days shall be forgotten" - implying that there are latter days, and this one has former and latter days.

hebrew_text: וְהָא, בְּטָמֵא שֶׁנָּזַר לָא מָצֵית אָמְרַתְּ, מִדְּקָתָנֵי ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר מֵאָה״, וְנִטְמָא בִּתְחִלַּת מֵאָה, וְקָתָנֵי ״עַד שֶׁיְּהוּ לוֹ יָמִים רִאשׁוֹנִים״, תְּיוּבְתָּא.
human_translation: But this you cannot say to an impure who took a vow of naziriteship from that it teaches: I am hereby a nazirite one hundred and he became impure at the beginning one hundred, And it teaches: Until he will have “first days,” a conclusive refutation
llm_translation: And this, in a case of one who became impure after taking a Nazirite vow, you did not find a case where she said, "I am a Nazirite for one hundred days," and became impure at the beginning of one hundred days, and it is taught, "until he has completed the initial days," this is a contradiction.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב פָּפָּא לְאַבָּיֵי: הָלֵין יָמִים דְּקָאָמְרִינַן, דְּנָפֵק חַד וּמַתְחִילִין תְּרֵין, אוֹ דִּלְמָא דְּנָפְקִין תְּרֵין וּמַתְחִילִין תְּלָתָא? לָא הֲוָה בִּידֵיהּ, אֲתָא שַׁיְילֵיהּ לְרָבָא. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: ״יִפְּלוּ״ כְּתִיב.
human_translation: Rav Pappa said to Abaye: Those days that we said that one has finished and a second has started, or perhaps that two have finished, and a third has started, was not available to him, went ask Rava, said to him: is written: shall be void [ yippelu ]”
llm_translation: He said to him Rav Papa to Abbaye: "The days that we say, when one goes out and begins two, or perhaps when two go out and begin three? It was not in his hands, he brought it to Rava. He said to him: 'They shall fall' is written."
