hebrew_text: וְאִיצְטְרִיךְ לְמִיכְתַּב ״יָמִים״ וְאִיצְטְרִיךְ לְמִיכְתַּב ״יִפְּלוּ״, דְּאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״יָמִים״ וְלָא כְּתַב ״יִפְּלוּ״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: עַד דְּנָפְקִין תְּרֵין וְעָיְילִין תְּלָתָא, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״יִפְּלוּ״. וְאִי כְּתַב ״יִפְּלוּ״ וְלָא כְּתַב ״יָמִים״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא אֲפִילּוּ חַד, כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״יָמִים״.
human_translation: And it was necessary to write “days” and it was necessary to write “shall be void” For if the Merciful One wrote “days” and had not written “shall be void” I would say that if two have finished and a third has started. The Merciful One wrote “shall be void.” And if wrote “shall be void” and had not written “days,” I would say even one The Merciful One wrote “days,”
llm_translation: The text reads: "And it was necessary to write 'days' and it was necessary to write 'they shall fall,' for if the Merciful One had written 'days' and not written 'they shall fall,' I would have said: until two come out and three go in, the Merciful One wrote 'they shall fall.' And if He had written 'they shall fall' and not written 'days,' I would have said even one, the Merciful One wrote 'days.'"

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁנָּזַר נְזִירוּת הַרְבֵּה, וְהִשְׁלִים אֶת נְזִירוּתוֹ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ בָּא לָאָרֶץ, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: נָזִיר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם, וּבֵית הִילֵּל אוֹמְרִים: נָזִיר בַּתְּחִלָּה.
human_translation: One who vowed many naziriteship and completed his naziriteship, and afterward came to Eretz Beit Shammai say: a nazirite thirty days, and Beit Hillel say: a nazirite from the beginning,
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One who increases his Nazirite vow and completes his Nazirite vow, and then comes to the land, Beit Shammai say: A Nazirite for thirty days, and Beit Hillel say: A Nazirite from the beginning.

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּהֵילֵנִי הַמַּלְכָּה שֶׁהָלַךְ בְּנָהּ לְמִלְחָמָה, וְאָמְרָה: אִם יָבוֹא בְּנִי מִן הַמִּלְחָמָה בְּשָׁלוֹם — אֱהֵא נְזִירָה שֶׁבַע שָׁנִים. וּבָא בְּנָהּ מִן הַמִּלְחָמָה, וְהָיְתָה נְזִירָה שֶׁבַע שָׁנִים, וּבְסוֹף שֶׁבַע שָׁנִים עָלְתָה לָאָרֶץ, וְהוֹרוּהָ בֵּית הִלֵּל שֶׁתְּהֵא נְזִירָה עוֹד שֶׁבַע שָׁנִים אֲחֵרוֹת. וּבְסוֹף שֶׁבַע שָׁנִים נִטְמֵאת. וְנִמְצֵאת נְזִירָה עֶשְׂרִים וְאַחַת שָׁנָה. אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוּדָה: לֹא הָיְתָה נְזִירָה אֶלָּא אַרְבַּע עֶשְׂרֵה שָׁנָה.
human_translation: An incident with regard to Queen Helene, whose son had gone to war, and she said: If my son will return from war safely, I will be a nazirite seven years. And her son returned from the war, and she was a nazirite seven years. And at the end of seven years, she ascended to Eretz and Beit Hillel instructed her, that she should be a nazirite for an additional seven years. And at the end of seven years she became ritually impure, And she was found to be a nazirite twenty-one years. Rabbi Yehuda said: She was a nazirite only fourteen years
llm_translation: The story of Queen Helena, whose son went to war, and she said: If my son returns from the war in peace - let me be a Nazirite for seven years. And her son returned from the war, and she was a Nazirite for seven years. At the end of the seven years, she went up to the Land, and the House of Hillel ruled that she should be a Nazirite for another seven years. And at the end of the seven years, she became defiled. And she was found to be a Nazirite for twenty-one years. Rabbi Yehuda said: She was a Nazirite for only fourteen years.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ קָתָנֵי רֵישָׁא: בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: נָזִיר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם, וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: נָזִיר בַּתְּחִלָּה. לֵימָא בְּהָא קָמִיפַּלְגִי, דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי סָבְרִי: אֶרֶץ הָעַמִּים מִשּׁוּם גּוּשָׁהּ גָּזְרוּ עָלֶיהָ,
human_translation: The first clause teaches Beit Shammai say: a nazirite thirty days, and Beit Hillel say: a nazirite from the beginning. Let us say that they disagree about this, Beit Shammai hold land of the nations they decreed with regard to its earth.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches in the beginning: Beit Shammai say: a Nazirite for thirty days, and Beit Hillel say: a Nazirite initially. Let us say in this case, that Beit Shammai hold: the land of the nations they decreed upon it due to its winepress.

hebrew_text: וּבֵית הִלֵּל סָבְרִי: מִשּׁוּם אַוֵּירָא גָּזְרוּ עָלֶיהָ? לָא, דְּכוּלֵּי עָלְמָא מִשּׁוּם גּוּשָׁהּ גָּזְרוּ עָלֶיהָ, וּבֵית שַׁמַּאי סָבְרִי בִּסְתָם נְזִירוּת קָנֵיסְנָא, וּבֵית הִלֵּל סָבְרִי: כִּי קָנֵיסְנָא — בִּתְחִילַּת נְזִירוּת.
human_translation: and Beit Hillel hold: They decreed with regard to its airspace, No, that everyone they decreed with regard to its earth, and Beit Shammai hold we penalize with an unspecified term of naziriteship, and Beit Hillel hold when we penalize, to the beginning of naziriteship,
llm_translation: House of Hillel hold: Because of 'Avira they decreed upon it? No, for the whole world they decreed upon it because of its hair, and House of Shammai hold: In general Naziriteship we acquire, and House of Hillel hold: When we acquire — at the beginning of Naziriteship.

hebrew_text: מַעֲשֶׂה בְּהֵילֵנִי הַמַּלְכָּה וְכוּ׳. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: בְּשֶׁנִּטְמֵאת, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי? אוֹ דִּלְמָא בְּשֶׁלֹּא נִטְמֵאת, וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית הִלֵּל?
human_translation: An incident with regard to Queen Helene. A dilemma was raised before them: where she became impure and in accordance with Beit Shammai, Or perhaps where she did not become impure and in accordance with Beit Hillel
llm_translation: The story of Queen Helena, etc. They asked: When she became impure, should she follow the opinion of Beit Shammai? Or perhaps when she did not become impure, should she follow the opinion of Beit Hillel?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: עָלְתָה לָאָרֶץ, וְהוֹרוּהָ בֵּית הִלֵּל שֶׁתְּהֵא נְזִירָה עוֹד שֶׁבַע שָׁנִים אֲחֵרוֹת וְכוּ׳. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בְּשֶׁנִּטְמֵאת וְאַלִּיבָּא דְּבֵית שַׁמַּאי, אִי הָכִי, ״רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר לֹא הָיְתָה נְזִירָה אֶלָּא אַרְבַּע עֶשְׂרֵה שָׁנָה״? ״אַרְבַּע עֶשְׂרֵה שָׁנָה וּשְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם״ מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ!
human_translation: Come hear She ascended to Eretz and Beit Hillel instructed her that she should be a nazirite for an additional seven years, etc. And if it enters your mind where she became ritually impure and in accordance with of Beit Shammai, if so, Rabbi Yehuda say she was a nazirite only fourteen years? He should have fourteen years and thirty days,
llm_translation: Come and hear: She ascended to the Land, and the House of Hillel instructed that she should be a Nazirite for another seven years, etc. And if it enters your mind that she became impure and inclined towards the opinion of Beit Shammai, if so, "Rabbi Yehuda says she was a Nazirite only for fourteen years"? "Fourteen years and thirty days" - this is what he requires!

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: דְּאָמַר קְרָא ״זֹאת תּוֹרַת הַנָּזִיר״, הַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה: כִּי נִטְמָא בְּיוֹם מְלֹאת — תֵּן לוֹ תּוֹרַת נָזִיר.
human_translation: This is also taught Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer that the verse states: “This is the law of the nazirite The Torah states: When he becomes impure on the day of the completion give him the law of nazirite,
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: As the verse states, "This is the law of the Nazirite," the Torah said: If he becomes defiled on the day of his completion, give him the law of a Nazirite.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ מִי שֶׁהָיוּ שְׁתֵּי כִּיתֵּי עֵדִים מְעִידוֹת אוֹתוֹ, אֵלּוּ מְעִידִים שֶׁנָּזַר שְׁתַּיִם, וְאֵלּוּ מְעִידִים שֶׁנָּזַר חָמֵשׁ, בֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: נֶחְלְקָה הָעֵדוּת — וְאֵין כָּאן נְזִירוּת, וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: יֵשׁ בִּכְלַל חָמֵשׁ שְׁתַּיִם, שֶׁיְּהֵא נָזִיר שְׁתַּיִם.
human_translation: one who had two sets of witnesses testifying about him these testify that he took a vow of naziriteship two and these testify that he took a vow of naziriteship five Beit Shammai say: The testimony is divided, and there is no naziriteship here And Beit Hillel say: two are included in five that he is a nazirite two
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: If two groups of witnesses testify about him, these testify that he became a Nazir for two time periods, and these testify that he became a Nazir for five time periods. Beit Shammai says: The testimonies are contradictory, and there is no Nazirite status here. Beit Hillel says: There is a total of five time periods, so that he should be a Nazir for two time periods.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַתְנִיתִין דְּלָא כִּי הַאי תַּנָּא, דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל בְּנוֹ שֶׁל רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן בֶּן בְּרוֹקָא אוֹמֵר: לֹא נֶחְלְקוּ בֵּית שַׁמַּאי וּבֵית הִלֵּל עַל שְׁתֵּי כִּיתֵּי עֵדִים, אַחַת אוֹמֶרֶת שְׁתַּיִם, וְאַחַת אוֹמֶרֶת חָמֵשׁ, שֶׁיֵּשׁ בִּכְלַל חָמֵשׁ שְׁתַּיִם. עַל מָה נֶחְלְקוּ — עַל כַּת אַחַת, אֶחָד אוֹמֵר שְׁתַּיִם, וְאֶחָד אוֹמֵר חָמֵשׁ, שֶׁבֵּית שַׁמַּאי אוֹמְרִים: נֶחְלְקָה עֵדוּתָן. וּבֵית הִלֵּל אוֹמְרִים: יֵשׁ בִּכְלַל חָמֵשׁ שְׁתַּיִם.
human_translation: The mishna is not in accordance with this tanna , as it is taught Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree with regard to two sets of witnesses, one says two and one says five that two are included in five With regard to what did they disagree? with regard to one set one says two and one says five that Beit Shammai say: their testimony is divided, And Beit Hillel say: two are included in five
llm_translation: Gemara: Mishnah that is not like this Tanna, as it was taught: Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yochanan ben Broka, says: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel did not disagree regarding two groups of witnesses, one saying two and one saying five, for five includes two. What did they disagree about? On one group, one says two and one says five. Beit Shammai says: Their testimony is in disagreement. Beit Hillel says: Five includes two.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב: הַכֹּל מוֹדִים בְּמוֹנֶה. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב חָמָא לְרַב חִסְדָּא: מַאי קָאָמַר? אִילֵּימָא: אֶחָד אוֹמֵר חָמֵשׁ וְלֹא שְׁתַּיִם, וְאֶחָד אוֹמֵר שְׁתַּיִם וְלֹא חָמֵשׁ — הָא קָא מַכְחֲשִׁי אַהֲדָדֵי! אֶלָּא: אֶחָד אוֹמֵר אַחַת וּשְׁתַּיִם, וְאֶחָד אוֹמֵר שָׁלֹשׁ אַרְבַּע חָמֵשׁ.
human_translation: Rav said: All concede in counting Rav Ḥama said to Rav Ḥisda: What is he saying; If we say that one says: five and not two and one says: two and not five they contradict one another, Rather, one says one and two and one says three, four, five
llm_translation: Rav said: Everyone agrees with the counter. Rav Ḥama said to Rav Ḥisda: What is he saying? If you say: One says five and not two, and one says two and not five - they are contradicting each other! Rather, one says one and two, and one says three, four, five.

hebrew_text: הָא לְמָה לִי? הַשְׁתָּא יֵשׁ לוֹמַר: חֲמִירְתָּא אָמַר רַב, קִילְּתָא לָא אָמַר?! אָמְרִי בְּמַעְרְבָא: אֵין הַכְחָשָׁה בְּמוֹנֶה.
human_translation: Why do I this Now that it is said a stringent Rav said a lenient not say They say in the West, There is no conflicting in counting,
llm_translation: "This, why to me? Now there is to say: a donkey said Rav, a dog did not say?! They said in the West: there is no denial in a count."

hebrew_text: הַדְרָן עֲלָךְ מִי שֶׁאָמַר
llm_translation: We will return to you, saying "Who said..."

hebrew_text: מִי שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״ וְשָׁמַע חֲבֵירוֹ וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״, ״וַאֲנִי״ — כּוּלָּם נְזִירִים. הוּתַּר הָרִאשׁוֹן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן. הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר וְכוּלָּם אֲסוּרִין. אָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״, וְשָׁמַע חֲבֵירוֹ וְאָמַר ״פִּי כְּפִיו וּשְׂעָרִי כִּשְׂעָרוֹ״ — הֲרֵי זֶה נָזִיר.
human_translation: one who said: I am hereby a nazirite, and another heard and said: And I, And I, they are all nazirites. the first was dissolved they are all dissolved. the last was dissolved the last is dissolved, and all bound said: I am hereby a nazirite, and another heard and said: My mouth is like his mouth and my hair is like his hair, he is a nazirite.
llm_translation: One who said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," and his friend heard and said, "And I too," "And I too" - all of them are Nazirites. If the first one is permitted - they are all permitted. If the last one is permitted - the last one is permitted and all of them are forbidden. If he said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," and his friend heard and said, "My mouth like his mouth, and my hair like his hair" - behold, this one is a Nazirite.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״, וְשָׁמְעָה אִשְׁתּוֹ וְאָמְרָה ״וַאֲנִי״ — מֵיפֵר אֶת שֶׁלָּהּ, וְשֶׁלּוֹ קַיָּים. ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה״, וְשָׁמַע בַּעֲלָהּ וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר וְאַתְּ״, וְאָמְרָה ״אָמֵן״ — מֵיפֵר אֶת שֶׁלָּהּ, וְשֶׁלּוֹ קַיָּים. ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה וְאַתָּה״, וְאָמַר ״אָמֵן״ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר.
human_translation: I am hereby a nazirite, and his wife heard and said: And I, nullify her But his intact, I am hereby a nazirite, and her husband heard and said: And I, he cannot nullify I am hereby a nazirite, and you, and she said: Amen, he can nullify her and his intact. I am hereby a nazirite, and you, and he said: Amen, he cannot nullify
llm_translation: "I am a Nazirite," and his wife heard and said, "And I" - he annuls hers, and his remains valid. "I am a Nazirite," and her husband heard and said, "And I" - he cannot annul it. "I am a Nazirite and you," and she said "Amen" - he annuls hers, and his remains valid. "I am a Nazirite and you," and he said "Amen" - he cannot annul it.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ יָתֵיב רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ קַמֵּיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה נְשִׂיאָה וְיָתֵיב וְקָאָמַר: וְהוּא שֶׁהִתְפִּיסוּ כּוּלָּן בְּתוֹךְ כְּדֵי דִיבּוּר. וְכַמָּה תּוֹךְ כְּדֵי דִיבּוּר — כְּדֵי שְׁאֵלַת שָׁלוֹם, וְכַמָּה כְּדֵי שְׁאֵלַת שָׁלוֹם — כְּדֵי שֶׁאוֹמֵר שָׁלוֹם תַּלְמִיד לָרַב.
human_translation: Reish Lakish sat before Rabbi Yehuda Nesia, and he sat and said And this when they all associating within the time required for speaking And how much Within the time required for speaking for greeting And how much is for greeting for a student to say: Peace to rabbi.
llm_translation: Gemara: Reish Lakish sat before Rabbi Yehuda the Nasi and he sat and said: "And he Moses caught them all in the midst of speech. And how much is 'in the midst of speech'? - The amount of time it takes to say 'shalom'. And how much is 'the amount of time it takes to say shalom'? - The amount of time it takes for a student to greet his teacher."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: תּוּב לָא שָׁבְקַתְּ רַוְוחָא לְתַלְמִידָא!
human_translation: said to Once again you have provided no advantage to a student
llm_translation: He said to him: "You have not left any room for the student!"

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: מִי שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״, וְשָׁמַע חֲבֵירוֹ וְשָׁהָה כְּדֵי דִבּוּר, וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ — הוּא אָסוּר, וַחֲבֵירוֹ מוּתָּר. וְכַמָּה כְּדֵי דִבּוּר — כְּדֵי שְׁאֵילַת שָׁלוֹם תַּלְמִיד לָרַב.
human_translation: This is also taught one who said: I am hereby a nazirite, and another heard and waited the time required for speaking and said: And I, is bound and the other is permitted, And how much the time required for speaking? for a student inquire the welfare rabbi.
llm_translation: It was taught in a baraita: If one said, "Behold, I am a nazirite," and his fellow heard and delayed speaking for the time it takes to speak, and then said, "And I," he is forbidden, while his fellow is permitted. And how long is the time it takes to speak? The time it takes for a disciple to greet his teacher.

hebrew_text: לֵימָא מְסַיְּיעָא לֵיהּ: מִי שֶׁאָמַר ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״, וְשָׁמַע חֲבֵירוֹ וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ ״וַאֲנִי״, וְתוּ לָא! תַּנָּא כִּי רוֹכְלָא לִיחְשֹׁיב וְלֵיזִיל?!
human_translation: Shall we say that supports one who said: I am hereby a nazirite, and another heard him and said: And I, And I, and no more, should the tanna have continued reckoning like a peddler,
llm_translation: Let us say it assists him: One who said, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," and his fellow heard and said, "And I am," "And I am," and yet it is not so! It was taught: For a peddler to consider and leave?!

hebrew_text: וְלִיתְנֵי חַד וְלַשְׁמְעִינַן הָנֵי! הָכָא נָמֵי, וּמִשּׁוּם דְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא הוּתַּר הָרִאשׁוֹן הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן, הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר וְכוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין, מִכְּלָל דְּאִיכָּא אֶמְצָעִי, וּמִשּׁוּם הָכִי קָתָנֵי ״וַאֲנִי״ ״וַאֲנִי״.
human_translation: But let him teach one and teach us these Indeed, but because teaches in the latter clause: the first was dissolved they are all dissolved, the last was dissolved the last is dissolved and all bound by inference that there is a middle And due to that teaches: And I, and I,
llm_translation: And let one teach and let us hear those! Here it is stated, and because the latter clause was taught, the first one was permitted, they were all permitted, the latter one is permitted and all of them are forbidden, from the inference that there is an intermediary, and therefore it was taught "and I" "and I."

hebrew_text: אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: חַד בְּחַבְרֵיהּ מִיתְּפִיס, אוֹ דִּלְמָא בְּקַמָּא מִיתַּפְסִי? לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ — לְאִתְּפוֹסֵי וּמֵיזַל. אִי אָמְרַתְּ חַד בְּחַבְרֵיהּ מִתְּפִיס — מִתַּפְסִין וְאָזְלִין לְעוֹלָם. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ בְּקַמָּא מִתַּפְסִי — טְפֵי מִכְּדֵי דִבּוּר לָא מִתַּפְסִין. מַאי?
human_translation: a dilemma was raised before one associating with the other, or perhaps they associate with the first What difference is there? can continue to associate If you say one associates with the other continue to associate forever, And if you say they associate with the first they may not associate more than required for speaking What
llm_translation: He asked them: Does one catch among his companions, or perhaps in the front one catches? What is the practical difference? — To catch and go out. If you say catching among his companions — they catch and go out forever. And if you say in the front one catches — small talk does not catch. What is the resolution?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״, וְשָׁמַע חֲבֵירוֹ וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ ״וַאֲנִי״, וְתוּ לָא מִידֵּי, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ בְּקַמָּא הוּא דְּמִתַּפְסִי, דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ חַד בְּחַבְרֵיהּ מִיתְּפִיס — לִיתְנֵי טוּבָא ״וַאֲנִי״! תַּנָּא כִּי רוֹכְלָא לִיחְשֹׁיב וְלֵיזִיל?!
human_translation: Come hear I am hereby a nazirite, and another heard and said: And I, And I, and no more. Learn from this that they associated with the first as, if it should enter your mind one associates with the other let teach: And I, many should the tanna have continued reckoning like a peddler?
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Come and hear: 'Behold, I am a Nazirite,' and his friend heard and said, 'And I am a Nazirite,' 'And I am a Nazirite.' And it is not immediately clear, hear from it in the beginning that he is mistaken, for if your mind is not in agreement with his friend, he is mistaken — let him bring a sacrifice! It was taught: When a peddler comes to calculate and leave?!"

hebrew_text: וְלִיתְנֵי חַד וְלַשְׁמְעִינַן כּוּלְּהוֹן! אַיְּידֵי דְּקָתָנֵי הוּתַּר הָרִאשׁוֹן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן, הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר וְכוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין, מִכְּלָל דְּאִיכָּא אֶמְצָעִי, מִשּׁוּם הָכִי קָתָנֵי ״וַאֲנִי״ ״וַאֲנִי״.
human_translation: But let him teach once, and we learn they all Since teaches the first was dissolved they are all dissolved, the last was dissolved the last is dissolved and all bound by inference that there is a middle due to that teaches: And I, and I,
llm_translation: And let one teach and let us hear all of them! Since the first one was taught — all of them were permitted, if the last one was permitted — the last one is permitted and all of them are forbidden, from the principle that there is an intermediary, therefore it was taught "and I" "and I."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הוּתַּר הָרִאשׁוֹן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן. רִאשׁוֹן הוּא דִּשְׁרוּ, הָא אֶמְצָעִי לָא, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ בְּקַמָּא מִתַּפְסִין.
human_translation: Come hear the first was dissolved, they are all dissolved. it is first dissolved However, middle no, Learn from this associated with the first
llm_translation: "Come and hear: If the first one is permitted, they are all permitted. The first one is the one who permitted, but the middle one did not. Listen, from her mouth they may be taken in the beginning."

hebrew_text: אֵימָא לָךְ: לְעוֹלָם חַד בְּחַבְרֵיהּ מִתְּפִיס. וְאַיְּידֵי דְּבָעֵי מִיתְנֵא ״הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן״, דְּאִי תְּנָא אֶמְצָעִי, אִיכָּא רִאשׁוֹן דְּלָא מִשְׁתְּרֵי, מִשּׁוּם הָכִי קָתָנֵי רִאשׁוֹן.
human_translation: I say to you actually, each associates with the other But since wanted to teach: They are all dissolved, had he taught the middle there is first that is not dissolved, Due to that teaches first one
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Eima lach: Le'olam chad b'chavrei mitfis. V'ayidei d'baei mitne 'hutru kulan', d'ei tana emtsa'i, ika rishon d'lo mishtrei, mishum hachi katanei rishon." English translation: "Say to her: Always one with his colleagues grasps. And since he wants to teach 'they were all permitted', for if he teaches the middle, there is a first that is not permitted, therefore the first teaches."

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר וְכוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין. דְּלָא אִיכָּא אַחֲרִינָא בָּתְרֵיהּ, אֲבָל אֶמְצָעִי, דְּאִיכָּא אַחֲרִינָא בָּתְרֵיהּ — מִשְׁתְּרֵי. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ חַד בְּחַבְרֵיהּ מִתְּפִיס.
human_translation: Come hear: the last was dissolved, the last is dissolved and they are all bound as he is not followed by anyone. However, middle one, who is followed by someone else, is dissolved. learn from this one associates with the other
llm_translation: Come and hear: If the last one is permitted, the last one is permitted, and all the others are forbidden. Because there is no other one after it. But if there is another one after it, it is permitted. Learn from this one thing: one of his colleagues caught him.

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם אֵימָא לָךְ: בְּקַמָּא מִיתַּפְסִין, וּמַאי ״אַחֲרוֹן״ דְּקָתָנֵי — אֶמְצָעִי, וְאַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא רִאשׁוֹן, תְּנָא אַחֲרוֹן.
human_translation: Actually, I say to you that they associate with the first and what is last one, that teaches? the middle And Since taught: First, he taught: Last,
llm_translation: Always say to you: In the beginning they grasp, and what is the "last" that it teaches - the middle, and since it teaches the first, it teaches the last.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּתַנְיָא בְּהֶדְיָא: הוּתַּר הָרִאשׁוֹן — הוּתְּרוּ כּוּלָּן, הוּתַּר הָאַחֲרוֹן — הָאַחֲרוֹן מוּתָּר וְכוּלָּן אֲסוּרִין, הוּתַּר אֶמְצָעִי — הֵימֶנּוּ וּלְמַטָּה מוּתָּר, הֵימֶנּוּ וּלְמַעְלָה — אָסוּר, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ חַד בְּחַבְרֵיהּ מִתְּפִיס, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: Come hear, as it is taught explicitly: the first is dissolved, they are all dissolved; the last is dissolved, the last is dissolved and they are all bound If middle is dissolved, from him and after are dissolved; from him and before bound learn from this each associates the other Learn from this
llm_translation: Come and hear, for it was taught in a Baraita: If the first one is permitted, they are all permitted; if the last one is permitted, the last one is permitted and they are all prohibited; if the middle one is permitted, it and those below it are permitted, but it and those above it are prohibited. Know from this one case with its companions, know from this one case.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר״, וְשָׁמַע חֲבֵירוֹ וְאָמַר ״פִּי כְּפִיו וּשְׂעָרִי כִּשְׂעָרוֹ וְכוּ׳״. מִשּׁוּם דְּאָמַר ״פִּי כְּפִיו וּשְׂעָרִי כִּשְׂעָרוֹ״ הֲרֵי נָזִיר?
human_translation: I am hereby a nazirite, and another heard and said, my mouth is like his mouth, and my hair is like his hair, because he said: My mouth is like his mouth and my hair is like his hair, he a nazirite?
llm_translation: "Behold, I am a Nazirite," and his friend heard and said, "My mouth like his mouth, and my hair like his hair, etc." Since he said, "My mouth like his mouth, and my hair like his hair," behold, is he a Nazirite?

hebrew_text: וּרְמִינְהוּ: ״יָדִי נְזִירָה״ וְ״רַגְלִי נְזִירָה״ — לֹא אָמַר כְּלוּם, ״רֹאשִׁי נְזִירָה״, ״כְּבֵדִי נְזִירָה״ — הֲרֵי זֶה נָזִיר. זֶה הַכְּלָל: דָּבָר שֶׁהַנְּשָׁמָה תְּלוּיָה בּוֹ — הֲרֵי זֶה נָזִיר.
human_translation: And raises a contradiction My hand is a nazirite, and My foot is a nazirite, he has not said anything My head is a nazirite, My liver is a nazirite, he is a nazirite. This is the principle: an entity upon which life depends, he is a nazirite.
llm_translation: And they asked: "My hand is a Nazirite" and "my foot is a Nazirite" — he did not say anything, "my head is a Nazirite," "my liver is a Nazirite" — this one is a Nazirite. This is the principle: something that the soul depends on — this one is a Nazirite.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה, דְּאָמַר הָכִי: יֵעָשֶׂה פִּי כְּפִיו מִיַּיִן, וּשְׂעָרִי כִּשְׂעָרוֹ מִלָּגוֹז.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said that he said like this; Let my mouth be like his mouth from wine, and my hair like his hair from cutting
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said, as he said thus: "Let his mouth be like wine, and his hair like wool of Laggot."

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה״, וְשָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וַאֲמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר, אוֹ דִּלְמָא מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז? לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ —
human_translation: I am hereby a nazirite, and her husband heard and said: And I, he cannot nullify A dilemma was raised before a husband uproot or perhaps severs What difference is there
llm_translation: "Behold, I am a Nazirite," and her husband heard and said, "And I..." he cannot annul. The question was asked: Did the husband uproot her from the outset, or perhaps he annulled her from the moment of the vow? What is the practical difference?

hebrew_text: לְאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְשָׁמְעָה חֲבֶרְתָּהּ וְאָמְרָה ״וַאֲנִי״, וְשָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ שֶׁל רִאשׁוֹנָה וְהֵפֵר לָהּ. אִי אָמְרַתְּ מִיעְקָר עָקַר — הַהִיא נָמֵי אִישְׁתְּרַאי. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז — אִיהִי אִישְׁתְּרַאי, חֲבֶרְתַּהּ אֲסִירָא. מַאי?
human_translation: with regard to a woman who vowed to be a nazirite, and another heard and said: And I, and the husband of the first heard and nullified her If you say uproots that also be dissolved, And if you say severs is dissolved, other bound What,
llm_translation: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite, and her friend heard and said, "And I." And her former husband heard and annulled it for her. If you say from the outset, the original vow is annulled - that one is certainly a wife. And if you say from the middle, the middle vow is annulled - she is a wife, her friend is a prisoner. What is the ruling?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה״ וְשָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ בַּעַל מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז — לֵיפַר לְאִישְׁתּוֹ וְהוּא לִיתְּסַר. אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ, בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר.
human_translation: Come hear I am hereby a nazirite, and her husband heard and said: And I, he cannot nullify And if it should enter your mind husband severs let him nullify for his wife and he will bound Rather, not conclude from the husband uproots
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "Come and hear: 'Behold, I am a Nazirite,' and her husband heard and said, 'And I' — he cannot annul. And if it enters your mind that a husband is like a gazing idol — he may annul for his wife, but he is not exempt. Rather, if he did not hear from her, the husband uproots the root." English translation:

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז. וּבְדִין הוּא דְּלֵיפַר לַהּ. וְהַיְינוּ טַעְמָא דְּלָא מָצֵי מֵיפַר, כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר לַהּ ״וַאֲנִי״, כְּמַאן דְּאָמַר ״קַיָּים לִיכִי״ דָּמֵי. אִי מִתְּשִׁיל אַהֲקָמָתוֹ, — מָצֵי מֵיפַר, וְאִי לָא — לָא מָצֵי מֵיפַר.
human_translation: No; actually, severs And by right that he can nullify for her; and this is the reason why he cannot nullify Since he said to her: And I, considered like one who said: It is upheld for you, if he requested his upholding he can nullify and if not, he cannot nullify
llm_translation: Not, always from the winepress grapes. And in judgment it is to pay for it. And that is the reason that it cannot be paid for, since he said to her "and I," it is like one who says "I am able to you." If he establishes his claim, he can pay for it, and if not, he cannot pay for it.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְהִפְרִישָׁה אֶת בְּהֶמְתָּהּ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ, אִם שֶׁלּוֹ הָיְתָה הַבְּהֵמָה — תֵּצֵא וְתִרְעֶה בָּעֵדֶר. וְאִם שֶׁלָּהּ הָיְתָה הַבְּהֵמָה — הַחַטָּאת תָּמוּת.
human_translation: Come hear: a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and separated her animal and afterward her husband nullified her if the animal was his, it shall go out and graze among flock And if the animal was hers, a sin-offering, it must die,
llm_translation: Come and hear: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite, and separated her animal, and afterwards her husband annulled it for her, if the animal belonged to him - it shall go out and graze with the flock. But if the animal belonged to her - the sin offering shall die.

hebrew_text: וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר — תִּיפּוֹק לְחוּלִּין! אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ, בַּעַל מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז!
human_translation: And if it should enter your mind the husband uproots be released as a non-sacred Rather, not conclude from the husband severs
llm_translation: "If, however, your initial thought was that Baal Miakar uprooted - let it emerge in mundane matters! Rather, it is not the case, Baal Migaz gazes!"

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם אֵימָא לָךְ בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר, וְהַיְינוּ טַעְמָא: כֵּיוָן דְּלֹא צְרִיכָה כַּפָּרָה, הֲוָת כְּחַטָּאת שֶׁמֵּתוּ בְּעָלֶיהָ, וּגְמִירִי דְּחַטָּאת שֶׁמֵּתוּ בְּעָלֶיהָ — תָּמוּת.
human_translation: Actually, I say to you husband uproots and this is the reason Since she requires no atonement, is as a sin-offering whose owners have died, and is learned that a sin-offering whose owners have died must die.
llm_translation: Forever say to you Baal Miakar uprooted, and that is the reason: since not needed atonement, was like a sin offering that died in its owners, and we learn that a sin offering that died in its owners - shall die.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְהָיְתָה שׁוֹתָה יַיִן וּמִטַּמְּאָה לְמֵתִים — הֲרֵי זוֹ סוֹפֶגֶת אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. הֵיכִי דָמֵי? אִילֵּימָא דְּלָא הֵיפַר לַהּ בַּעַל — צְרִיכָא לְמֵימַר?
human_translation: Come hear a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and was drinking wine and rendering herself ritually impure with the dead, she incurs the forty What are the circumstances If we say that husband did not nullify her need this be said
llm_translation: Come and hear: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite and drank wine and became impure through contact with the dead — she is considered to be violating the forty days. What is the reason? If we say that her husband did not annul her vow — it is necessary to say?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא פְּשִׁיטָא דְּהֵיפַר לַהּ בַּעַל. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר — אַמַּאי סוֹפֶגֶת אַרְבָּעִים? אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ, בַּעַל מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז?
human_translation: Rather, is obvious husband nullified her And if it should enter your mind husband uproots why she incur the forty Rather, not conclude from husband severs
llm_translation: Rather, it is obvious that the husband has annulled it for her. And if it enters your mind that the husband uprooted it from the outset — why does she absorb forty? Rather, it is not a valid assumption, the husband has merely stirred up the coals?

hebrew_text: לְעוֹלָם אֵימָא לָךְ בַּעַל מִיעְקָר עָקַר, וּמִשּׁוּם דְּקָתָנֵי סֵיפָא: הֵיפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ וְהִיא לֹא יָדְעָה, וְהָיְתָה שׁוֹתָה יַיִן וּמִטַּמְּאָה לְמֵתִים — אֵינָהּ סוֹפֶגֶת אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים,
human_translation: Actually, I say to you husband uproots and due to that teaches the latter clause husband nullified her and she did not know, and she was drinking wine and rendering herself ritually impure with the dead, she does not incur the forty
llm_translation: Forever say to you Baal Mi'akar uprooted, and because taught the end: he exaggerated to her her husband and she did not know, and she was drinking wine and defiling to the dead — she does not absorb the forty.

hebrew_text: תְּנָא נָמֵי רֵישָׁא סוֹפֶגֶת.
human_translation: also taught: She incurs, the first clause,
llm_translation: It was taught: Nami Reishah Sofeges.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר וְנִטְמֵאת, וְאַחַר כָּךְ הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעֲלָהּ — מְבִיאָה חַטַּאת הָעוֹף, וְאֵינָהּ מְבִיאָה עוֹלַת הָעוֹף. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בַּעַל מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז — תַּיְיתֵי נָמֵי עוֹלַת הָעוֹף!
human_translation: Come hear a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and she became ritually impure, and afterward her husband nullified her she brings the bird sin-offering, and she does not bring the bird burnt-offering. And if it should enter your mind husband severs let her also bring the bird burnt-offering,
llm_translation: Come and hear: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite and became impure, and afterwards her husband annulled it for her - she brings a sin offering of a bird, but she does not bring a burnt offering of a bird. And if you think that the husband is like a priest - let him bring a burnt offering of a bird!

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא מַאי, מִיעְקָר עָקַר? חַטַּאת הָעוֹף נָמֵי לָא תַּיְיתֵי! הָכִי נָמֵי, וְהָא מַנִּי — רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר הִיא.
human_translation: Rather, what then? uproots she should also not bring the bird sin-offering. So too, but whose is this It is Rabbi Elazar HaKappar.
llm_translation: And rather what, what is the primary root? The sin offering of the bird, indeed not brought! Thus it is indeed so, and this is the teaching — Rabbi Elazar HaKappar it is.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַקַּפָּר (בַּר רַבִּי) אוֹמֵר: מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״מֵאֲשֶׁר חָטָא עַל הַנָּפֶשׁ״? וְכִי בְּאֵיזוֹ נֶפֶשׁ חָטָא זֶה? אֶלָּא מִפְּנֵי שֶׁצִּיעֵר עַצְמוֹ מִן הַיַּיִן נִקְרָא חוֹטֵא. וַהֲלֹא דְּבָרִים קַל וָחוֹמֶר: וּמָה זֶה שֶׁלֹּא צִיעֵר עַצְמוֹ אֶלָּא מִן הַיַּיִן נִקְרָא חוֹטֵא, הַמְצַעֵר עַצְמוֹ מִכׇּל דָּבָר — עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה.
human_translation: As it is taught Rabbi Elazar HaKappar the esteemed says: What the verse states: for that he sinned by reason of the soul” And with which soul did this sin? Rather, because he deprived himself of wine he is called a sinner. And are not matters a fortiori : And if this one, who deprived himself only of wine, is called a sinner, one who deprives himself of everything all the more so
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Elazar HaKappar (son of Rabbi) says: What is the Talmud teaching by saying "from that which he sinned against the soul"? And in what soul did he sin? Rather, because he afflicted himself from wine, he is called a sinner. And are these not logical arguments: And if one who did not afflict himself except from wine is called a sinner, one who afflicts himself from everything — all the more so.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע, דְּתַנְיָא בְּהֶדְיָא: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְשָׁמְעָה חֲבֶירְתָּהּ וְאָמְרָה ״וַאֲנִי״, וּבָא בַּעְלָהּ שֶׁל רִאשׁוֹנָה וְהֵפֵר לָהּ — הִיא מוּתֶּרֶת וַחֲבֶירְתָּהּ אֲסוּרָה. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: בַּעַל מִיגָּז גָּיֵיז.
human_translation: Come hear as it is taught explicitly: a woman who vowed to be a nazirite, and another heard and said: And I, and husband of the first one came and nullified her she is permitted and other is prohibited. learn from this husband severs
llm_translation: Listen and hear, as it was taught in a baraita: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite, and her friend heard and said, "And I," and her former husband came and annulled it for her - she is permitted, and her friend is forbidden. Learn from it: A husband who is a barber shaves.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אִם אָמְרָה לָהּ ״הֲרֵינִי כְּמוֹתֵיךְ״ — שְׁתֵּיהֶן מוּתָּרוֹת.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon says if said to her, I am hereby like you, they are both permitted.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon says: If she said to her, "Behold, I am like you," both are permitted.

hebrew_text: מָר זוּטְרָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב מָרִי אָמַר: הַאי, הַיְינוּ דְּרָמִי בַּר חָמָא. דְּבָעֵי רָמֵי בַּר חָמָא: ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כִּבְשַׂר זֶבַח שְׁלָמִים״, מַהוּ?
human_translation: Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said: This is of Rami bar Ḥama As Rami bar Ḥama raises a dilemma: This to me like the flesh of a peace-offering, what is
llm_translation: Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said: This, is the one who throws hot water. He asked: What is the law regarding "I have upon me the flesh of the peace offering"?

hebrew_text: כִּי מַתְפֵּיס אִינִישׁ, בְּעִיקָּרָא מַתְפֵּיס, אוֹ דִּלְמָא בִּצְנָנָא מַתְפֵּיס?
human_translation: When a person associates associate by its fundamental state? Or perhaps associates by its permitted state bitzenana
llm_translation: When one grasps, does he primarily grasp, or perhaps he grasps with a fork?

hebrew_text: מִי דָּמֵי? הָתָם כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר ״הֲרֵי עָלַי כִּבְשַׂר זֶבַח שְׁלָמִים״, אַף עַל גַּב דִּלְאַחַר שֶׁנִּזְרַק דָּמוֹ מָצֵי אָכֵיל לֵיהּ בַּחוּץ, מִיקְדָּשׁ קָדֵישׁ. אֲבָל הָכָא, אִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בִּצְנָנָא קָא מַתְפֵּיס — הָא הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ! אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי, הַיְינוּ דְּרָמֵי בַּר חָמָא וַדַּאי.
human_translation: Are comparable? There, since he said: is to me like the flesh of a peace-offering, even though after its blood has been sprinkled it can be eaten outside sacred However, here, if it should enter your mind associates permitted state, her husband has nullified her Some say is certainly of Rami bar Ḥama.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Who is similar? There, since he said, "Behold, upon me is the fat of the peace offering," even though after its blood was sprinkled, its fat is found, he may eat it outside, it is sanctified holy. But here, if it enters your mind that he is grasping it in the cold - behold, he has nullified it for her husband! Some say, this is what Rami bar Hama meant for sure.

hebrew_text: אָמְרָה לָהּ, ״הֲרֵינִי נְזִירָה בְּעִיקְבֵיךְ״, מַהוּ? ״הֲרֵינִי בְּעִיקְבֵיךְ״ — בְּכוֹלָּא מִילְּתָא, וְשַׁרְיָא. אוֹ דִלְמָא כְּמִיקַּמֵּי דְּלֵיפַר לַהּ בַּעְלַהּ, וַאֲסִירָא?
human_translation: said to I am hereby a nazirite in your footsteps, what is I am hereby in your footsteps, in all matters, and dissolved, or perhaps to before her husband nullified her and bound
llm_translation: She said to her, "Behold, I am a Nazirite because of your heels," what is it? "Behold, I am because of your heels" - in all matters, and it is permitted. Or perhaps it is like the case where her husband annulled it for her, and it is prohibited?

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע: הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְשָׁמַע בַּעְלָהּ וְאָמַר ״וַאֲנִי״ — אֵינוֹ יָכוֹל לְהָפֵר. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ כִּי אֲמַר לַהּ ״הֲרֵינִי בְּעִיקְבֵיךְ״ — בְּעִיקָּרָא קָא מַתְפֵּיס, לֵיפַר לַהּ לְדִידַהּ וְלוֹקֵים דִּידֵיהּ.
human_translation: Come hear a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and her husband heard and said: And I, he cannot nullify And if it should enter your mind when he says to her: I am hereby in your footsteps, he associates the fundamental state let him nullify her and uphold his.
llm_translation: Come and hear: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite, and her husband heard and said, "And I" — he cannot annul. And if your mind suggests that when he said to her, "Behold, I am in your way" — he is essentially annulling, he is annulling for himself and leaving her vows intact.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא לָאו, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ בְּכוֹלָּא דְּמִילְּתָא מַתְפֵּיס, וְהִלְכָּךְ הוּא דְּלָא מָצֵי מֵיפַר. הָא אִשָּׁה דְּאָמְרָה ״הֲרֵינִי בְּעִיקְבֵיךְ״, הִיא נָמֵי מוּתֶּרֶת!
human_translation: Rather, not conclude from associates all matters and therefore he cannot nullify but a woman said: I am hereby in your footsteps, she is also permitted
llm_translation: Rather, no, learn from it that in all matters of circumcision it is effective, and therefore he cannot annul it. For a woman who says, "I am betrothed to you," she is indeed permitted!

hebrew_text: לָא, לְעוֹלָם בְּעִיקָּרָא מַתְפֵּיס, וְהָכָא כֵּיוָן דְּאָמַר לַהּ ״וַאֲנִי״ — כְּאוֹמֵר ״קַיָּים לִיכִי״ דָּמֵי. וְאִי מִתְּשִׁיל אַהֲקָמָתוֹ — מָצֵי מֵיפַר, וְאִי לָא — לָא.
human_translation: No; actually, associates the fundamental state and here, Since he says to her: And I, he is considered to have said: upheld for you, And if requests of his upholding he can nullify and if not cannot
llm_translation: Not, always primarily grasps, and here since said to her "and I" - like saying "I am able" similar. And if he does not establish his position - he may retract, and if not - not.

hebrew_text: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר וְאַתְּ״, וְאָמְרָה ״אָמֵן״ — מֵיפֵר אֶת שֶׁלָּהּ, וְשֶׁלּוֹ קַיָּים. וּרְמִינְהוּ: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר וְאַתְּ״, וְאָמְרָה ״אָמֵן״ — שְׁנֵיהֶם אֲסוּרִין, וְאִם לָאו — שְׁנֵיהֶם מוּתָּרִין, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁתָּלָה נִדְרוֹ בְּנִדְרָהּ.
human_translation: I am hereby a nazirite and you, and said: Amen, he can nullify her and his intact. And raises a contradiction I am hereby a nazirite and you, and she said: Amen, they are both bound and if not they are both permitted, because he made his vow dependent on her vow.
llm_translation: "I hereby vow to be a Nazirite, and you," and she said "Amen" - she annuls her vow, and his vow remains valid. And they raised a dilemma: "I hereby vow to be a Nazirite, and you," and she said "Amen" - both of them are forbidden, and if not - both of them are permitted, because he suspended his vow with her vow."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה, תְּנִי: ״מֵיפֵר אֶת שֶׁלָּהּ וְשֶׁלּוֹ קַיָּים״. אַבָּיֵי אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא כִּדְקָתָנֵי, בָּרַיְיתָא כְּגוֹן דְּקָאָמַר לַהּ: ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר וְאַתְּ״, דְּקָא תָּלֵי נִדְרוֹ בְּנִדְרָהּ.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda said: Teach He can nullify hers and his intact, Abaye said: You even say as it teaches, baraita where he said to her I am hereby a nazirite and you, as he makes his vow dependent on her vow.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said, "Teach: 'He nullifies hers and his remains valid.'" Abaye said: Even if you say as the Tanna taught, in a baraita, for example, where he says to her, "Behold, I am a Nazirite, and you," he is imposing his vow upon her vow.

hebrew_text: וּמַתְנִיתִין כְּגוֹן דַּאֲמַר לַהּ ״הֲרֵינִי נָזִיר, וְאַתְּ מַאי?״ מִשּׁוּם הָכִי, מֵיפֵר אֶת שֶׁלָּהּ וְשֶׁלּוֹ קַיָּים.
human_translation: And the mishna where he said to her I am hereby a nazirite, and what you? Due to that he may nullify hers and his is intact.
llm_translation: Mishnah: For example, if he said to her, "Behold, I am a Nazirite," and she responded, "And what about you?" Therefore, he annuls her vow and his vow remains valid.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְהָיְתָה שׁוֹתֶה בְּיַיִן וּמִטַּמְּאָה לְמֵתִים — הֲרֵי זֶה סוֹפֶגֶת אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. הֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ, וְהִיא לֹא יָדְעָה שֶׁהֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ, וְהָיְתָה שׁוֹתָה בְּיַיִן וּמִטַּמְּאָה לְמֵתִים — אֵינָהּ סוֹפֶגֶת אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אִם אֵינָהּ סוֹפֶגֶת אֶת הָאַרְבָּעִים — תִּסְפּוֹג מַכַּת מַרְדּוּת.
human_translation: a woman who vowed to be a nazirite, and she was drinking wine and rendering herself ritually impure by the dead, she incurs the forty her husband nullified her and she did not know that her husband had nullified her and she was drinking wine and rendering herself impure by the dead, she does not incur the forty Rabbi Yehuda says: if she does not incur the forty she should incur lashes for rebelliousness [ makat mardut ],
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite, and was drinking wine and becoming impure through contact with the dead — she is absorbing the forty lashes. If her husband annulled her vow, and she was unaware that her husband annulled her vow, and she was drinking wine and becoming impure through contact with the dead — she is not absorbing the forty lashes. Rabbi Yehuda says: If she is not absorbing the forty lashes, she should absorb the punishment of rebelliousness.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״אִישָׁהּ הֲפֵרָם וַה׳ יִסְלַח לָהּ״ — בְּאִשָּׁה שֶׁהֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ וְהִיא לֹא יָדְעָה הַכָּתוּב מְדַבֵּר, שֶׁהִיא צְרִיכָה כַּפָּרָה וּסְלִיחָה.
human_translation: The Sages taught “Her husband has nullified them, and the Lord will forgive her” the verse is speaking of a woman whose husband nullified her and she did not know that she requires atonement and forgiveness.
llm_translation: The Sages taught: "Her husband annulled them, and God will forgive her" — regarding a woman whose husband annulled her vows without her knowledge, as the verse speaks, she requires atonement and forgiveness.

hebrew_text: וּכְשֶׁהָיָה מַגִּיעַ רַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אֵצֶל פָּסוּק זֶה, הָיָה בּוֹכֶה: וּמָה מִי שֶׁנִּתְכַּוֵּון לַעֲלוֹת בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר, וְעָלָה בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר טָלֶה — טָעוּן כַּפָּרָה וּסְלִיחָה. הַמִּתְכַּוֵּון לַעֲלוֹת בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר וְעָלָה בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר — עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה.
human_translation: And when Rabbi Akiva would reach this verse he would cry, And if one who intended to pick up pork in his hand and he picked up the meat of a lamb in his hand requires atonement and forgiveness, one who intends to pick up pork in his hand and picked up pork in his hand, all the more so
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And when Rabbi Akiva would reach this verse, he would cry: And what if one intends to bring in his hand pork, but in his hand it is lamb — he needs atonement and forgiveness. But if one intends to bring in his hand pork, and in his hand it is pork — how much more so. English translation:

hebrew_text: כַּיּוֹצֵא בַּדָּבָר אַתָּה אוֹמֵר: ״וְלֹא יָדַע וְאָשֵׁם וְנָשָׂא עֲוֹנוֹ״,
human_translation: On a similar note, you say “Though he does not know it yet he is guilty, and shall bear his iniquity”
llm_translation: As an example in the matter, you say: "And he did not know, and he is guilty, and he shall bear his iniquity."

hebrew_text: וּמָה מִי שֶׁנִּתְכַּוֵּון לַעֲלוֹת בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר טָלֶה, וְעָלָה בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר, כְּגוֹן חֲתִיכָה סָפֵק שֶׁל שׁוּמָּן סָפֵק שֶׁל חֵלֶב — אָמַר קְרָא ״וְנָשָׂא עֲוֹנוֹ״. מִי שֶׁנִּתְכַּוֵּון לַעֲלוֹת בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר, וְעָלָה בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר — עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה.
human_translation: And if one who intended to pick up the meat of a lamb in his hand and he picked up pork in his hand for example, a piece uncertain fat uncertain fat, the verse states: “And shall bear his iniquity,” one who intends to pick up pork in his hand and picked up pork in his hand, all the more so
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And what about one who intends to bring up in his hand the flesh of a lamb, and it came up in his hand the flesh of a pig, such as a piece that is doubtful whether it is fat of the tail or whether it is fat — the verse says, "And he shall bear his iniquity." But one who intends to bring up in his hand the flesh of a pig, and it came up in his hand the flesh of a pig — this is all the more so. English translation: And what about one who intends to bring up in his hand the flesh of a lamb, and it came up in his hand the flesh of a pig, such as a piece that is doubtful whether it is fat of the tail or whether it is fat — the verse says, "And he shall bear his iniquity." But one who intends to bring up in his hand the flesh of a pig, and it came up in his hand the flesh of a pig — this is all the more so.

hebrew_text: אִיסִי בֶּן יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: ״וְלֹא יָדַע וְאָשֵׁם וְנָשָׂא עֲוֹנוֹ״, וּמָה מִי שֶׁנִּתְכַּוֵּון לַעֲלוֹת בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר טָלֶה, וְעָלָה בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר, כְּגוֹן שְׁתֵּי חֲתִיכוֹת אַחַת שֶׁל חֵלֶב וְאַחַת שֶׁל שׁוּמָּן — ״וְנָשָׂא עֲוֹנוֹ״. הַמִּתְכַּוֵּון לַעֲלוֹת בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר, וְעָלָה בְּיָדוֹ בְּשַׂר חֲזִיר — עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה.
human_translation: Isi ben Yehuda says “Though he does not know it yet he is guilty, and shall bear his iniquity” And if one who intended to pick up the meat of a lamb in his hand and he picked up pork in his hand, e.g., two pieces one of fat and one of fat, “And shall bear his iniquity,” one who intends to pick up pork in his hand and picked up pork in his hand, all the more so
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Isi ben Yehuda says: "And he did not know, and he is guilty, and he shall bear his iniquity." And what is the case of one who intended to pick up in his hand the flesh of a lamb, and it turned out to be the flesh of a pig, such as two pieces, one of fat and one of lard - "and he shall bear his iniquity." One who intended to pick up in his hand the flesh of a pig, and it turned out to be the flesh of a pig - how much more so is he guilty.

hebrew_text: עַל דָּבָר זֶה יִדְווּ הַדּוֹוִים.
human_translation: And with regard to this matter, those who suffer should suffer,
llm_translation: Regarding this matter, the experts will deliberate.

hebrew_text: וְכׇל הָנֵי לְמָה לִי? צְרִיכִין, דְּאִי תְּנָא גַּבֵּי אִשָּׁה, הָתָם הוּא דְּבָעֲיָא כַּפָּרָה וּסְלִיחָה — מִשּׁוּם דְּמֵעִיקָּרָא לְאִיסּוּרָא אִיכַּוֵון. אֲבָל חֲתִיכָה סָפֵק שֶׁל חֵלֶב סָפֵק שֶׁל שׁוּמָּן, דִּלְהֶיתֵּרָא אִיכַּוֵּין — לָא בָּעֵי כַּפָּרָה וּסְלִיחָה.
human_translation: And why do I all these are necessary, as had we taught with regard to a woman, it is there that she requires atonement and forgiveness because at the outset her intention was to sin. However, a piece uncertain fat uncertain fat, who intended permitted he does not require atonement and forgiveness.
llm_translation: "And all these, why do I need them? They are necessary, for if a Tanna were to teach regarding a woman, there, where he requires atonement and forgiveness - because from the outset it was not properly established as forbidden. But a piece that is doubtful whether it is fat or doubtful whether it is suet, since it is leaning towards being permitted - it does not require atonement and forgiveness."

hebrew_text: וְאִי אִיתְּמַר הָדָא — דְּאִיכָּא אִיסּוּרָא. אֲבָל אִשָּׁה דְּהֵפֵר לָהּ בַּעְלָהּ, דְּהֶתֵּירָא — לָא תִּיבְעֵי כַּפָּרָה וּסְלִיחָה.
human_translation: And had this been stated as there is a prohibition However, a woman whose husband nullified her where permitted she does not require atonement and forgiveness.
llm_translation: And if it is said that there is a prohibition. But a woman whose husband divorced her and then permitted her - she does not require atonement and forgiveness.

hebrew_text: וְאִי אִיתְּמַר הָנֵי תַּרְתֵּי, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: הָנֵי תַּרְתֵּי הוּא דְּסַגִּי לְהוֹן בְּכַפָּרָה וּסְלִיחָה — דְּלָא אִיקְּבַע אִיסּוּרָא. אֲבָל שְׁתֵּי חֲתִיכוֹת אַחַת שֶׁל חֵלֶב וְאַחַת שֶׁל שׁוּמָּן, דְּאִיקְּבַע אִיסּוּרָא — לָא סַגִּי לֵיהּ בְּכַפָּרָה וּסְלִיחָה, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא שְׁנָא.
human_translation: And had these two been stated, I would say: It is these two which atonement and forgiveness are enough for them, as the prohibition is not established; However, two pieces, one of fat and one of fat, where the prohibition is established, atonement and forgiveness should not suffice for him. teaches us that is no different,
llm_translation: And if it were to be said regarding those two, I would say: those two are sufficient for them in atonement and forgiveness - for the prohibition is not firmly established. But two pieces, one of fat and one of oil, for the prohibition is firmly established - it is not sufficient for them in atonement and forgiveness, it is evident to us that it is not different.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבָּה בַּר בַּר חָנָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״כִּי יְשָׁרִים דַּרְכֵי ה׳ וְצַדִּקִים יֵלְכוּ בָם וּפֹשְׁעִים יִכָּשְׁלוּ בָם״ — מָשָׁל לִשְׁנֵי בְּנֵי אָדָם שֶׁצָּלוּ אֶת פִּסְחֵיהֶן, אֶחָד אֲכָלוֹ לְשׁוּם מִצְוָה, וְאֶחָד אֲכָלוֹ לְשׁוּם אֲכִילָה גַּסָּה. זֶה שֶׁאֲכָלוֹ לְשׁוּם מִצְוָה — ״וְצַדִּקִים יֵלְכוּ בָם״. וְזֶה שֶׁאֲכָלוֹ לְשׁוּם אֲכִילָה גַּסָּה — ״וּפֹשְׁעִים יִכָּשְׁלוּ בָם״.
human_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥanna said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What which is written: “For the paths of the Lord are right, and the just walk in them, but transgressors stumble over them” comparable to two people who roasted their Paschal offerings One ate it for the sake of the mitzva, and one ate it for the sake of excessive eating. This who ate it for the sake of the mitzva, “And the just walk in them,” while that who ate it for the sake of excessive eating, “But transgressors stumble over them.”
llm_translation: Rabba bar bar Ḥana said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: What is the meaning of what is written, "For the ways of the Lord are straight, and the righteous walk in them, but transgressors stumble in them"? This can be compared to two people who roasted their Passover offering, one ate it for the sake of the mitzvah, and the other ate it for the sake of gluttony. This one who ate it for the sake of the mitzvah - "and the righteous walk in them." And this one who ate it for the sake of gluttony - "but transgressors stumble in them."

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: הַאי ״רָשָׁע״ קָרֵית לֵיהּ?! נְהִי דְּלָא קָא עָבֵיד מִצְוָה מִן הַמּוּבְחָר, פֶּסַח מִיהָא קָא עָבֵיד! אֶלָּא: מָשָׁל לִשְׁנֵי בְּנֵי אָדָם, זֶה אִשְׁתּוֹ וַאֲחוֹתוֹ עִמּוֹ, וְזֶה אִשְׁתּוֹ וַאֲחוֹתוֹ עִמּוֹ. לְזֶה נִזְדַּמְּנָה לוֹ אִשְׁתּוֹ, וּלְזֶה נִזְדַּמְּנָה לוֹ אֲחוֹתוֹ. זֶה שֶׁנִּזְדַּמְּנָה לוֹ אִשְׁתּוֹ — ״צַדִּקִים יֵלְכוּ בָם״, וְזֶה שֶׁנִּזְדַּמְּנָה לוֹ אֲחוֹתוֹ — ״וּפֹשְׁעִים יִכָּשְׁלוּ בָם״.
human_translation: Reish Lakish said to You call this wicked? though he had not performed the mitzva in the optimal manner he has at least performed Paschal offering. Rather, comparable to two people; this his wife and sister with him, and that his wife and sister with him. This happened upon his wife, and that happened upon his sister. This who happened upon his wife, “And the just walk in them,” and that who happened upon his sister, “But transgressors stumble over them.”
llm_translation: He said to him, Reish Lakish: This "wicked" you call him?! Yes, for he is not doing a mitzvah from the choicest, rather he is doing Passover from it! Rather, a parable to two men, this one, his wife and sister are with him, and this one, his wife and sister are with him. To this one, his wife is similar, and to this one, his sister is similar. This one, whose wife is similar to him - "the righteous will walk in them," and this one, whose sister is similar to him - "and sinners will stumble in them."

hebrew_text: מִי דָּמֵי? אֲנַן קָאָמְרִינַן חֲדָא דֶּרֶךְ. הָכָא — שְׁנֵי דְרָכִים. אֶלָּא, מָשָׁל לְלוֹט וּשְׁתֵּי בְנוֹתָיו עִמּוֹ. הֵן שֶׁנִּתְכַּוְּונוּ לְשֵׁם מִצְוָה — ״וְצַדִּקִים יֵלְכוּ בָם״, הוּא שֶׁנִּתְכַּוֵּין לְשֵׁם עֲבֵירָה — ״וּפֹשְׁעִים יִכָּשְׁלוּ בָם״.
human_translation: Is it comparable? We said one path; here two paths. Rather, comparable to Lot and his two daughters, with him. They, who intended for the sake of a mitzva, “And the just walk in them.” He who intended for the sake of a transgression “But transgressors stumble over them.”
llm_translation: Who is similar? We are saying one way. Here - two ways. Rather, a parable to Lot and his two daughters with him. If they intended for the sake of a commandment - "and the righteous will walk in them," he who intended for the sake of a transgression - "and the sinners will stumble in them."

hebrew_text: וְדִלְמָא הוּא נָמֵי לְשׁוּם מִצְוָה אִיכַּוֵּוין? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כׇּל הַפָּסוּק הַזֶּה עַל שֵׁם עֲבֵירָה נֶאֱמַר.
human_translation: And perhaps too intended for the sake of a mitzva? Rabbi Yoḥanan said This entire verse: is stated with regard to sin
llm_translation: And perhaps he is considered to have fulfilled the mitzvah properly? Rabbi Yochanan said: This entire verse was stated in the context of a transgression.

hebrew_text: ״וַיִּשָּׂא לוֹט״ — ״וַתִּשָּׂא אֵשֶׁת אֲדֹנָיו אֶת עֵינֶיהָ״. [״אֶת עֵינָיו״ —] ״כִּי הִיא יָשְׁרָה בְעֵינָי״.
human_translation: “And Lot lifted up “That his master’s wife lifted up her eyes” “his eyes,” “For she is pleasing in my eyes”
llm_translation: "And Lot lifted up" — "And his master's wife lifted up her eyes." "Her eyes" "For she was pleasing in his eyes."

hebrew_text: ״וַיַּרְא״ — ״וַיַּרְא אֹתָהּ שְׁכֶם בֶּן חֲמוֹר״. ״אֶת כׇּל כִּכַּר הַיַּרְדֵּן״ — ״כִּי בְעַד אִשָּׁה זוֹנָה עַד כִּכַּר לָחֶם״. ״כִּי כֻלָּהּ מַשְׁקֶה״ — ״אֵלְכָה אַחֲרֵי מְאַהֲבַי נֹתְנֵי לַחְמִי וּמֵימַי צַמְרִי וּפִשְׁתִּי שַׁמְנִי וְשִׁיקּוּיָי״.
human_translation: “and saw” “And Shechem, the son of Hamor the Hivite, saw her “All the plain [ kikar ] of the Jordan,” “For on account of a harlot a man is brought to a loaf [ kikar ] of bread” “That it was well watered everywhere,” “I will go after my lovers, who give me my bread and my water, my wool and my flax, my oil and my drink”
llm_translation: "And he saw" — "And he saw her, Shechem son of Hamor." "All the plain of the Jordan" — "For because of this harlot woman, up to a loaf of bread." "For she has poured out all" — "I will go after my lovers, who give my bread and my water, my wool and my flax, my oil and my drink."

hebrew_text: וְהָא מֵינָס אֲנִיס! תָּנָא מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בַּר רַב חוֹנִי: לָמָּה נָקוּד עַל וָיו ״וּבְקוּמָהּ״ שֶׁל בְּכִירָה, לוֹמַר שֶׁבְּשִׁכְבָהּ לָא יָדַע, אֲבָל בְּקוּמָהּ יָדַע.
human_translation: But was forced taught in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Rav Ḥoni: Why is there a dot over vav of “ uvekumah ,” with regard to elder to say that when she lay down he did not know; however, when she arose he knew
llm_translation: The Gemara asks: And did she flee and was forced to commit adultery? It was taught in a Baraita in the name of Rabbi Yosei bar Rav Ḥoni: Why is the vav in the word "ובקומה" of the eldest daughter marked with a dot? To say that in her lying down she did not know that it was her father, but in her rising up she knew that it was her father.

hebrew_text: וּמַאי הֲוָה לֵיהּ לְמִיעְבַּד? מַאי דַהֲוָה הֲוָה! נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ, דִּלְפַנְיָא אַחֲרִינָא לָא אִיבְּעִי לְמִישְׁתֵּי חַמְרָא.
human_translation: And what could he have done What has happened has happened; difference that on the other, night, he should not have drunk wine
llm_translation: And what was it for him to do? Whatever was, was! It emerged from her, for before another one, he did not need to drink wine.

hebrew_text: דָּרֵשׁ רָבָא: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״אָח נִפְשָׁע מִקִּרְיַת עֹז
human_translation: Rava interpreted homiletically What is which is written: “A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city,
llm_translation: Rava expounded: What is the meaning of what is written, "A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city"?

hebrew_text: וּמִדְיָנִים כִּבְרִיחַ אַרְמוֹן״? ״אָח נִפְשָׁע מִקִּרְיַת עֹז״ — זֶה לוֹט, שֶׁפֵּירַשׁ מֵאַבְרָהָם. ״וּמִדְיָנִים כִּבְרִיחַ אַרְמוֹן״ — שֶׁהֵטִיל מִדְיָנִים כִּבְרִיחִין וְאַרְמוֹן, ״לֹא יָבֹא עַמּוֹנִי וּמוֹאָבִי בִּקְהַל ה׳״.
human_translation: and their contentions are like the bars of a castle” “A brother offended is harder to be won than a strong city,” this is Lot, who separated from Abraham. “And their contentions are like the bars of a castle,” because brought contention like bars, a castle. “An Ammonite and a Moabite shall not enter into the assembly of the Lord”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And Midianites like the bars of a palace?" "A brother is born for adversity from the city of strength" - this is Lot, who separated from Abraham. "And Midianites like the bars of a palace" - that Midianites cast bars and palace, "An Ammonite or Moabite shall not enter into the congregation of the Lord."

hebrew_text: דָּרֵשׁ רָבָא וְאִיתֵּימָא רַבִּי יִצְחָק: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״לְתַאֲוָה יְבַקֵּשׁ נִפְרָד וּבְכׇל תּוּשִׁיָּה יִתְגַּלָּע״? ״לְתַאֲוָה יְבַקֵּשׁ נִפְרָד״ — זֶה לוֹט, ״וּבְכָל תּוּשִׁיָּה יִתְגַּלָּע״ — שֶׁנִּתְגַּלָּה קְלוֹנוֹ בְּבָתֵּי כְנֵסִיּוֹת וּבְבָתֵּי מִדְרָשׁוֹת. דִּתְנַן: עַמּוֹנִי וּמוֹאָבִי אֲסוּרִין, וְאִיסּוּרָן אִיסּוּר עוֹלָם.
human_translation: Rava expounded homiletically, and some say Rabbi Yitzḥak: What is which is written: “He who separates himself seeks his own desire, and snarls against all sound wisdom” “He who separates himself seeks his own desire,” this is Lot, “And snarls [ yitgala ] against all sound wisdom,” as his shame was revealed [ nitgala ] in the synagogues, and in the study halls, As we learned An Ammonite and a Moabite are prohibited and their prohibition is permanent.
llm_translation: Rava sought and it was stated by Rabbi Yitzchak: What is the meaning of what is written, "He seeks desire, he separates, he rebels against all sound wisdom"? "He seeks desire, he separates" - this refers to Lot, "and he rebels against all sound wisdom" - that his disgrace was revealed in synagogues and study halls. As we learned: Ammonites and Moabites are prohibited, and their prohibition is an eternal prohibition.

hebrew_text: אָמַר עוּלָּא: תָּמָר זִינְּתָה, זִמְרִי זִינָּה.
human_translation: Ulla said: Tamar engaged in licentious Zimri engaged in licentious
llm_translation: Ula said: "A date palm is promiscuous, a vine is promiscuous."

hebrew_text: תָּמָר זִינְּתָה — יָצְאוּ מִמֶּנָּה מְלָכִים וּנְבִיאִים. זִמְרִי זִינָּה — נָפְלוּ עָלָיו כַּמָּה רְבָבוֹת מִיִּשְׂרָאֵל.
human_translation: Tamar engaged in licentious kings descended from her. And prophets, Zimri, engaged in licentious several multitudes of Israel fell due to him;
llm_translation: Date palm tree — kings and prophets emerged from it. Olive tree — many myriads of Israel fell upon it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בַּר יִצְחָק: גְּדוֹלָה עֲבֵירָה לִשְׁמָהּ מִמִּצְוָה שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָהּ. וְהָאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: לְעוֹלָם יַעֲסוֹק אָדָם בְּתוֹרָה וּבְמִצְוֹת אֲפִילּוּ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָן, שֶׁמִּתּוֹךְ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָן בָּא לִשְׁמָן?
human_translation: Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Greater is a transgression for its own sake, than a mitzva not for its own sake. But didn’t Rav Yehuda say Rav said: A person should always occupy himself with Torah and mitzvot even not for their own sake, as through not for their own sake for their own sake come
llm_translation: Rav Nachman son of Yitzchak said: Great is sin for its own sake than commandment not for its own sake. And Rav Yehuda said in the name of Rav: A person should always engage in Torah and commandments even not for their own sake, for through not for their own sake, one comes to do them for their own sake.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אֵימָא: כְּמִצְוָה שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָהּ. דִּכְתִיב: ״תְּבֹרַךְ מִנָּשִׁים יָעֵל אֵשֶׁת חֶבֶר הַקֵּינִי מִנָּשִׁים בָּאֹהֶל תְּבֹרָךְ״. מַאן נָשִׁים שֶׁבָּאֹהֶל — שָׂרָה רִבְקָה רָחֵל וְלֵאָה.
human_translation: Rather, say equivalent to a mitzva not for its own sake. as it is written: “Blessed above women shall Yael be, the wife of Hever the Kenite, above women in the tent she shall be blessed” Who are “women in the tent?” Sarah, Rebecca, Rachel, and Leah.
llm_translation: Rather say: like a commandment not for its own sake. As it is written: "Blessed above women shall Yael the wife of Hever the Kenite be, blessed shall she be above women in the tent." Who are the women in the tent? Sarah, Rivka, Rachel, and Leah.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: שֶׁבַע בְּעִילוֹת בָּעַל אוֹתוֹ רָשָׁע בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״בֵּין רַגְלֶיהָ כָּרַע נָפַל שָׁכָב וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That wicked one, engaged in seven acts of sexual intercourse at that time, as it is stated: “Between her feet he sunk, he fell, he lay;
llm_translation: Rabbi Yochanan said: Seven coitions the husband of that wicked woman at that time, as it is said: "Between her legs he stumbled, he fell, he lay down, etc."

hebrew_text: וְהָא קָא מִתְהַנְיָא מִבְּעִילָה דִילֵיהּ? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כׇּל טוֹבָתָן שֶׁל רְשָׁעִים — אֵינָהּ אֶלָּא רָעָה אֵצֶל צַדִּיקִים,
human_translation: But enjoyed the sexual intercourse him; Rabbi Yoḥanan said: All the good of the wicked, is nothing other evil for the righteous,
llm_translation: And this one is benefiting from his wife's menstruation? Rabbi Yochanan said: All the goodness of the wicked is only bad for the righteous.

hebrew_text: שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הִשָּׁמֶר לְךָ מִדַּבֵּר עִם יַעֲקֹב מִטּוֹב וְעַד רָע״. בִּשְׁלָמָא רַע — שַׁפִּיר, אֶלָּא טוֹב אַמַּאי לָא? אֶלָּא, לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: טוֹבָתוֹ — רָעָה הִיא. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: As is stated “Guard yourself from speaking to Jacob, from good to evil” Granted, evil, fine However, why shouldn’t good Rather, not conclude from good is bad Learn from this
llm_translation: Talmudic text: As it is stated: "Take heed to yourself that you speak not to Jacob either good or bad." (Genesis 31:24) Now, bad is understandable - it is fine. But why not good? Rather, infer from it: his good is bad. Infer from it.

hebrew_text: גּוּפָא, אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: לְעוֹלָם יַעֲסוֹק אָדָם בְּתוֹרָה וּבְמִצְוֹת אֲפִילּוּ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָן, שֶׁמִּתּוֹךְ שֶׁלֹּא לִשְׁמָן בָּא לִשְׁמָן. שֶׁבִּשְׂכַר אַרְבָּעִים וּשְׁנַיִם קׇרְבָּנוֹת שֶׁהִקְרִיב בָּלָק הָרָשָׁע — זָכָה וְיָצְאָה מִמֶּנּוּ רוּת. וְאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: רוּת, בַּת בְּנוֹ שֶׁל עֶגְלוֹן מֶלֶךְ מוֹאָב הָיְתָה.
human_translation: the itself. Rav Yehuda said Rav said: A person should always occupy himself with Torah and mitzvot even not for their own sake, as through not for their own sake, for their own sake come that in reward for the forty-two offerings that the wicked Balak sacrificed he merited that Ruth descended from him. And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: Ruth was the daughter of the son of Eglon, king of Moab,
llm_translation: The body, Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: A person should always engage in Torah and mitzvot, even not for their own sake, for through not for their own sake, one comes to do them for their own sake. For in the merit of the forty-two sacrifices that the wicked Balak offered, Ruth was privileged and emerged from him. And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Chanina, said: Ruth was the daughter of Eglon, king of Moab.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אַבָּא אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מִנַּיִן שֶׁאֵין הַקָּדוֹשׁ בָּרוּךְ הוּא מְקַפֵּחַ אֲפִילּוּ שְׂכַר שִׂיחָה נָאָה, דְּאִילּוּ בְּכִירָה דִּקְרָיתֵיהּ מוֹאָב, אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַחֲמָנָא ״אַל תָּצַר אֶת מוֹאָב וְאַל תִּתְגָּר בָם מִלְחָמָה״. מִלְחָמָה הוּא דְּלָא, אֲבָל צַעוֹרֵי צַעֲרִינֻּן.
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where that the Holy One, Blessed be He, does not deprive even reward for proper speech, As while elder who called Moab [ mo’av ], and the Merciful One says to “Do not besiege Moab, nor contend with them in war” war that is not however, harassing, to harass them.
llm_translation: Rabbi Hiyya bar Abba said in the name of Rabbi Yohanan: From where do we know that the Holy One, blessed be He, does not withhold reward even for pleasant conversation? For even with regard to the city of Moab, as it is written, "Do not harass Moab or engage them in battle" (Deuteronomy 2:9). Engage them in battle is not permitted, but causing distress is permitted.

hebrew_text: וְאִילּוּ צְעִירָה דִּקְרָיתֵיהּ בֶּן עַמִּי. אֲמַר לֵיהּ: ״אַל תְּצֻרֵם וְאַל תִּתְגָּר בָם״. אֲפִילּוּ צַעוֹרֵי, לָא תְּצַעֲרִינֻּן כְּלָל.
human_translation: And while younger who called Ben-Ami, said to “Do not harass them, nor contend with them” even harassing you may not harass them at all.
llm_translation: And if a young girl read it, her father said to her: "Do not close them off, and do not engage with them." Even with small children, we do not cause them any distress at all.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי חִיָּיא בַּר אָבִין, אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קׇרְחָה: לְעוֹלָם יַקְדִּים אָדָם לִדְבַר מִצְוָה, שֶׁבִּשְׂכַר לַיְלָה אַחַת שֶׁקְּדָמַתָּה בְּכִירָה לִצְעִירָה,
human_translation: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin said Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa said: A person should always come first to a matter of a mitzva, as in reward of one night that the elder preceded the younger
llm_translation: Rabbi Hiyya bar Avin said, Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha said: A person should always hasten to perform a commandment, for in reward for one night that the elder preceded the younger,

hebrew_text: זָכְתָה וְקָדְמָה אַרְבָּעָה דּוֹרוֹת בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל לַמַּלְכוּת.
human_translation: she merited to precede four generations to the monarchy of the Jewish people.
llm_translation: She merited and preceded four generations in Israel to the monarchy.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ הָאִשָּׁה שֶׁנָּדְרָה בְּנָזִיר, וְהִפְרִישָׁה אֶת בְּהֶמְתָּהּ, וְאַחַר כָּךְ הֵיפֵר לָהּ בַּעֲלָהּ. אִם שֶׁלּוֹ הָיְתָה הַבְּהֵמָה — תֵּצֵא וְתִרְעֶה בָּעֵדֶר.
human_translation: a woman who vowed to be a nazirite and separated her animals and afterward her husband nullified her vow, If the animal was his, it shall go out and graze among flock
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: A woman who took a vow of a Nazirite, and separated her animal, and afterwards her husband annulled it for her. If the animal belonged to him, it should go out and graze with the flock.

hebrew_text: וְאִם שֶׁלָּהּ הָיְתָה הַבְּהֵמָה, הַחַטָּאת — תָּמוּת, וְעוֹלָה — תִּקְרַב עוֹלָה, שְׁלָמִים — תִּקְרַב שְׁלָמִים, וְנֶאֱכָלִין לְיוֹם אֶחָד, וְאֵינָן טְעוּנִין לֶחֶם.
human_translation: And if the animal was hers, The a sin-offering must die And a burnt-offering is sacrificed a burnt-offering, a peace-offering, sacrificed peace-offering. And is eaten for one day, But does not require bread,
llm_translation: If it was hers, the sin offering - shall die, and the burnt offering - shall be brought as a burnt offering, the peace offerings - shall be brought as peace offerings, and they shall be eaten in one day, and they do not require bread.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ לָהּ מָעוֹת סְתוּמִין — יִפְּלוּ לִנְדָבָה. מָעוֹת מְפוֹרָשִׁין, דְּמֵי חַטָּאת — יֵלְכוּ לְיָם הַמֶּלַח. לֹא נֶהֱנִין, וְלֹא מוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן.
human_translation: she had unallocated funds, will be earmarked for gift allocated funds, the money for the sin-offering taken into the Dead Sea, not benefit but not misuse with it.
llm_translation: If she has sealed coins - they shall fall for a donation. Unsealed coins, the value of a sin offering - shall go to the Dead Sea. They are not enjoyed, and not benefited from.

hebrew_text: דְּמֵי עוֹלָה — יָבִיאוּ עוֹלָה, וּמוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן. דְּמֵי שְׁלָמִים — יָבִיאוּ שְׁלָמִים, וְנֶאֱכָלִין לְיוֹם אֶחָד, וְאֵין טְעוּנִין לֶחֶם.
human_translation: the money for the burnt-offering, a burnt-offering is brought and from it misuse the money for a peace-offering, a peace-offering is brought and is eaten for one day and does not require bread.
llm_translation: The value of a burnt offering - they shall bring a burnt offering, and benefit from them. The value of peace offerings - they shall bring peace offerings, and they shall be eaten in one day, and there is no requirement for bread.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ מַאן תְּנָא דְּבַעַל לָא מִשְׁתַּעְבַּד לַהּ? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רַבָּנַן הִיא. דְּאִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא, אַמַּאי תֵּצֵא וְתִרְעֶה בָּעֵדֶר? הָא מִשְׁתַּעְבַּד לַהּ.
human_translation: Who taught that a husband is not indebted to Rav Ḥisda said: It is the Rabbis. As, if it should enter your mind it is Rabbi Yehuda, why go out and graze among flock indebted to her
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara: Maan tana de'baal lo mishtabed la? Amar Rav Chisda: Rabbanan hi. De'ei sakadateich Rabbi Yehuda hi, amai teitzei ve'tir'eh ba'eder? Ha mishtabed la. English translation: Gemara: Who is the Tanna that a Baal does not become subservient to her? Rav Chisda said: It is the Rabbis. For if according to your opinion it is Rabbi Yehuda, why then should she go out and graze in the pasture? She becomes subservient to him.

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: אָדָם מֵבִיא קׇרְבַּן עָשִׁיר עַל אִשְׁתּוֹ.
human_translation: As it is taught Rabbi Yehuda says: A person brings the offering of a rich on behalf of his wife.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yehuda says: A person brings a rich offering for his wife.

hebrew_text: וְכֵן כׇּל קׇרְבְּנוֹתֶיהָ שֶׁהִיא חַיֶּיבֶת, שֶׁכָּךְ כָּתַב לָהּ: ״כׇּל אַחְרָיוּת דְּאִית לִיךְ עֲלַי מִן קַדְמַת דְּנָא״.
human_translation: And similarly, all her offerings that she is obligated that he wrote to her like this: all guarantee that you have upon me from beforehand.
llm_translation: And so too all its offerings that are obligatory, for thus it is written for her: "All its afterbirth that comes out from her."

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה, כִּי מְשַׁעְבַּד לַהּ — בְּמִילְּתָא דִּצְרִיכָא לַהּ, בְּמִילְּתָא דְּלָא צְרִיכָא לַהּ — לָא.
human_translation: Rava said: You even say Rabbi Yehuda, When he obligated her in a matter that is necessary for her in a matter that is not necessary for her no
llm_translation: Rava said: Even if you say it is Rabbi Yehuda, when it is necessary for her - in a matter that she needs, when it is not necessary for her - no.

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא דְּאָמְרִי: מַאן תַּנָּא? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא. וְכִי מְשַׁעְבַּד לַהּ — בְּמִילְּתָא דִּצְרִיכָא לַהּ, בְּמִילְּתָא דְּלָא צְרִיכָא לָהּ — לָא. דְּאִי רַבָּנַן — לָא מְשַׁעְבַּד לַהּ כְּלָל.
human_translation: Some say Who taught Rav Ḥisda said it is Rabbi Yehuda, and When he indebted her in a matter that is necessary for her in a matter that is not necessary for her no As, the Rabbis, he is not mortgaged to her at all.
llm_translation: There are those who say: Who is the Tanna? Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yehuda. And if he is subservient to her - in a matter that she needs, in a matter that she does not need - no. For if he is a scholar, he does not serve her at all.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא הֵיכִי דָּמֵי דִּמְשַׁעְבַּד לַהּ — כְּגוֹן דְּאַקְנְיַיהּ לַהּ, וְכֵיוָן דְּאַקְנֵי לַהּ — הָוֵה דְּנַפְשַׁהּ.
human_translation: Rather, what are the circumstances he is obligated to her For example, if he transferred to her But since he has transferred it to her, it is her own,
llm_translation: Rather, how so is the case that he is obligated to her — for example, if he acquires her, and once he acquires her — she becomes his own soul.

hebrew_text: רָבָא אָמַר: אֲפִילּוּ תֵּימָא רַבָּנַן, כִּי מַקְנֵי לַהּ — נָמֵי בְּמִלְּתָא דִּצְרִיכָא לַהּ, בְּמִילְּתָא דְּלָא צְרִיכָא לַהּ — לָא מַקְנֵי לַהּ.
human_translation: Rava said: You even say the Rabbis, even when he transfers it to her, for a matter that is necessary for her for a matter is not necessary for her he does not transfer it to her.
llm_translation: Rava said: Even if you say they are scholars, when it comes to something she needs, yes, in something she does not need, they do not acquire for her.

hebrew_text: אִם שֶׁלָּהּ הָיְתָה בְּהֶמְתָּהּ, חַטָּאת — תָּמוּת, וְעוֹלָה — תִּקְרַב. הִיא מְנָא לַהּ? הָאָמְרַתְּ: מַה שֶּׁקָּנְתָה אִשָּׁה קָנָה בַּעְלָהּ! אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: שֶׁקִּמְּצַתָּה מֵעִיסָּתָהּ. אִיבָּעֵית אֵימָא: דְּאַקְנִי לַהּ אַחֵר, וַאֲמַר לַהּ: ״עַל מְנָת שֶׁאֵין לְבַעְלֵיךְ רְשׁוּת בָּהֶן״.
human_translation: If the animal was hers, the sin-offering must die and the burnt-offering is sacrificed. She, from where her Haven’t you said that a woman acquires, her husband acquires Rav Pappa said: where she saved it from her dough, if you wish, say that another transferred to her, and said to her on the condition that your husband has no rights to it.
llm_translation: If it was hers, her sin offering — she shall die, and her burnt offering — she shall bring near. How does she count for herself? For you said: "Whatever a woman acquires, her husband acquires!" Rav Papa said: "That she found from her dough." If you wish, say: "I will acquire another for her, and say to her: 'On the condition that your husbands have no authority over them.'"

hebrew_text: הָעוֹלָה — תִּקְרַב עוֹלָה, וְהַשְּׁלָמִים — תִּקְרַב כּוּ׳. אֲמַר לֵיהּ שְׁמוּאֵל לַאֲבוּהּ בַּר אִיהִי: לָא תִּיתֵּיב עַל כַּרְעָיךְ עַד דְּאָמְרַתְּ לִי הָדָא מִילְּתָא: וְאֵלּוּ הֵן אַרְבָּעָה אֵילִים שֶׁאֵינָן טְעוּנִין לֶחֶם: שֶׁלּוֹ, וְשֶׁלָּהּ, וְשֶׁלְּאַחַר הַמִּיתָה, וְשֶׁלְּאַחַר כַּפָּרָה.
human_translation: the burnt-offering is sacrificed as a burnt-offering and the peace-offering is sacrificed Shmuel said to Avuh bar Ihi: You shall not sit on your feet until you say to me this matter And these are four rams that do not require bread His, hers, the one after death, and the one after atonement
llm_translation: Talmudic text: The burnt offering - bring a burnt offering, and the peace offerings - bring like so. Samuel said to his father-in-law, son of Ihi: Do not sit on your heels until you say to me this matter: And these are the four rams that are not required for bread: his, and hers, and after death, and after atonement.

hebrew_text: שֶׁלָּהּ — הָא דַּאֲמַרַן. שֶׁלּוֹ — דִּתְנַן: הָאִישׁ מַדִּיר אֶת בְּנוֹ בְּנָזִיר, וְאֵין הָאִשָּׁה מַדֶּרֶת אֶת בְּנָהּ בְּנָזִיר. גִּילַּח, אוֹ שֶׁגִּילְּחוּהוּ קְרוֹבִים, מִיחָה, אוֹ שֶׁמִּיחוּהוּ קְרוֹבִים.
human_translation: Hers, that we said, His, as we learned A man can vow his son to a nazirite, but a woman cannot vow her son to a nazirite. shaved or if relatives shaved him, objected, or if relatives made him object,
llm_translation: Her hair — this that we say. His hair — as we learned: If a man vows his son as a Nazirite, but the woman does not vow her son as a Nazirite. If he shaved, or if his close relatives shaved him, or if they anointed him, or if his close relatives anointed him.

hebrew_text: הָיוּ לוֹ מָעוֹת סְתוּמִין — יִפְּלוּ לִנְדָבָה. מָעוֹת מְפוֹרָשִׁין, דְּמֵי חַטָּאת — יֵלְכוּ לְיָם הַמֶּלַח, דְּמֵי עוֹלָה — יָבִיאוּ עוֹלָה, וּמוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן. דְּמֵי שְׁלָמִים — יָבִיאוּ שְׁלָמִים, וְנֶאֱכָלִין לְיוֹם אֶחָד, וְאֵינָן טְעוּנִין לֶחֶם.
human_translation: he had unallocated funds, will be earmarked for gift offerings. allocated funds the money for a sin-offering taken into the Dead Sea; the money for a burnt-offering is brought a burnt-offering, and from it misuse the money for a peace-offering is brought a peace-offering and it is eaten for one day and does not require bread.
llm_translation: If he had sealed coins - they should be designated for voluntary offerings. Sealed coins, the value of a sin offering - should be thrown into the Dead Sea. The value of a burnt offering - should be brought as a burnt offering, and one may benefit from them. The value of peace offerings - should be brought as peace offerings, and they are to be eaten within one day, and they do not require bread.

hebrew_text: שֶׁלְּאַחַר מִיתָה מְנָלַן, דְּתַנְיָא: הַמַּפְרִישׁ מָעוֹת לִנְזִירוּתוֹ — לֹא נֶהֱנִין וְלֹא מוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהֵן רְאוּיִין לְהָבִיא בְּכוּלָּן שְׁלָמִים.
human_translation: that is after death, from where do we As it is taught one who separates money for his naziriteship not derive benefit but from it not misuse because is fit to bring peace-offerings with all of it,
llm_translation: After death, from where do we derive this? For it was taught: One who separates coins for his Nazirite vow—neither benefit nor trespass is derived from them, because they are fit to be brought as peace offerings.

hebrew_text: מֵת, וְהָיוּ לוֹ מָעוֹת סְתוּמִים — יִפְּלוּ לִנְדָבָה. מָעוֹת מְפוֹרָשִׁין, דְּמֵי חַטָּאת — יוֹלִיךְ לְיָם הַמֶּלַח, לֹא נֶהֱנִין וְלֹא מוֹעֲלִין. דְּמֵי עוֹלָה — יָבִיאוּ עוֹלָה, וּמוֹעֲלִין בָּהֶן. דְּמֵי שְׁלָמִים — יָבִיאוּ שְׁלָמִים, וְנֶאֱכָלִין לְיוֹם אֶחָד, וְאֵינָן טְעוּנִין לֶחֶם.
human_translation: died and he had unallocated funds, they are allocated for gift allocated funds, the money for a sin-offering, take into the Dead Sea; not derive benefit but from it not misuse The money for a burnt-offering is brought a burnt-offering, and from it misuse The money for a peace-offering is brought a peace-offering, and it is eaten for one day and does not require bread.
llm_translation: Deceased, and he has sealed coins - they shall fall for a donation. Explicit coins, the value of a sin offering - he shall cast into the Dead Sea, they are not enjoyed and not benefiting. The value of a burnt offering - he shall bring a burnt offering, and they benefit from it.
