human_translation: And the Rabbis, are necessary, For had the Merciful One written with regard to a sin-offering, I would say a nazirite cannot be derived from it, due to we do not derive a nazirite from consecrated
llm_translation: The sages said: It is necessary, for if the Merciful One had written regarding the sin offering, I would have said: A nazirite does not come from it, because a nazirite cannot be derived from consecrated items.

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא גַּבֵּי נָזִיר, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: מִנָּזִיר לָא יָלְפִינַן, מִשּׁוּם דַּחֲמִיר אִיסּוּרֵיהּ, דַּאֲפִילּוּ חַרְצָן אֲסִיר לֵיהּ, הִלְכָּךְ לָא אָתְיָא מִינֵּיהּ.
human_translation: And had the Merciful One written with regard to a nazirite, I would say we do not derive from a nazirite due to that its prohibition is stringent. as even a grape seed is forbidden to Therefore, cannot be derived from
llm_translation: If the Merciful One wrote regarding a Nazirite, I would say: We do not derive laws from a Nazirite, because his prohibitions are stringent, for even if a razor touches him, he becomes liable. Therefore, the law does not come from him.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא אָמַר לָךְ: לְמַאי צְרִיכִי? בִּשְׁלָמָא אִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא חַטָּאת, לָא גָּמַר נָזִיר מִינַּהּ — דְּחוּלִּין מִקֳּדָשִׁים לָא גָּמְרִינַן. אֶלָּא לִכְתּוֹב רַחֲמָנָא בְּנָזִיר, וְתֵיתֵי חַטָּאת מִינֵּיהּ, דְּהָא כׇּל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה קָא גָמְרִי מִנָּזִיר.
human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva said to you, Why are necessary? Granted, if the Merciful One had written to a sin-offering, not derive a nazirite from it, we do not derive non-sacred from consecrated However, let the Merciful One write with regard to a nazirite, and you derive sin-offering from as all prohibitions in the Torah is derived from a nazirite.
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva said to you: For what do I need it? If indeed the Merciful One wrote "sin offering," we would not complete the Nazirite from it - for we do not complete mundane matters from matters of sanctity. Rather, to write "Nazirite" and bring a sin offering from it, for all prohibitions in the Torah are completed from the Nazirite.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן אָמְרִי לָךְ: חַטָּאת לְהֶיתֵּר מִצְטָרֵף לְאִיסּוּר, וְחוּלִּין מִקֳּדָשִׁים לָא גָּמְרִינַן.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, would say to you a sin-offering to that a permitted combines with a forbidden and one cannot derive non-sacred from consecrated
llm_translation: The sages say to you: a sin offering to be permitted joins with a prohibition, and common items do not complete with sanctified items.

hebrew_text: וּ״מִשְׁרַת״ — לִיתֵּן טַעַם כְּעִיקָּר, מִכָּאן אַתָּה דָּן לְכׇל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה.
human_translation: And “soaked,” teaches flavor like substance. And from here you derive to all of the prohibitions of the Torah.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And 'mishrat' - to give a reason as the primary, from here you judge for all prohibitions in the Torah." English translation: "And 'mishrat' - to give a reason as the primary, from here you judge for all prohibitions in the Torah."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, תַּרְוַיְיהוּ לְהֶיתֵּר מִצְטָרֵף לְאִיסּוּר, וְהָווּ לְהוּ שְׁנֵי כְתוּבִין הַבָּאִין כְּאֶחָד, וְכׇל שְׁנֵי כְתוּבִין הַבָּאִים כְּאֶחָד — אֵין מְלַמְּדִין.
human_translation: And Rabbi Akiva both that a permitted combines with a forbidden and they are two verses that come as one, And any two verses that come as one do not teach
llm_translation: Rabbi Akiva, both of them to be permitted from being combined to prohibition, and they were to him two Scriptures that come as one, and any two Scriptures that come as one - do not teach.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אָשֵׁי לְרַב כָּהֲנָא: אֶלָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: ״מִכֹּל אֲשֶׁר יֵעָשֶׂה מִגֶּפֶן הַיַּיִן״, לִימֵּד עַל אִיסּוּרֵי נָזִיר שֶׁהֵן מִצְטָרְפִין זֶה עִם זֶה, לְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, הַשְׁתָּא יֵשׁ לוֹמַר הֶיתֵּר מִצְטָרֵף לְאִיסּוּר, אִיסּוּר לְאִיסּוּר מִבַּעְיָא?
human_translation: Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: But that which is taught anything that is made of the grapevine” taught with regard to prohibitions of a nazirite that combine with each other. According to Rabbi Akiva, now one says permitted combine with forbidden is it necessary forbidden combines with forbidden
llm_translation: He said to him, Rav Ashe to Rav Kahana: Rather, as it was taught: "From all that is done from the grapevine of wine," it teaches about the prohibitions of a Nazirite which combine with each other, according to Rabbi Akiva. Now, can one prohibition combine with another prohibition?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הֶיתֵּר לְאִיסּוּר — בְּבַת אַחַת, אִיסּוּר לְאִיסּוּר — אֲפִילּוּ בְּזֶה אַחַר זֶה.
human_translation: said to Permitted with forbidden simultaneously, forbidden combine with forbidden even one after the other.
llm_translation: He said to him: Permitted for prohibition - in one instance, prohibition for prohibition - even in this after that.

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon,
llm_translation: And Rabbi Shimon

hebrew_text: דְּלֵית לֵיהּ צֵירוּף, ״מִכֹּל אֲשֶׁר יֵעָשֶׂה״, מַאי דָּרֵישׁ בֵּיהּ? אָמַר לָךְ: הַהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ: לְעוֹלָם אֵינוֹ נָזִיר עַד שֶׁיַּזִּיר מִכּוּלָּן.
human_translation: who is not of combination what does he derive “anything that is made said to you: That necessary one is never a nazirite until he vows naziriteship from all of them.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If it does not have a mixture, "from all that he will do," what does he expound in it? He said to you: That one requires it: He is never a Nazirite until he separates from all of them. English translation: If it does not have a mixture, "from all that he will do," what does he expound in it? He said to you: That one requires it: He is never a Nazirite until he separates from all of them.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֲבָהוּ אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: כׇּל רְבִיעִיּוֹת שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה, אֵין הֶיתֵּר מִצְטָרֵף לְאִיסּוּר, חוּץ מֵרְבִיעִית שֶׁבַּנָּזִיר, שֶׁהֲרֵי אָמְרָה תּוֹרָה ״מִשְׁרַת״. מַאי אִיכָּא בֵּין רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן לְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר?
human_translation: Rabbi Abbahu said Rabbi Elazar said: every that is in the Torah a quarter- a permitted does not combine with a forbidden apart from the quarter of a nazirite. as the Torah stated: “Soaked” What is there between Rabbi Yoḥanan, and Rabbi Elazar,
llm_translation: Said Rabbi Avahu said Rabbi Elazar: All fourths in the Torah, not permitted joins with forbidden, except fourth of the Nazirite, as Torah said "from wine." What is the difference between Rabbi Yochanan to Rabbi Elazar?

hebrew_text: אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ, דְּרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מֵרַבִּי אֲפִילּוּ אוֹכָלִין, וְרַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר, מַשְׁקִין — אִין, מִידֵּי אַחֲרִינָא — לָא.
human_translation: There is between them, as Rabbi Yoḥanan amplifies even foods, and Rabbi Elazar liquids, yes, other matters, no,
llm_translation: There is a difference between them, that Rabbi Yochanan from Rabbi even if they eat, and Rabbi Elazar, they drink - no, from others - no.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: עֶשֶׂר רְבִיעִיּוֹת הֵן, וְנָקֵיט רַב כָּהֲנָא בִּידֵיהּ חֲמֵשׁ סוּמָּקָתָא וַחֲמֵשׁ חִיוּוֹרָתָא. חֲמֵשׁ סוּמָּקָתָא: ״נָזִיר וְעוֹשֵׂה פֶסַח שֶׁהוֹרוּ בַּמִּקְדָּשׁ וָמֵתוּ״.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar says: There are ten quarter and Rav Kahana held in his hand Five red and five white. five red A nazirite; and one who performs the Paschal offering; who instructed; in the Temple; and they died.
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar said: There are ten quarters, and Rav Kahana took in his hands five red and five white. Five red: "A Nazirite and one who performs the Passover sacrifice, who were warned in the Temple and died."

hebrew_text: ״נָזִיר״ — רְבִיעִית יַיִן לְנָזִיר. ״עוֹשֵׂה פֶסַח״ — דְּאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: אַרְבַּע כּוֹסוֹת הַלָּלוּ צָרִיךְ שֶׁיְּהֵא בָּהֶן כְּדֵי רְבִיעִית. ״שֶׁהוֹרוּ״ — שָׁתָה רְבִיעִית יַיִן אַל יוֹרֶה. ״בַּמִּקְדָּשׁ״ — שָׁתָה רְבִיעִית יַיִן וְנִכְנַס לַמִּקְדָּשׁ חַיָּיב מִיתָה.
human_translation: A nazirite, quarter of wine for a nazirite Who performs Paschal offering, as Rav Yehuda says Shmuel says: these four cups they must contain a quarter Who instructed, drank a quarter of wine may not issue rulings In the Temple, drank a quarter of wine and entered the Temple is liable the death penalty
llm_translation: "Nazir" - a quarter of a log of wine for a Nazirite. "Making Pesach" - as Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: These four cups of praise require that there should be in them a quarter of a log. "That they became intoxicated" - one who drinks a quarter of a log of wine should not render a legal decision. "In the Temple" - one who drinks a quarter of a log of wine and enters the Temple is liable to receive the death penalty.

hebrew_text: ״וּמֵתוּ״ — דְּתַנְיָא: מִנַּיִן לִרְבִיעִית דָּם שֶׁיּוֹצְאָה מִשְּׁנֵי מֵתִים שֶׁהִיא מְטַמְּאָה בְּאֹהֶל, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְעַל כׇּל נַפְשׁוֹת מֵת לֹא יָבֹא״.
human_translation: And they died, as it is taught From where to a quarter of blood that emerges from two corpses, that it renders ritually impure in a tent, As it is stated, “Neither shall he go in to any dead bodies”
llm_translation: "Tanna taught: From where do we derive the fourth degree of impurity of blood that emerges from two corpses, which defiles in a tent, as it is stated: 'But for a dead person, he shall not enter' (Numbers 19:14)."

hebrew_text: וַחֲמֵשׁ חִיוּוֹרָתָא: ״חַלַּת נָזִיר וּמְצוֹרָע שֶׁנִּפְסְלוּ בְּשַׁבָּת״. ״חַלַּת״ — רְבִיעִית שֶׁמֶן לְחַלָּה. ״נָזִיר״ — רְבִיעִית שֶׁמֶן לְנָזִיר. מְצוֹרָע — רְבִיעִית מַיִם לִמְצוֹרָע. ״שֶׁנִּפְסְלוּ״ — דִּתְנַן: וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַמַּשְׁקִין טְמֵאִין פּוֹסְלִין אֶת הַגְּוִיָּיה בִּרְבִיעִית.
human_translation: And five white The loaf of, a nazirite, and a leper, which were disqualified, on Shabbat. The loaf of, quarter of oil to the loaves A nazirite, quarter of oil for a nazirite, A leper, quarter water for a leper Which were disqualified, as we learned And all other ritually impure liquids disqualify the body of quarter
llm_translation: Five measures: "A dough of a Nazirite and a leper that were invalidated on Shabbat." "Dough" - a quarter-log of oil for dough. "Nazirite" - a quarter-log of oil for a Nazirite. "Leper" - a quarter-log of water for a leper. "That were invalidated" - as we learned: and the remainder of all liquids that are impure invalidate the dough in a quarter-log.

hebrew_text: ״בְּשַׁבָּת״ — דִּתְנַן: וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַמַּשְׁקִין — בִּרְבִיעִית, וּשְׁאָר כׇּל הַשּׁוֹפְכִים — בִּרְבִיעִית.
human_translation: On Shabbat, as we learned And all other liquids, a quarter and all waste water a quarter
llm_translation: "Talmudic text: 'On Shabbat' — as we learned: 'And the remainder of all liquids' — in a quarter-log, and 'the remainder of all pourers' — in a quarter-log."

hebrew_text: וְתוּ לֵיכָּא? וְהָאִיכָּא: מֵרְבִיעִית נוֹטְלִין לַיָּדַיִם לְאֶחָד וַאֲפִילּוּ לִשְׁנַיִם. בִּפְלוּגְתָּא לָא קָא מַיְירֵי.
human_translation: And are there no more But there is With a quarter one can wash the hands of one and even for two does not deal to a dispute,
llm_translation: And is there a contradiction? But there is a distinction: From the fourth cup one may take the cup into the hands for one person, and even for two. In a case of division, it does not apply.

hebrew_text: וְהָא אִיכָּא: הָיָה מֵבִיא פְּיָילֵי שֶׁל חֶרֶס וְנוֹתֵן לְתוֹכָהּ חֲצִי לוֹג מַיִם מִן הַכִּיּוֹר, וְרַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: רְבִיעִית. בִּפְלוּגְתָּא לָא קָא מַיְירֵי.
human_translation: But there is would bring an earthenware vessel [ pailei ] and place in it a half log of water from the basin and Rabbi Yehuda says a quarter does not deal to a dispute,
llm_translation: And there is a case: One would bring a clay jug and place within it half a log of water from the basin, and Rabbi Yehuda says: a quarter log. In a dispute they do not argue.

hebrew_text: וְהָאִיכָּא: כַּמָּה מַיִם נוֹתֵן לְתוֹכָהּ — כׇּל שֶׁהוּא, רַבִּי זַכַּאי אוֹמֵר: רְבִיעִית! בִּפְלוּגְתָּא לָא קָא מַיְירֵי. וְהָאִיכָּא מִקְוֶה! בַּר מֵהַהִיא, דְּבַטְּלוּהָ רַבָּנַן.
human_translation: But there is How much water must one place in Any quantity Rabbi Zakkai said: A quarter does not deal to a dispute. But there is a ritual bath, excludes that as the Sages annulled
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: And there is a case: How much water does one place inside it? - Whatever it is, Rabbi Zakkai says: A quarter! In a case of a half, they do not discuss. And there is a case of a mikveh! In the son of that case, the Rabbis annulled it.

hebrew_text: וְאֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא עַד שֶׁיֹּאכַל מִן הָעֲנָבִים כְּזַיִת וְכוּ׳. תַּנָּא קַמָּא לָא מְדַמֵּי לְהוֹן לְכׇל אִיסּוּרֵי נָזִיר לִשְׁתִיָּה, וְרַבִּי עֲקִיבָא, כֵּיוָן דִּכְתִיב ״וַעֲנָבִים לַחִים וִיבֵשִׁים לֹא יֹאכֵל״, מָה אֲכִילָה כְּזַיִת — אַף כֹּל אִיסּוּרִין כְּזַיִת.
human_translation: And he is liable only if he eats an olive-bulk of the grapes. The first tanna does not liken all the prohibitions of a nazirite to drinking And Rabbi Akiva since it is written: “Nor eat fresh grapes or dried” just as eating an olive-bulk, so too, all the prohibitions an olive-bulk.
llm_translation: "And he is not liable until he eats from the grapes like an olive and so forth. It was taught: The first Tanna does not compare them grapes to all the prohibitions of a Nazirite for drinking, but Rabbi Akiva, since it is written, 'He shall not eat moist or dried grapes,' just as eating grapes like an olive — so too all prohibitions are measured like an olive."

hebrew_text: [וְחַיָּיב עַל הַיַּיִן בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ כּוּ׳.] תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״וַעֲנָבִים לַחִים וִיבֵשִׁים לֹא יֹאכֵל״, לְחַיֵּיב עַל זֶה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ וְעַל זֶה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ. מִכָּאן אַתָּה דָּן לְכׇל אִיסּוּרִין שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה: מָה כָּאן שֶׁהוּא מִין אֶחָד, וְהֵן שְׁנֵי שֵׁמוֹת, וְחַיָּיב עַל זֶה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ וְעַל זֶה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ; אַף כֹּל שֶׁהוּא מִין אֶחָד, וְהֵן שְׁנֵי שֵׁמוֹת — חַיָּיב עַל זֶה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ וְעַל זֶה בִּפְנֵי עַצְמוֹ.
human_translation: And he is liable for wine by itself, The Sages taught: “Nor eat fresh grapes or dried” to render liable for this by itself and for that by itself, From here you derive to all prohibitions of the Torah: Just as here there is one type which are two names, and he is liable for this by itself and for that by itself, so too, all is one type and they are two names, one is liable for this by itself and for that by itself.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And liable for wine by itself etc." The Rabbis taught: "One may not eat moist grapes and dry grapes," for he is liable for each one separately. From here you can infer for all prohibitions in the Torah: Just as here it is one type, yet they have two names, and he is liable for each one separately; so too for every type, even though they have two names - he is liable for each one separately.

hebrew_text: לְאֵיתוֹיֵי חַמְרָא חַדְתָּא וְעִינְבֵי.
human_translation: to include new wine, and grapes.
llm_translation: For the purposes of new wine and grapes.

hebrew_text: אָמַר אַבָּיֵי: אָכַל חַרְצָן — לוֹקֶה שְׁתַּיִם. אָכַל זָג — לוֹקֶה שְׁתַּיִם. אָכַל חַרְצָן וְזָג — לוֹקֶה שָׁלֹשׁ. רָבָא אָמַר: אֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה אֶלָּא אַחַת, שֶׁאֵינוֹ לוֹקֶה אַלָּאו שֶׁבִּכְלָלוֹת.
human_translation: Abaye says: ate a grape seed is flogged twice, ate a grape skin he is flogged twice. ate a grape seed and a grape skin he is flogged three Rava says: He is flogged only once because one is not flogged for a general prohibition.
llm_translation: Abaye said: One who eats ḥarṣan is lashed twice. One who eats zag is lashed twice. One who eats ḥarṣan and zag is lashed three times. Rava said: He is only lashed once, as he is only lashed for what is included in it.

hebrew_text: מֵתִיב רַב פָּפָּא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: נָזִיר שֶׁהָיָה שׁוֹתֶה יַיִן כׇּל הַיּוֹם אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: ״אַל תִּשְׁתֶּה״ ״אַל תִּשְׁתֶּה״, וְהוּא שׁוֹתֶה — חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת. אָכַל עֲנָבִים לַחִים וִיבֵשִׁים, חַרְצַנִּים וְזַגִּים, וְסָחַט אֶשְׁכּוֹל שֶׁל עֲנָבִים וְשָׁתָה — לוֹקֶה חָמֵשׁ. אִי הָכִי — לִילְקֵי שֵׁשׁ, אַחַת עַל ״מִכׇּל אֲשֶׁר יַעֲשֶׂה״.
human_translation: Rav Pappa raised an objection Rabbi Eliezer says: A nazirite who was drinking wine all day is liable to only one said to him Do not drink, do not drink, and he drinking, he is liable for each and every one ate grapes and raisins, grape seeds and grape skins, and squeezed a cluster of grapes and drank he is flogged five If so, let him be flogged six one for “anything that is made
llm_translation: The Gemara raises an objection: Rav Papa raised an objection: Rabbi Eliezer says: A Nazirite who drank wine all day is liable only once. They said to him: "Do not drink," "Do not drink," and he drinks - he is liable for each and every one. If he ate moist grapes and dried grapes, grape seeds and grape skins, and squeezed a cluster of grapes and drank - he receives forty lashes. If so - he should receive sixty lashes, one for "from all that he may eat."

hebrew_text: תְּנָא וְשַׁיַּיר. מַאי שַׁיֵּיר דְּהַאי שַׁיַּיר? שַׁיַּיר ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״.
human_translation: taught and omitted What did he omit that he omitted this? He omitted “He shall not profane his word”
llm_translation: Tanna: And he left over. What is meant by "left over" that he left over? Left over "his word shall not fail."

hebrew_text: אִי מִשּׁוּם הַאי — לָאו שִׁיּוּרָא הוּא, כִּי קָתָנֵי מִידֵּי דְּלָא אִיתֵיהּ בְּדוּכְתָּא אַחֲרִיתִי, ״לֹא יַחֵל דְּבָרוֹ״ אִיתֵיהּ בִּנְדָרִים.
human_translation: If due to that is not an omission, as when teaches matters that are not elsewhere, “He shall not profane his word” is to vows
llm_translation: If because of this - it is not a valid objection, for it is taught from the hands of one who does not have another alternative, "he shall not profane his word" is found in vows.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבִינָא מִפַּרְזִקְיָא לְרַב אָשֵׁי: וְהָא שַׁיַּיר דְּבֵין הַבֵּינַיִים. אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: לָא תַּנְיָא מִידֵּי חָמֵשׁ. וְהָא
human_translation: Ravina from Parzakya said to Rav Ashi: But he omitted of in between. Rather, Rav Pappa said: did not teach anything five But
llm_translation: Ravina said to Rav Ashi from Pardesak: "But the leftover bread between the dishes." Rather, Rav Papa said: "Do not teach this from the hands of five."

hebrew_text: אוֹתְבֵיהּ חָמֵשׁ, וּמֵאַחַר דְּלָא תַּנְיָא חָמֵשׁ, מַאי טַעְמָא אוֹתְבֵיהּ? אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: אֲנָא סְבַרִי לָאו גְּמָרָא הִיא בִּידֵיהּ, וְהָדַר בֵּיהּ. וְלָא יָדַעְנָא דִּגְמָרָא הִיא בִּידֵיהּ, וְלָא הָדַר בֵּיהּ.
human_translation: raised objection to five and since is not taught five what is the reason raised objection to Rav Pappa said: I held it is not a tradition in hand and he retract But I did not know that is a tradition in hand and he did not
llm_translation: He wrote it five, and since he did not teach five, what is the reason he wrote it? Rav Papa said: I think it is not yet complete in his hands, and he will come back to it. And we do not know if it is complete in his hands, and he will not come back to it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר בֶּן עֲזַרְיָה אוֹמֵר כּוּ׳. אָמַר רַב יוֹסֵף: כְּמַאן מְתַרְגְּמִינַן ״מִפּוּרְצְנִין וְעַד עִיצּוּרִין״ — כְּרַבִּי יוֹסֵי.
human_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says: Rav Yosef said: In accordance with whose we translate From the seeds [ purtzanin ] to the skins [ itzurin ]? in accordance with Rabbi Yosei.
llm_translation: Rabbi Elazar ben Azariah says: "As it is stated." Rav Yosef said: In whose translation do we find "from breaches to breaches" - like Rabbi Yosei.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ סְתַם נְזִירוּת — שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם. גִּילַּח אוֹ שֶׁגִּילְּחוּהוּ לִסְטִים — סוֹתֵר שְׁלֹשִׁים יוֹם. נָזִיר שֶׁגִּילַּח בֵּין בְּזוּג בֵּין בְּתַעַר, אוֹ שֶׁסִּיפְסֵף כׇּל שֶׁהוּא — חַיָּיב.
human_translation: A naziriteship unspecified thirty days. shaved or if he was shaved by bandits [ listim ] negates thirty days a nazirite who shaved whether with scissors or with a razor, or pulled out [ sifsef ] any amount, is liable.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Mishnah: A regular Nazirite vow is for thirty days. If one shaves it, or if they shaved it with scissors, it annuls the thirty days. A Nazirite who shaves, whether with a razor or with scissors, or if they even just trimmed any amount, is liable.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: הַאי מַזְיָא מִלְּתַחַת רָבֵי אוֹ מִלְּעֵיל? לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ? לְנָזִיר שֶׁגִּילְּחוּהוּ לִיסְטִים וְשִׁיְּירוּ בּוֹ כְּדֵי לָכוֹף רֹאשׁוֹ לְעִיקָּרוֹ.
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before this hair grow from the bottom or from the top? What difference of a nazirite who was shaved by bandits but they left of it, enough to bend its end to its root.
llm_translation: The Gemara raises a question: Is this bandage placed from below Rabbi or from above? What practical difference does it make? For a Nazirite whose hair was shorn with scissors and left long enough to bend his head to its root.

hebrew_text: אִי אָמְרַתְּ מִלְּתַחַת רָבֵי — נְזִירוּת הָא שַׁקְלֵיהּ. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ מִלְּעֵיל רָבֵי — מַאי דְּאַקְדֵּישׁ הָא קָאֵים.
human_translation: If you say grows from the bottom, he has removed the naziriteship, But if you say that grows from the top, that which he sanctified still exists
llm_translation: If you say from below, Rabbi - it is the Nazirite vow that he took. Rather, if you say from above, Rabbi - what is it that he sanctified that stands here.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע מֵהָא אִינְבָּא חַיָּה דְּקָאֵים בְּעִיקְבָּא דְבִינְתָּא, וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ מִלְּתַחַת רָבֵי — בְּרֵישָׁא דְבִינְתָּא בָּעֵי לְמֵיקַם. לְעוֹלָם מִלְּתַחַת רָבֵי וְאַגַּב חַיּוּתָא נָחֵית וְאָזֵיל אִינְבָּא.
human_translation: Come hear from this live louse [ inba ], which is found in the root of the hair. And if it should enter your mind grows from the bottom, should be situated on the end of the hair, Actually, grows from the bottom, and because it is alive the louse continuously descends,
llm_translation: Come and hear: from this teaching it is inferred that a wild animal that stands in the corner of a house, and if your mind is inclined to the opinion of Rabbi — at the beginning of the house it needs to be established. Always, it should be established at the beginning of the house, and due to the animal's vitality, it will descend and go out.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע אִינְבָּא מֵתָה בְּרֵישָׁא דְבִינְתָּא, וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ מִלְּעֵיל רָבֵי — בְּעִיקְבָּא דְבִינְתָּא בָּעֵי לְמֵיקַם. הָתָם נָמֵי, מִשּׁוּם דְּלֵית בַּהּ חֵילָא שָׂרוֹגֵי שָׂרֵיגָא וְאָזֵיל.
human_translation: Come hear a dead louse is found on the end of the hair. And if it should enter your mind grows from on top, should be situated on the root of the hair. There too, because it has no strength it is caught and goes
llm_translation: Come and hear: Death entered at the beginning of understanding, and if it occurs to you to say that Rabbi's mind is superior — in the heel of understanding it is necessary to establish. There, too, it is stated, because it does not have the strength of the chain of the chain, and it goes away.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע מִבְּלוֹרִית דְּכוּשִׁיִּים, דְּבָתַר דִּמְגַדְּלִין לַהּ רָפְיָא מִלְּתַחַת. הָתָם נָמֵי, אַיְּידֵי דְּקָמְטָא הִיא מִשִּׁיכְבָא דְּרָפְיָא.
human_translation: Come hear from the long hair [ belorit ] of gentiles, As, after they braid it, it becomes loose underneath, There too, since it crumples from lies it becomes loose
llm_translation: Come and hear from the bilorit of the Cushites, that after they anoint her with oil from below. There, it is stated, since she is sweetened from the anointing of oil.

hebrew_text: תָּא שְׁמַע מִסְּקַרְתָּא, דְּרָפֵי עַמְרָא מִלְּתַחַת, וְתַנְיָא. וְתוּ: כַּד צָבְעִי סָבַיָּא דִּיקְנְהוֹן חָוְורָן
human_translation: Come hear the dye as the wool becomes loose underneath. And was taught And furthermore, when old men dye their beards, turn white
llm_translation: Come and hear from the marketplace, that they spread out the sheaves from below, and it was taught. And come and see: like the color of the sky they dyed them, the white ones.

hebrew_text: עִיקְבֵי נִימְהוֹן, שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ מִלְּתַחַת רָבֵי. שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ.
human_translation: the roots of their hair. learn from it that grows from the bottom, learn from it
llm_translation: Heel of the shoe, hear from it below Rabbi. Hear from it.

hebrew_text: וְאֶלָּא הָא דְּתַנְיָא: נָזִיר שֶׁגִּילְּחוּהוּ לִסְטִים, וְשִׁיְּירוּ בּוֹ כְּדֵי לָכוֹף רֹאשׁוֹ לְעִיקָּרוֹ — אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ מִלְּתַחַת רָבֵי, לִיסְתּוֹר! כְּגוֹן שֶׁגִּילְּחוּהוּ אַחַר מְלֹאת. וּמַנִּי — רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר הִיא, דְּאָמַר: כׇּל אַחַר מְלֹאת שִׁבְעָה סוֹתֵר.
human_translation: But this that is taught a nazirite who was shaved by bandits, and they left him enough to bend its end to its root, does not negate And if it should enter your mind grows from the bottom, let negate where they shaved him after the completion and whose It is Rabbi Eliezer, who says: any after the completion negates seven
llm_translation: And rather this that it was taught: A Nazirite whose hair was shorn with scissors, and they left in it enough hair to grasp his head at its root - he does not invalidate his vow. And if it enters your mind to investigate beneath Rabbi, to investigate! For example, if they shorn it after it had grown back. And who is the authority? Rabbi Eliezer, for he said: Any hair shorn after it has grown back sevenfold invalidates the vow.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמָא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר? יָלֵיף תִּגְלַחַת טׇהֳרָה מִתִּגְלַחַת טוּמְאָה. מַה תִּגְלַחַת טוּמְאָה שִׁבְעָה, אַף תִּגְלַחַת טׇהֳרָה — שִׁבְעָה.
human_translation: What is the reason of Rabbi Eliezer? derives the shaving of ritual purity from the shaving of impurity Just as shaving of impurity, seven so too shaving of purity; seven
llm_translation: What is the reason for Rabbi Eliezer? He derives the shaving of purity from the shaving of impurity. Just as the shaving of impurity is seven, so too the shaving of purity is seven.

hebrew_text: וְקִים לְהוּ לְרַבָּנַן כׇּל שִׁבְעָה יוֹמִין אָתְיָא מַזְיָיא כְּדֵי לָכוֹף רֹאשׁוֹ לְעִיקָּרוֹ.
human_translation: And the Sages, have an tradition every seven days hair grows enough to bend its end to its root.
llm_translation: And established for them the Rabbis, every seven days comes a messenger to heal his head to its root.

hebrew_text: נָזִיר שֶׁגִּילַּח בֵּין בְּתַעַר בֵּין בְּזוּג, אוֹ שֶׁסִּיפְסֵף כׇּל שֶׁהוּא — חַיָּיב. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״תַּעַר״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא תַּעַר. תָּלַשׁ, מֵירַט, סִיפְסֵף כׇּל שֶׁהוּא, מִנַּיִן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״קָדוֹשׁ יִהְיֶה גַּדֵּל פֶּרַע שְׂעַר רֹאשׁוֹ״, דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יֹאשִׁיָּה.
human_translation: a nazirite who shaved whether with scissors or with a razor, or pulled out any amount, liable. The Sages taught: “A razor I have only a razor; from where tore out, uprooted, pulled out any amount of The verse states: “He shall be holy, he shall let the locks of the hair of his head grow long” the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.
llm_translation: Nazarite who shaved whether with a razor or with scissors, or who trimmed any amount - liable. The Sages taught: "Razor," I only have a razor. Plucking, scraping, trimming any amount - from where? The Talmud teaches: "He shall be holy, he shall let the locks of the hair of his head grow," the words of Rabbi Yoshiyah.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יוֹנָתָן אוֹמֵר: ״תַּעַר״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא תַּעַר. מֵירַט, תָּלַשׁ, סִיפְסֵף כׇּל שֶׁהוּא — פָּטוּר. וְהָכְתִיב ״קָדוֹשׁ יִהְיֶה״! מֵימְרָא דְּאִם גִּילַּח לֵיהּ בְּתַעַר — קָאֵים עֲלֵיהּ בַּעֲשֵׂה וְלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yonatan says “razor” I have only a razor, tore out, uprooted, pulled out any amount he is exempt. But isn’t it written: “He shall be holy”? That is to say that if he shaved with a razor he stands for a positive mitzva and a prohibition.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yonatan says: "Ta'ar," I have only Ta'ar. From the moment he shaves, plucks, or cuts anything - he is exempt. And it is written, "He shall be holy!" This teaches that if he shaves with a razor - he is liable for a positive commandment and not a negative commandment.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא אִידַּךְ: ״תַּעַר״, אֵין לִי אֶלָּא תַּעַר. תָּלַשׁ, מֵירַט, סִיפְסֵף כׇּל שֶׁהוּא, מִנַּיִן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״לֹא יַעֲבוֹר עַל רֹאשׁוֹ״. וּמֵאַחַר שֶׁסּוֹפֵינוּ לְרַבּוֹת כֹּל דָּבָר, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״תַּעַר לֹא יַעֲבוֹר עַל רֹאשׁוֹ״?
human_translation: It is taught another “razor” I have only a razor; from where tore out, uprooted, pulled out any amount of The verse states: shall not come upon his head” And since we eventually include everything what the verse states: “A razor shall not come upon his head”?
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: "Ta'ar," I have nothing except Ta'ar. Talaḥ, Meirat, Sipsef, anything at all, from where? The Torah teaches: "He shall not pass over his head." And since we ultimately include everything, what is the Torah teaching by saying, "A razor shall not pass over his head"?

hebrew_text: לְפִי שֶׁלֹּא לָמַדְנוּ לְתִגְלַחַת הָאַחֲרוֹנָה שֶׁיִּהְיֶה בְּתַעַר. לְלַמְּדוֹ מִמְּצוֹרָע — אִי אֶפְשָׁר,
human_translation: because we have not learned that the last shaving, must be with a razor, It is impossible to learn from a leper
llm_translation: According to the fact that we did not learn for the shaving of the last hair that it should be with a razor. To learn it from a leper — it is impossible.

hebrew_text: שֶׁאֵין דָּנִין קַל מֵחָמוּר לְהַחְמִיר עָלָיו.
human_translation: as one does not derive a lenient from stringent to be stringent
llm_translation: That one does not judge leniently from a stringent matter to be stringent upon it.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ, הֲרֵי הוּא אוֹמֵר ״תַּעַר לֹא יַעֲבוֹר עַל רֹאשׁוֹ עַד מְלֹאת״, הַתּוֹרָה אָמְרָה: ״אַחַר מְלֹאת״ — לֹא תְּהֵא תִּגְלַחַת אֶלָּא בְּתַעַר.
human_translation: Rabbi says is not necessary as states: “A razor shall not come upon his head until the completion the Torah said: After the completion the shaving must be only with a razor.
llm_translation: Rabbi says: It is not necessary, as he says, "A razor shall not pass over his head until the completion," the Torah said: "After the completion" - one should only shave with a razor.

hebrew_text: וְהָכְתִיב ״תַּעַר לֹא יַעֲבוֹר עַל רֹאשׁוֹ״!
human_translation: But isn’t it written: “A razor shall not come upon his head”
llm_translation: And it is written, "A razor shall not pass over his head"!

hebrew_text: לַעֲבוֹר עָלָיו בִּשְׁנֵי לָאוִין.
human_translation: that he will violate two prohibitions for this
llm_translation: To pass over upon him in two prohibitions.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: לִלְקוֹת — בְּאַחַת, לְעַכֵּב — בִּשְׁתַּיִם, לִסְתּוֹר — אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר אֶלָּא בְּרוֹב רֹאשׁוֹ וּבְתַעַר.
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda says: to flogging, for one to invalidation, invalidated to two for negating negates only if most of his head. And with a razor.
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said: To wound — in one strike, to delay — in two, to close — one only closes with the majority of its head and its handle.

hebrew_text: בְּתַעַר — אִין, בְּמִידֵּי אַחֲרִינָא — לָא? וְהָקָתָנֵי: מִנַּיִן לְרַבּוֹת אֶת כׇּל הַמַּעֲבִירִין! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: כְּעֵין תַּעַר.
human_translation: with a razor, yes, with anything else, no, But isn’t it taught: From where to include all that remove Rather, say In the manner of a razor.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "B'ta'ar - ein, b'midei acharina - la? V'hakatanei: Minayin l'rabot et kol ha'ma'avirin! Ella eima: Ke'ein ta'ar." English translation: "With a razor - no, in other cases - yes? And it was taught: From where do we derive to include all those who pass through! Rather say: Like a razor."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: נָזִיר שֶׁתָּלַשׁ, מֵירַט, סִיפְסֵף כׇּל שֶׁהוּא — אֵינוֹ סוֹתֵר אֶלָּא בְּרוֹב רֹאשׁוֹ וּבְתַעַר. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן: כְּשֵׁם שֶׁשְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת מְעַכְּבוֹת בּוֹ, כָּךְ שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת סוֹתְרוֹת בּוֹ.
human_translation: This is also taught a nazirite who tore out, uprooted, pulled out any amount negates only if most of his head, and in a razor. Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: Just as two hairs invalidates his so too, two hairs negates his
llm_translation: It was taught in a baraita: If a nazirite's hair was interwoven, tangled, or matted in any way — it only invalidates the nazirite vow if it is the majority of his head and with a razor. Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: Just as two hairs prevent the hair from being considered interwoven, so too two hairs invalidate the hair from being considered interwoven.

hebrew_text: תְּנַן הָתָם: שְׁלֹשָׁה מְגַלְּחִין, וְתִגְלַחְתָּן מִצְוָה: נָזִיר, וּמְצוֹרָע, וּלְוִיִּם. וְכוּלָּן שֶׁגִּילְּחוּ שֶׁלֹּא בְּתַעַר, אוֹ שֶׁשִּׁיְּירוּ שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת — לֹא עָשׂוּ וְלֹא כְּלוּם.
human_translation: We learned there Three shave and their shaving a mitzva: A nazirite; and a leper, And Levites, And all of them, if they shaved with other than a razor, or if they left two hairs they have done nothing,
llm_translation: We learned there: Three types of individuals may shave, and you shall shave them as a commandment: a Nazirite, a leper, and Levites. And all of them, if they shaved not with a razor, or if they left two hairs — they have not fulfilled the commandment and have not completed it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: שְׁלֹשָׁה מְגַלְּחִין וְתִגְלַחְתָּן מִצְוָה. פְּשִׁיטָא! מַהוּ דְּתֵימָא מִשּׁוּם עַבּוֹרֵי שֵׂעָר הוּא, וַאֲפִילּוּ סָךְ נָשָׁא, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא.
human_translation: The Master said Three shave and their shaving a mitzva. is obvious; lest you say is due to removal of hair, and even one who applied a depilatory [ nasha ] teaches us that not
llm_translation: Master said: Three people shave and you shall shave them as a commandment. It is obvious! What is the reason you might say? Because it is related to removing hair growth, and even if a sack is used, it teaches us that it is not permissible.

hebrew_text: קָתָנֵי: וְכוּלָּן שֶׁגִּילְּחוּ שֶׁלֹּא בְּתַעַר. בִּשְׁלָמָא גַּבֵּי נָזִיר, כְּתִיב: ״תַּעַר לֹא יַעֲבוֹר עַל רֹאשׁוֹ״. וְגַבֵּי לְוִיִּם כְּתִיב: ״וְהֶעֱבִירוּ תַעַר עַל כׇּל בְּשָׂרָם״. אֶלָּא מְצוֹרָע בְּתַעַר, מְנָלַן?
human_translation: teaches: And all of them, if they shaved with other than a razor, Granted, with regard to a nazirite it is written: “A razor shall not come upon his head” And with regard to Levites it is written: “And let them cause a razor to pass over all their flesh” However, from where do we a leper with a razor
llm_translation: The text states: "And all of them who shaved, not with a razor. Regarding a Nazirite, it is written: 'No razor shall pass over his head.' And regarding Levites, it is written: 'And they shall pass a razor over all their flesh.' But a Metzora with a razor, from where do we derive?"

hebrew_text: וְכִי תֵימָא, תֵּיתֵי מִלְּוִיִּם: מָה לְוִיִּם שֶׁכֵּן טְעוּנִין תִּגְלַחַת, וְאֵין תִּגְלַחְתָּן אֶלָּא בְּתַעַר — אַף אֲנִי אָבִיא אֶת הַמְצוֹרָע שֶׁהוּא טָעוּן תִּגְלַחַת, וְאֵין תִּגְלַחְתּוֹ אֶלָּא בְּתַעַר. אִיכָּא לְמִיפְרַךְ: מָה לִלְוִיִּם שֶׁכֵּן טְעוּנִין תְּנוּפָה בְּגוּפָם, תֹּאמַר בִּמְצוֹרָע דְּלָא!
human_translation: And if you would say is derived from Levites, just as Levites require shaving and their shaving is only with a razor, so too, I will bring a leper, who requires shaving and his shaving only with a razor, can be refuted. What about Levites that they require waving of their bodies, you say with regard to a leper, who not
llm_translation: And if you say, let it be derived from Levites: Just as Levites require shaving, and their shaving is only with a razor - so too I will bring the leper who requires shaving, and his shaving is only with a razor. There is room to refute: Just as Levites require waving with their bodies, you would say in the case of a leper that it is not so!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא תֵּיתֵי מִנָּזִיר: מָה לְנָזִיר שֶׁכֵּן קׇרְבָּנוֹ טָעוּן לֶחֶם, תֹּאמַר בִּמְצוֹרָע דְּלָא. אֶלָּא מֵחֲדָא לָא אָתְיָא, תֵּיתֵי מִתַּרְוֵיהוֹן.
human_translation: Rather, derived from a nazirite, What about the nazirite that his offering requires bread. Will you say with regard to a leper, not Rather, not derived one let it be derived from the two of them.
llm_translation: Rather, let us bring proof from the case of a Nazirite: What about a Nazirite, whose sacrifice requires bread? You might say it is similar to a leper, who does not require bread. Rather, it comes from a different source; let us bring proof from their permission.

hebrew_text: מֵהֵי תֵּיתֵי? תֵּיתֵי מִלְּוִיִּם, מָה לִלְוִיִּם שֶׁכֵּן טְעוּנִין תְּנוּפָה בְּגוּפָן. נָזִיר יוֹכִיחַ, מָה לְנָזִיר שֶׁכֵּן קׇרְבָּנוֹ טָעוּן לֶחֶם. לְוִיִּם יוֹכִיחוּ.
human_translation: from which can it be derived? can be derived from Levites, what about Levites that they require waving of their bodies. a nazirite proves What about the nazirite that his offering requires bread, Levites prove
llm_translation: From where do we derive this? We derive it from the Levites. Just as the Levites require waving with their bodies, so too a Nazirite should prove his offering. A Nazirite should prove, just as his offering requires bread. The Levites should prove.

hebrew_text: וְחָזַר הַדִּין, לֹא רְאִי זֶה כִּרְאִי זֶה, וְלֹא רְאִי זֶה כִּרְאִי זֶה. הַצַּד הַשָּׁוֶה שֶׁבָּהֶם שֶׁהֵן טְעוּנִין תִּגְלַחַת, וְתִגְלַחְתָּן בְּתַעַר. אַף אֲנִי אָבִיא אֶת הַמְצוֹרָע שֶׁהוּא טָעוּן תִּגְלַחַת, וְתִגְלַחְתּוֹ בְּתַעַר.
human_translation: And the derivation has reverted The aspect of this is not like the aspect of that and the aspect of that is not like the aspect of this; The common denominator is that they require shaving and their shaving is with a razor. I will also bring the leper, who requires shaving, and his shaving with a razor.
llm_translation: The judgment returned, not seen this like seen this, and not seen this like seen this. The equal side in them that they require shaving, and you shall shave them with a razor. Also, I will bring the metzora who requires shaving, and you shall shave him with a razor.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא מִבַּרְנִישׁ לְרַב אָשֵׁי, וְלִיפְרוֹךְ: מָה לְהַצַּד הַשָּׁוֶה שֶׁבָּהֶן, שֶׁכֵּן
human_translation: Rava of Barnish said to Rav Ashi: And let us refute What Their common denominator is that
llm_translation: Rava said to Rav Ashe from Barnish, and to Pirok: What for the side that is equal in them, so.

hebrew_text: אֵין קׇרְבָּנוֹ בְּדַלּוּת. תֹּאמַר בִּמְצוֹרָע שֶׁקׇּרְבָּנוֹ בְּדַלּוּת!
human_translation: offering of poverty. you say with regard to the leper, whose offering of poverty,
llm_translation: There is no offering in poverty. You might say in the case of a leper, whose offering is in poverty!

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ רָבָא בַּר מְשַׁרְשְׁיָא לְרָבָא: הַאי תַּנָּא, מֵעִיקָּרָא אָמַר: לְלׇמְדוֹ מִמְּצוֹרָע אִי אֶפְשָׁר, שֶׁאֵין דָּנִין קַל מֵחָמוּר לְהַחְמִיר עָלָיו. וַהֲדַר אָמַר: נֵילַף מִדִּינָא, וּמִדִּינָא נָמֵי לָא יָלֵיף?
human_translation: Rava bar Mesharshiyya said to Rava: This tanna initially said, It is impossible to learn from a leper as one does not derive a lenient from stringent to be stringent And he then said: Let us derive of an inference and he did not derive from an inference either,
llm_translation: Rava said to Rava bar Mesharshaya: This Tanna, from the outset he said: to learn from the leper, is it possible? For we do not judge leniently from strictness to be stringent upon him. And then he said: Shall we derive from the law, and the law itself will not derive?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: הָהוּא — אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבָּנַן. הָא — אַלִּיבָּא דְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר. דִּתְנַן: וְאֵינוֹ חַיָּיב עַד שֶׁיְּלַקְּטֶנּוּ בְּתַעַר. רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ לִיקְּטוֹ בְּמַלְקֵט וּבְרָהִיטְנֵי — חַיָּיב.
human_translation: said to That in accordance with the Rabbis. this in accordance with Rabbi Eliezer, as we learned And liable only if he removes it with a razor. Rabbi Eliezer says: Even he removed it with tweezers or a plane [ rehitni ] he is liable.
llm_translation: He said to him: That one - according to the opinion of the sages. This one - according to the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer. As we learned: "And he is not liable until he gathers it with a cutting tool." Rabbi Eliezer says: Even if they gathered it with a sickle or with their hands - he is liable.

hebrew_text: מַאי טַעְמַיְיהוּ דְּרַבָּנַן? דְּתַנְיָא: ״זְקָנוֹ״ מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר? לְפִי שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וּפְאַת זְקָנָם לֹא יְגַלֵּחוּ״, יָכוֹל אֲפִילּוּ מְצוֹרָע כֵּן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״זְקָנוֹ״.
human_translation: What is the reason of the Rabbis; As it is taught what the verse states: “His beard”? because it is stated “Neither shall they shave off the corners of their beards” might the same also a leper, the verse states: “His beard,”
llm_translation: What is the reason of the Sages? For it was taught: "His beard" - what is the teaching to say? Because it is stated, "And they shall not shave the corner of their beard," one might think even a leper should not shave - the teaching is to say: "His beard."

hebrew_text: וּמְנָלַן דִּבְתַעַר? דְּתַנְיָא: ״וּפְאַת זְקָנָם לֹא יְגַלֵּחוּ״, יָכוֹל אֲפִילּוּ גִּילְּחוֹ בְּמִסְפָּרַיִם יְהֵא חַיָּיב, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְלֹא תַשְׁחִית״.
human_translation: And from where do we that with a razor? as it is taught “Neither shall they shave off the corners of their beards” might be liable even if he shaved with scissors. The verse states, “Neither shall you destroy
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And from where do we derive that it is prohibited? For it was taught: "But the corner of their beards you shall not destroy." One might think that even if he destroyed it with scissors, he would be liable. Therefore, the Scripture teaches: "And you shall not destroy." English translation: And from where do we derive that it is prohibited? For it was taught: "But the corner of their beards you shall not destroy." One might think that even if he destroyed it with scissors, he would be liable. Therefore, the Scripture teaches: "And you shall not destroy."

hebrew_text: יָכוֹל לִיקְּטוֹ בְּמַלְקֵט וּבְרָהִיטְנֵי יְהֵא חַיָּיב, תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וּפְאַת זְקָנָם לֹא יְגַלֵּחוּ״. הָא כֵּיצַד? אֵיזֶהוּ גִּילּוּחַ שֶׁיֵּשׁ בּוֹ הַשְׁחָתָה — הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: זֶה תַּעַר.
human_translation: might even he removed it with tweezers or planes he be liable. The verse states: “Neither shall they shave off the corners of their beards” How so? What is shaving that involves destruction? You must say this is a razor.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: One might have thought that one is liable for gathering with a gatherer and with a reaper, therefore the Scripture teaches: "And they shall not shave the corner of their beard." How so? What is the type of shaving that involves destruction? One would say: this is a razor.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי? דִּילְמָא לְעוֹלָם אֲפִילּוּ לִיקְּטוֹ בְּמַלְקֵט וּבְרָהִיטְנֵי נָמֵי מִצְוָה קָעָבֵיד, וְהָא קָאָתֵי לְאַשְׁמוֹעִינַן דַּאֲפִילּוּ בְּתַעַר לָא מִיחַיַּיב עֲלֵיהּ!
human_translation: From where Perhaps actually removed it with tweezers or a plane he also performs the mitzva and this is coming to teach us that even with a razor he is not liable for
llm_translation: From where? Perhaps, forever, even if he gathers with a gatherer and with a reaper of mitzvah, he is honored, and this comes to teach us that even with a razor, he is not liable upon it!

hebrew_text: אָמְרִי: אִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ כִּי עָבֵיד נָמֵי בְּמַלְקֵט וּבְרָהִיטְנֵי שַׁפִּיר דָּמֵי, לִישְׁתּוֹק קְרָא מִינֵּיהּ, וַאֲנָא אָמֵינָא: וּמָה גַּבֵּי נָזִיר דְּאִיסּוּרָא קָא עָבֵיד, אֲפִילּוּ הָכִי מִחַיַּיב, הָכָא דְּמִצְוָה — לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?
human_translation: They say If it should enter your mind that if performs with tweezers or a plane too, well let the verse be silent from And say And just as with regard to a nazirite, who performs a transgression even so, deemed liable here where a mitzva, not all the more so
llm_translation: They said: If it enters your mind that he is doing something prohibited by gleaning and by gathering, it is better to let the verse be uprooted, and I say: And what about a Nazirite who is performing a prohibition, even so he is liable, here where it is a commandment - all the more so?

hebrew_text: וְתוּ, אִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ כִּי עָבֵיד בְּמַלְקֵט וּבְרָהִיטְנֵי — מִצְוָה קָא עָבֵיד, מִדְּלָא כְּתִיב ״תַּעַר״, כְּרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ, דְּאָמַר:
human_translation: And furthermore, if it should enter your mind when he performs with tweezers or a plane he performs a mitzva, from razor is not written in accordance with Reish Lakish, who says
llm_translation: And come, if it enters your mind that one who gathers and threshes is performing a mitzvah, since it is not written "a sword," as Reish Lakish said:

hebrew_text: כׇּל מָקוֹם שֶׁאַתָּה מוֹצֵא עֲשֵׂה וְלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה, אִם אַתָּה יָכוֹל לְקַיֵּים אֶת שְׁנֵיהֶם — מוּטָב, וְאִם לָאו — יָבֹא עֲשֵׂה וְיִדְחֶה אֶת לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה.
human_translation: Any place where you find a positive and a prohibition if you can to fulfill both, preferable; and if that is not positive will come and override the prohibition.
llm_translation: Every place that you find "do" and "do not do," if you are able to fulfill both - it is better. But if not, let the "do" come and override the "do not do."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר מַאי טַעְמָא? יָלֵיף מֵ״רֹאשׁוֹ״. דְּתַנְיָא: ״רֹאשׁוֹ״, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר? לְפִי שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר גַּבֵּי נָזִיר ״תַּעַר לֹא יַעֲבוֹר עַל רֹאשׁוֹ״, יָכוֹל אַף נָזִיר מְצוֹרָע כֵּן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״רֹאשׁוֹ״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Eliezer, what is reason? derives from his head As it is taught Why does the verse state: “His head,” because it is stated with regard to a nazirite: “No razor shall come upon his head” might the same also a nazirite a leper, the verse states: “His head,”
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer, what is the reason? He derives it from "rosho." As it was taught: "Rosh," what is the teaching to say? Because it is stated regarding a Nazirite, "A razor shall not pass over his head," one might think the same applies to a Nazirite who is a leper — therefore, the teaching states: "His head."

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי? דִּלְמָא לְעוֹלָם אֲפִילּוּ לִיקְּטוֹ בְּמַלְקֵט וּבְרָהִיטְנֵי — מִצְוָה קָעָבֵיד. וְכִי תֵּימָא: תַּעַר לְמָה לִי — לְמֵימְרָא דַּאֲפִילּוּ בְּתַעַר. סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ אָמֵינָא, הוֹאִיל וְגַבֵּי נָזִיר כִּי עָבֵיד בְּתַעַר מִיחַיַּיב, גַּבֵּי מְצוֹרָע נָמֵי לִיחַיַּיב, קָא מַשְׁמַע לַן דְּלָא!
human_translation: from where Perhaps even actually removed it with tweezers or a plane he performs a mitzva. And if you would say: why do I a razor, That is to say that even with a razor. it might enter your mind to say since with regard to a nazirite, when performs with a razor liable with regard to a leper also be liable teaches us not
llm_translation: From where? Perhaps to say always even to gather with a sickle and with a reaping hook — a mitzvah is honored. And if you say: Why do I need a razor — to say that even with a razor. Your mind has come to say, since regarding a Nazirite when he does with a razor he is liable, regarding a leper he is also liable, it teaches us that it is not so!

hebrew_text: אִי סָלְקָא דַּעְתָּךְ כִּי עָבֵיד בְּמַלְקֵט וּבְרָהִיטְנֵי מִצְוָה קָעָבֵיד, מִדְּלָא כְּתַב ״תַּעַר״, כְּרֵישׁ לָקִישׁ.
human_translation: If it should enter your mind when performs with tweezers or a plane he performs a mitzva, from did not write: Razor, in accordance with Reish Lakish
llm_translation: If it comes to your mind that he performed the action with a sickle and with the handle of a commandment, he has performed the action, since he did not write "a sword," as Reish Lakish.

hebrew_text: וְרַבָּנַן הַאי ״רֹאשׁוֹ״, מַאי דָּרְשִׁי בֵּיהּ? מִיבְּעֵי לְהוּ לְמִידְחֵי לָאו דְּהַקָּפָה. דְּתַנְיָא: ״לֹא תַקִּיפוּ פְּאַת רֹאשְׁכֶם״, יָכוֹל אַף מְצוֹרָע כֵּן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״רֹאשׁוֹ״.
human_translation: And the Rabbis, this “His head,” what do they learn from it? They require to override prohibition of rounding As it is taught “You shall not round the corners of your heads” might the same also a leper, the verse states: “His head,”
llm_translation: The sages asked about this "head," what did he expound in it? He wanted to teach them not to round off the corners of the scalp. As it was taught: "Do not round off the corners of your head," one might think the same applies to a leper — therefore the verse states: "his head."

hebrew_text: לְמָה לִי לְמִכְתַּב ״רֹאשׁוֹ״? וְתִיפּוֹק לֵיהּ מִ״זְּקָנוֹ״. דְּתַנְיָא: ״זְקָנוֹ״, מָה תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר? לְפִי שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר ״וּפְאַת זְקָנָם לֹא יְגַלֵּחוּ״, יָכוֹל אַף מְצוֹרָע כֵּן — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״זְקָנוֹ״.
human_translation: Why do I to write: “His head”? And let one derive from “his beard” As it is taught Why does the verse state: “His beard”? because states “Neither shall they shave off the corners of their beards” might the same also a leper. the verse states: “His beard.”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Why do I need the word "rosho"? And derive from it "zekano." For it was taught: "Zekano," what does the Talmud say? Because it is stated, "And they shall not shave the corner of their beard," one might think the same applies to a leper — the Talmud teaches: "Zekano." English translation: Why do I need the word "his head"? And derive from it "his beard." For it was taught: "His beard," what does the Talmud say? Because it is stated, "And they shall not shave the corner of their beard," one might think the same applies to a leper — the Talmud teaches: "His beard."

hebrew_text: לְמָה לִי לְמִכְתַּב ״רֹאשׁוֹ״ וּלְמָה לִי לְמִכְתַּב ״זְקָנוֹ״? צְרִיכִי, דְּאִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״זְקָנוֹ״ וְלָא כְּתַב ״רֹאשׁוֹ״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: הַקָּפַת כׇּל הָרֹאשׁ לֹא שְׁמָהּ הַקָּפָה. לְהָכִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״רֹאשׁוֹ״.
human_translation: why do I to write: “His head,” and why do I to write: “His beard”? are necessary. As, had the Merciful One written “His beard,” and not written: “His head,” I would say the rounding of the entire head, not called rounding. For this the Merciful One writes: “His head,”
llm_translation: "Why do I need the writing of 'his head' and why do I need the writing of 'his beard'? I need it, for if the Merciful One had written 'his beard' and not written 'his head,' I would have said: the wrapping of the entire head is not called wrapping. Therefore, the Merciful One wrote 'his head'."

hebrew_text: וְאִי כְּתַב ״רֹאשׁוֹ״ וְלָא כְּתַב ״זְקָנוֹ״, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: מַשְׁמַע תַּרְתֵּי: דְּאָתֵי עֲשֵׂה וְדָחֵי אֶת לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה, וּמַשְׁמַע דְּהַקָּפַת כׇּל הָרֹאשׁ שְׁמָהּ הַקָּפָה. וְאַכַּתִּי בְּתַעַר מְנָלַן? לְהָכִי כְּתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״זְקָנוֹ״.
human_translation: And had written “His head,” and not written: “His beard,” I would say teaches two that a positive comes and overrides a prohibition. And it teaches that rounding the entire head is called rounding. And still, from where do we with a razor? For this the Merciful One wrote: “His beard,”
llm_translation: Talmudic text: If he wrote "his head" and did not write "his beard," I would say: It implies two things: that he comes to perform and to push aside a prohibition, and it implies that the covering of the entire head is called "head." But where do we derive this from? Therefore, the Merciful One wrote "his beard."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר, דְּאָתֵי עֲשֵׂה וְדָחֵי אֶת לֹא תַעֲשֶׂה מְנָלֵיהּ? יָלֵיף מִ״גְּדִילִים״. דְּתַנְיָא: ״לֹא תִלְבַּשׁ שַׁעַטְנֵז״,
human_translation: And Rabbi Eliezer, from where does he that a positive will come and override a prohibition? derives from fringes. As it is taught “You shall not wear diverse kinds
llm_translation: Rabbi Eliezer, when he comes to a case of a positive commandment conflicting with a negative commandment, how does he resolve it? He derives it from "g'dilim." For it was taught: "Do not wear sha'atnez."

hebrew_text: הָא ״גְּדִילִים תַּעֲשֶׂה לָּךְ״ מֵהֶם.
human_translation: “You shall make for yourself fringes” from them,
llm_translation: This, "You shall make tassels for yourself," from them.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר: וְכוּלָּם שֶׁגִּילְּחוּ שֶׁלֹּא בְּתַעַר, אוֹ שֶׁשִּׁיְּירוּ שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת — לֹא עָשׂוּ וְלֹא כְלוּם. אָמַר רַב אַחָא בְּרֵיהּ דְּרַב אִיקָא: זֹאת אוֹמֶרֶת, רוּבּוֹ כְּכוּלּוֹ מִדְּאוֹרָיְיתָא.
human_translation: The Master said And all of them, if they shaved with other than a razor, or if they left two hairs they have done nothing. Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said: That is to say The majority of like all of it, by Torah law.
llm_translation: Master said: And all of them that they plucked out not with a razor, or that they left two hairs - they did not do and they did not fulfill. Rav Acha, son of Rav Ika, said: This means, the majority is like the entirety from the Torah.

hebrew_text: מִמַּאי — מִדְּגַלִּי רַחֲמָנָא גַּבֵּי נָזִיר ״בְּיוֹם הַשְּׁבִיעִי יְגַלְּחֶנּוּ״ — הָכָא הוּא דְּעַד דְּאִיכָּא כּוּלּוֹ. הָא בְּעָלְמָא: רוּבּוֹ כְּכוּלּוֹ.
human_translation: From where from that the Merciful One revealed with regard to a nazirite: “On the seventh day he shall shave it” it is here until there is of all of it, in general the majority of like all of it.
llm_translation: From what — from the flag of mercy regarding a Nazirite. "On the seventh day he shall shave it" — here, it is until there is all of it. That is in general: most of it is like all of it.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רַבִּי יוֹסֵי בְּרַבִּי חֲנִינָא: הַאי בְּנָזִיר טָמֵא כְּתִיב! מַחֲכוּ עֲלַהּ בְּמַעְרְבָא: מִכְּדֵי נָזִיר טָמֵא דִּבְתַעַר מְנָלַן — מִנָּזִיר טָהוֹר יָלֵיף, לַיְתֵי נָזִיר טָהוֹר וְלֵילַף מִנָּזִיר טָמֵא: מָה טָמֵא כִּי שַׁיַּיר שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת — וְלָא כְּלוּם עֲבַד, הָכָא נָמֵי, כִּי שַׁיַּיר שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת — וְלָא כְּלוּם עֲבַד.
human_translation: Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, objects to this This is written with regard to a ritually impure nazirite, They laughed at in the West, After all, from where do we an impure nazirite with a razor? derived from a pure nazirite. let a pure nazirite come and derive from an impure nazirite: Just as an impure if he leaves two hairs he has done nothing, here too, leaves two hairs he has done nothing.
llm_translation: Challenges him Rabbi Yosei son of Rabbi Chanina: "This one, in a Nazirite, it is written! They waited for him in the west: From where do we derive that a Nazirite who shaved brings a sin offering — from a pure Nazirite he shall learn, to come a pure Nazirite and derive from a defiled Nazirite: Just as a defiled one, when he leaves two hairs — and did not complete, he has done nothing, here too, when he leaves two hairs — and did not complete, he has done nothing."

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי אַבָּיֵי: נָזִיר שֶׁגִּילַּח וְשִׁיֵּיר שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת, צָמַח רֹאשׁוֹ וְחָזַר וְגִילְּחָן, מַהוּ? מִי מְעַכְּבִי אוֹ לָא?
human_translation: Abaye raised a dilemma: a nazirite who shaved and left two hairs, his head grew and he again shaved, what is Do invalidate or not?
llm_translation: Ba'ei Abaye: Nazir shegilach veshiyer shetay se'arav, tzamach rosho vechazar vegilchan, mahu? Mi me'akvei o lo?

hebrew_text: בָּעֵי רָבָא: נָזִיר שֶׁגִּילַּח וְהִנִּיחַ שְׁתֵּי שְׂעָרוֹת, וְגִילַּח אַחַת וְנָשְׁרָה אַחַת, מַהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב אַחָא מִדִּיפְתִּי לְרָבִינָא: גִּילַּח שַׂעֲרָה שַׂעֲרָה קָא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְרָבָא?
human_translation: Rava raised a dilemma: a nazirite who shaved and left two hairs, and shaved one and one fell out what is Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina: Is Rava raising a dilemma shave hair by hair?
llm_translation: Ba'ei Rava: Nazir shegilach vehinich shetay se'arot, vegilachachat venashrahachat, mah? Amar lei Rav Acha midifti lerabina: Gilach sa'arah sa'arah ka mibe'ei lei leRava? Rava asked: If a Nazir shaved and left two hairs, then shaved one and pulled out one, what is the ruling? Rav Acha said to Ravina: Does he need to shave hair by hair according to Rava?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אֵימָא: נָשְׁרָה אַחַת וְגִילַּח אַחַת, מַהוּ? אֲמַר לֵיהּ: גִּילּוּחַ אֵין כָּאן, שֵׂעָר אֵין כָּאן. אִי שֵׂעָר אֵין כָּאן — גִּילּוּחַ יֵשׁ כָּאן! הָכִי קָאָמַר: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁשֵּׂעָר אֵין כָּאן, מִצְוַת גִּילּוּחַ אֵין כָּאן.
human_translation: Rather, say one fell out and he shaved one, what is said to him: there is no shaving here; there is no hair here. If there is no hair here, there is shaving here, This is what he said: Even though there is no hair here, there is no mitzva of shaving here,
llm_translation: Rather say: If one hair fell out and one was plucked out, what is the law? He said to him: Plucking is not here, hair is not here. If hair is not here - plucking is here! This is what he is saying: Even though there is no hair here, the obligation of plucking is not here.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נָזִיר חוֹפֵף וּמְפַסְפֵּס, אֲבָל לֹא סוֹרֵק.
human_translation: A nazirite may shampoo [ ḥofef ] and separate [ mefaspes ] However, he may not comb
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: A Nazir shaves with a razor and plucks with tweezers, but does not use a depilatory.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ חוֹפֵף וּמְפַסְפֵּס, מַנִּי? רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא, דְּאָמַר: דָּבָר שֶׁאֵין מִתְכַּוֵּין — מוּתָּר. אֲבָל לֹא סוֹרֵק — אֲתָאן לְרַבָּנַן.
human_translation: Who is may shampoo and separate It is Rabbi Shimon, who says: An unintentional act is permitted. However, he may not comb we have come to the Rabbis.
llm_translation: Gemar chofef u'mefapsef, mani? Rabbi Shimon hi, d'amar: davar she'ein mitkavein - mutar. Aval lo sorak - atan l'rabbannan.

hebrew_text: רֵישָׁא רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן וְסֵיפָא רַבָּנַן? אָמַר רַבָּה: כּוּלָּהּ רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן הִיא, כׇּל הַסּוֹרֵק — לְהָסִיר נִימִין מְדוּלְדָּלוֹת מִתְכַּוֵּין.
human_translation: the first clause Rabbi Shimon and the latter clause the Rabbis. Rabba said: entire is Rabbi Shimon, anyone who combs intends to remove stray hairs,
llm_translation: Beginning: Rabbi Shimon and the end: the Rabbis? Rabah said: The entire statement is attributed to Rabbi Shimon, anyone who rinses - to remove the droplets that are scattered.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ רַבִּי יִשְׁמָעֵאל אוֹמֵר: לֹא יָחוֹף בַּאֲדָמָה, מִפְּנֵי שֶׁמַּשֶּׁרֶת אֶת הַשֵּׂעָר.
human_translation: Rabbi Yishmael says: may not shampoo with earth because causes the hair to fall out.
llm_translation: The Mishnah: Rabbi Yishmael says: One should not scrape the ground, because it serves the hair.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיבַּעְיָא לְהוּ: ״מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהִיא מַשֶּׁרֶת אֶת הַשֵּׂעָר״ תְּנַן, אוֹ דִּלְמָא: ״מִפְּנֵי הַמַּשֶּׁרֶת״ תְּנַן? לְמַאי נָפְקָא מִינַּהּ?
human_translation: A dilemma was raised before we learn: Because it removes hair, or do we perhaps learn: Because of that which removes What difference
llm_translation: Gemara inquires: "Is it because she is serving the hair?" Did we learn, or perhaps: "Is it because of the serving?" What is derived from it?

hebrew_text: כְּגוֹן דְּאִיכָּא אֲדָמָה דְּלָא מַתְּרָא. אִי אָמְרַתְּ ״מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהִיא מַשֶּׁרֶת״ תְּנַן, הֵיכָא דְּיָדְעִינַן דְּלָא מַתְּרָא — שַׁפִּיר. אֶלָּא אִי אָמְרַתְּ ״מִפְּנֵי הַמַּשֶּׁרֶת״ — כְּלָל כְּלָל לָא. תֵּיקוּ.
human_translation: where there is earth that does not remove If you say we learned Because it removes where we know that it does not remove it is fine However, if you say Because of that which removes not at all, shall stand
llm_translation: For example, where there is soil that is not seen. If you say, "because it is serving," we learned: where we know that it is not seen - it is fine. But if you say, "because of the service" - it is a general principle, not a specific one. Let it stand undecided.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ נָזִיר שֶׁהָיָה שׁוֹתֶה יַיִן כׇּל הַיּוֹם — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: ״אַל תִּשְׁתֶּה״ ״אַל תִּשְׁתֶּה״, וְהוּא שׁוֹתֶה — חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת. הָיָה מְגַלֵּחַ כׇּל הַיּוֹם — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: ״אַל תְּגַלֵּחַ״ ״אַל תְּגַלֵּחַ״, וְהוּא מְגַלֵּחַ — חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת. הָיָה מִטַּמֵּא לְמֵתִים כׇּל הַיּוֹם — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אָמְרוּ לוֹ: ״אַל תִּטַּמֵּא״ ״אַל תִּטַּמֵּא״, וְהוּא מִטַּמֵּא — חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת.
human_translation: A nazirite who was drinking wine all day is liable only one said to him Do not drink, do not drink, and he drink, he is liable for each and every kept shaving all day, he is liable only one they said to him: Do not shave, do not shave, and he shaves, he is liable for each and every became ritually impure from a corpse all day, he is liable only one they said to him: Do not become impure, do not become impure, and he become impure, he is liable for each and every
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: A Nazirite who drank wine all day - he is only liable for one sin offering. They said to him: "Do not drink, do not drink," and he drinks - he is liable for each and every one. If he was shaving all day - he is only liable for one. They said to him: "Do not shave, do not shave," and he shaves - he is liable for each and every one. If he was becoming impure through contact with the dead all day - he is only liable for one. They said to him: "Do not become impure, do not become impure," and he becomes impure - he is liable for each and every one.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אִיתְּמַר, אָמַר רַבָּה אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: מִקְרָא מָלֵא דִּבֵּר הַכָּתוּב: ״לֹא יִטַּמָּא״. כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר ״לֹא יָבֹא״ — לְהַזְהִירוֹ עַל הַטּוּמְאָה, לְהַזְהִירוֹ עַל הַבִּיאָה. אֲבָל טוּמְאָה וְטוּמְאָה — לֹא.
human_translation: was stated. Rabba said Rav Huna said: The Torah stated a categorical verse: “He shall not become impure When states: “He shall not come to warn him with regard to impurity to warn him with regard to entering However, impurity and impurity not
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara itmar, amar Rabba amar Rav Huna: mikra malei diber haktuv: "lo yitama". Keshhu omer "lo yavo" - lehazhiro al hatum'ah, lehazhiro al habi'ah. Aval tum'ah vetum'ah - lo. English translation: It was stated in the Gemara, Rabba said in the name of Rav Huna: The verse speaks in full: "He shall not become impure." When it says "he shall not come" - to warn him regarding impurity, to warn him regarding entry. But impurity and impurity - no.

hebrew_text: וְרַב יוֹסֵף אָמַר: הָאֱלֹהִים! אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: אֲפִילּוּ טוּמְאָה וְטוּמְאָה. דְּאָמַר רַב הוּנָא: נָזִיר שֶׁהָיָה עוֹמֵד בְּבֵית הַקְּבָרוֹת, וְהוֹשִׁיטוּ לוֹ מֵתוֹ וּמֵת אַחֵר וְנָגַע בּוֹ — חַיָּיב. אַמַּאי? הָא מִיטַּמֵּא וְקָאֵים! אֶלָּא לָאו שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ, אָמַר רַב הוּנָא: אֲפִילּוּ טוּמְאָה וְטוּמְאָה.
human_translation: And Rav Yosef says By God! Rav Huna says even impurity and impurity As Rav Huna says: a nazirite who was standing in a cemetery, and they extended his corpse, to him, and a different corpse and he touched it, liable. why has already become impure and is standing Rather, isn’t it conclude from Rav Huna said even impurity and impurity
llm_translation: Rav Yosef said: "God!" Rav Huna said: "Even if he becomes impure and impure." For Rav Huna said: "A Nazirite who was standing in a cemetery, and his dead relative and another dead person were brought to him, and he touched them — he is liable. Why? Because he becomes impure and he remains in that state!" Rather, it is not a valid deduction. Rav Huna said: "Even if he becomes impure and impure."

hebrew_text: אֵיתִיבֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: כֹּהֵן שֶׁהָיָה לוֹ מֵת מוּנָּח עַל כְּתֵיפוֹ, וְהוֹשִׁיטוּ לוֹ מֵתוֹ וּמֵת אַחֵר וְנָגַע בּוֹ, יָכוֹל יְהֵא חַיָּיב — תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר: ״וְלֹא יְחַלֵּל״, בְּמִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְחוּלָּל, יָצָא זֶה שֶׁהוּא מְחוּלָּל וְעוֹמֵד.
human_translation: Abaye raised an objection to a priest who had a corpse placed on his shoulder, and they extended his corpse, to him, and a different corpse and he touched it, might he should be liable the verse states, “And he shall not profane to one who is not profaned, excluding this one who is profaned and standing
llm_translation: He raised an objection to him, Abaye: A priest who had a dead person lying on his shoulder, and they handed him his dead relative, and another person died and touched him, one might think he should be liable - the Scripture teaches: "And he shall not defile himself," with one who is not defiled, this one who is defiled and standing has fulfilled his obligation.

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: וְתִיקְשֵׁי לָךְ מַתְנִיתִין, דִּתְנַן: הָיָה מִיטַּמֵּא לְמֵתִים כׇּל הַיּוֹם — אֵינוֹ חַיָּיב אֶלָּא אַחַת. אָמְרוּ לוֹ ״אַל תִּטַּמֵּא״ ״אַל תִּטַּמֵּא״ — חַיָּיב עַל כׇּל אַחַת וְאַחַת. וְאַמַּאי? הָא מִיטַּמֵּא וְקָאֵים!
human_translation: said to him: But the mishna should pose a difficulty for you. As we learned became ritually impure from corpses all day, he is liable only one If they said to him: Do not become impure, do not become impure, he is liable for each and every But why He has already become impure and is standing
llm_translation: He said to him: And difficult for you are the Mishnayot, for we learned: If one was defiled by contact with the dead all day - he is liable only once. They said to him, "Do not become defiled," "Do not become defiled" - he is liable for each and every one. And why? Because he becomes defiled and stands!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא קַשְׁיָא אַהֲדָדֵי! לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן — בְּחִיבּוּרִין. כָּאן — שֶׁלֹּא בְּחִיבּוּרִין.
human_translation: Rather, a difficulty for each other. not difficult, here to a concurrent there to not a concurrent
llm_translation: Rather, the question is difficult! It is not difficult: here - in the case of combined entities. Here - not in the case of combined entities.

hebrew_text: וְטוּמְאָה בְּחִיבּוּרִין דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא? הָא אָמַר רַב יִצְחָק בַּר יוֹסֵף אָמַר רַבִּי יַנַּאי: לֹא אָמְרוּ טוּמְאָה בְּחִיבּוּרִין אֶלָּא לִתְרוּמָה וְקָדָשִׁים, אֲבָל לְנָזִיר וְעוֹשֵׂה פֶסַח — לָא. וְאִי אָמְרַתְּ דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא, מַאי שְׁנָא?
human_translation: And concurrent impurity, by Torah law? Didn’t Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef say Rabbi Yannai said: They stated concurrent impurity only with regard to teruma and consecrated However, with regard to a nazirite, and one who performs the Paschal offering, not And if you say by Torah law, what is different
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And is she impure in regards to mixtures by Torah law? This is what Rav Yitzchak bar Yosef said in the name of Rabbi Yannai: They only said she is impure in regards to mixtures for terumah and holy items, but not for a Nazirite or one who observes Passover. And if you say it is by Torah law, what is the difference?

hebrew_text: כָּאן, בְּחִיבּוּרֵי אָדָם בְּאָדָם. כָּאן, בְּחִיבּוּרֵי אָדָם בְּמֵת.
human_translation: Here, concurrent person with person. there to concurrent a person with a corpse.
llm_translation: Here, in the joining of man with man. Here, in the joining of man with the deceased.

hebrew_text: אֲבָל טוּמְאָה וְטוּמְאָה לָא, דְּהָא מִיטַּמֵּא וְקָאֵים.
human_translation: However, impurity and impurity not as he has already become impure and is standing
llm_translation: But impurity and impurity no, for it becomes impure and stands.

hebrew_text: טוּמְאָה וּבִיאָה נָמֵי, הָא מִיטַּמֵּא וְקָאֵי! אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: כָּאן בְּבַיִת,
human_translation: impurity and entering likewise, he has already become impure and is standing Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Here, into a house
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Tum'ah uvi'ah namei, ha mitamei ve'kaei! Amar Rabbi Yochanan: Kan bebayit, English translation: Impurity and intercourse also, this one becomes impure and stands! Rabbi Yochanan said: Here in the house,

hebrew_text: כָּאן בְּשָׂדֶה.
human_translation: there, in a field.
llm_translation: Here in the field.

hebrew_text: בְּבַיִת נָמֵי, כֵּיוָן דְּאַעֵיל יְדֵיהּ — אִיסְתָּאַב, כִּי עָיֵיל כּוּלֵּי, הַאי טָמֵא הוּא!
human_translation: into a house too, once he inserts his hand he becomes ritually impure. when all of him enters, this is impure.
llm_translation: In the house of Nami, since he brought his hands in — he became confused, for he brought everything, this one is impure!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר: צֵירַף יָדוֹ, מִשּׁוּם טוּמְאָה — אִיכָּא, מִשּׁוּם בִּיאָה — לֵיכָּא. וְצֵירַף גּוּפוֹ — טוּמְאָה וּבִיאָה בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי קָאָתוּ. הָא אִי אֶפְשָׁר דְּלָא עָיֵיל חוֹטְמוֹ בְּרֵישָׁא, וְנָחֵית לֵיהּ טוּמְאָה!
human_translation: Rather, Rabbi Elazar said: he inserted his hand there is due to ritual impurity; there is no due to entering But he joined his body impurity and entering occur simultaneously, It is impossible his nose would not enter first, and impurity would descend to it
llm_translation: Rather, Rabbi Elazar said: If he tied his hand due to impurity - there is a concern, due to intercourse - there is no concern. And if he tied his body - there is a concern of both impurity and intercourse simultaneously. For if not, he might inadvertently bring his hand to his head, and impurity would come upon it!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רָבָא: הִכְנִיס יָדוֹ, מִשּׁוּם טוּמְאָה — אִיכָּא, מִשּׁוּם בִּיאָה — לֵיכָּא. הִכְנִיס גּוּפוֹ — טוּמְאָה וּבִיאָה בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי קָא אָתְיָין. וְהָא אִי אֶפְשָׁר דְּלָא עָיֵיל אֶצְבְּעָתָא דְכַרְעֵיהּ בְּרֵישָׁא וְנָחֵת לְהוּ טוּמְאָה!
human_translation: Rather, Rava said: he entered his hand there is due to ritual impurity, there is no due to entering he entered his body impurity and entering occur simultaneously. But it is impossible his toes would not enter first, and impurity would descend to them,
llm_translation: Rather, Rava said: If he inserted his hand due to impurity - there is a concern, due to intercourse - there is not. If he inserted his body - there is both impurity and intercourse coming together. But is it not impossible that he did not bring his finger to the opening of his foot and cause impurity to them!

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אָמַר רַב פָּפָּא: כְּגוֹן שֶׁנִּכְנַס בְּשִׁידָּה תֵּיבָה וּמִגְדָּל, וּבָא חֲבֵירוֹ וּפָרַע עָלָיו אֶת הַמַּעֲזִיבָה, דְּטוּמְאָה וּבִיאָה בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי קָאָתְיָין. מָר בַּר רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: כְּגוֹן דְּעָיֵיל כְּשֶׁהוּא גּוֹסֵס, וּנְפַק נִשְׁמְתֵיהּ אַדְּיָתֵיב. דְּטוּמְאָה וּבִיאָה בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי קָאָתְיָין.
human_translation: Rather, Rav Pappa said: where one entered in a chest, a box, or a cabinet, and another came and opened the cover from over him. that impurity and entering occur simultaneously. Mar bar Rav Ashi said: where one entered when was dying, and soul departed when was sitting that impurity and entering occur simultaneously.
llm_translation: Rather, Rav Pappa said: For example, when one enters a storage shed or a tower, and his friend comes and removes the support beam from above him, causing the structure to collapse, impurity and entry are intertwined with one another. Mar bar Rav Ashi said: For example, when one ascends while he is stooping, and his soul departs before he reaches the top. Impurity and entry are intertwined with one another.

hebrew_text: תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״לְהֵחַלּוֹ״, עַד שָׁעָה שֶׁיָּמוּת. רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: ״בְּמוֹתָם יִטַּמָּא״, עַד שֶׁיָּמוּת.
human_translation: the Sages taught: to profane himself” until the time that dies. Rabbi says when they die, contracts ritual impurity until dies.
llm_translation: The sages taught: "To begin," until the hour he dies. Rabbi says: "Upon their death, they shall become impure," until he dies.

hebrew_text: מַאי בֵּינַיְיהוּ? אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: מַשְׁמָעוּת דּוֹרְשִׁין אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ. רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ אָמַר: גּוֹסֵס אִיכָּא בֵּינַיְיהוּ. לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִ״לְּהֵחַלּוֹ״ — אֲפִילּוּ גּוֹסֵס, לְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״בְּמוֹתָם״ — עַד שֶׁיָּמוּת אִין, גּוֹסֵס לָא.
human_translation: What is between Rabbi Yoḥanan says: The interpretation of the meaning is between them. Reish Lakish said: between them a dying person: According to the one who says to profane himself,” even a dying person According to the one who says “when they die,” once he dies, yes a dying person, no,
llm_translation: What is the difference between them? Rabbi Yochanan said: There is a difference in interpretation between them. Resh Lakish said: There is a difference in the text. According to the one who says "to desecrate it" - even if it is desecrated, according to the one who says "in their deaths" - until he dies, it is not desecrated.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִ״לְּהֵחַלּוֹ״, הָכְתִיב ״בְּמוֹתָם״! מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְכִדְרַבִּי. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: בְּמוֹתָם אֵינוֹ מִטַּמֵּא, אֲבָל מִטַּמֵּא בְּנִגְעָתָם וּבְזִיבָתָם.
human_translation: And according to the one who says “to profane himself,” isn’t it written: “When they die”? He requires for that which by Rabbi As it is taught Rabbi says when they die he may not become impure; however, he may become impure from their leprosy or from their gonorrhea-like discharge.
llm_translation: And for the one who says "to begin," it is written "in their death"! He needs it according to Rabbi. As it was taught, Rabbi says: "In their death" does not render impure, but they render impure through their touch and their flow.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״בְּמוֹתָם״, הָא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְהַאי סְבָרָא! אִם כֵּן, לֵימָא קְרָא ״בְּמוֹת״, מַאי ״בְּמוֹתָם״ — שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ תַּרְתֵּי.
human_translation: And according to the one who says “when they die,” he requires that for this reason; If so, let the verse state: When he dies; what is “when they die”? You can learn from two
llm_translation: And for the one who says "in their deaths," this requires him to hold this opinion! If so, let the verse say "in death," what is "in their deaths" - learn from it two.

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר ״בְּמוֹתָם״, הָכְתִיב ״לְהֵחַלּוֹ״! ״לְהֵחַלּוֹ״ לְהָכִי הוּא דַּאֲתָא, בְּמִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מְחוּלָּל, יָצָא זֶה שֶׁמְּחוּלָּל וְעוֹמֵד.
human_translation: And according to the one who says “when they die,” isn’t it written: “To profane himself”? “To profane himself” comes for this to one who is not profaned, excluding one who is profaned.
llm_translation: "And for the one who says 'in their deaths,' it is written 'to begin.' 'To begin' - this is what came, with one who is not defiled, this one who is defiled and standing has fulfilled his obligation."

hebrew_text: וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִ״לְּהֵחַלּוֹ״, הָא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ לְהַאי סְבָרָא! אִם כֵּן לֵימָא קְרָא ״לְהֵחֵל״, מַאי ״לְהֵחַלּוֹ״ — שָׁמְעַתְּ מִינַּהּ תַּרְתֵּי.
human_translation: And according to the one who says “to profane himself,” he requires that for this reason; If so, let the verse state: To profane; what is “to profane himself”? You can learn from two
llm_translation: And for the one who says "from the beginning," this requires him to hold this opinion! If so, let the verse say "to begin," what is "to initiate" - you learn two from it.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: אָדָם אֵינוֹ מְטַמֵּא (אֶלָּא) עַד שֶׁתֵּצֵא נַפְשׁוֹ. וַאֲפִילּוּ מְגוּיָּיד וַאֲפִילּוּ גּוֹסֵס. וּלְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִ״לְּהֵחַלּוֹ״ הָא קָתָנֵי דְּאֵינוֹ מְטַמֵּא! לְעִנְיַן טַמּוֹיֵי — עַד דְּנָפְקָא נַפְשֵׁיהּ, לְעִנְיַן אִתַּחוֹלֵי — הָא אִיתַּחִיל.
human_translation: raises an objection A person renders impure only when his soul departs him, even if he has severe lacerations [ meguyyad ], and even if is dying. But according to the one who says from “to profane himself,” teaches does not impart impurity. With regard to imparting impurity, until his soul departs, but with regard to profaning is profaned
llm_translation: The question was raised: A person does not become impure until his soul departs. And even if he is decaying, and even if he is a corpse. And according to the one who says, "from the beginning," it is taught that he does not become impure! Regarding impurity — until his soul departs, regarding purification — that is when he becomes purified.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא אָמַר רַב: נִקְטַע רֹאשׁוֹ שֶׁל אָבִיו — אֵינוֹ מִטַּמֵּא לוֹ. מַאי טַעְמָא — אָמַר קְרָא: ״לְאָבִיו״, בִּזְמַן שֶׁהוּא שָׁלֵם, וְלֹא בִּזְמַן שֶׁהוּא חָסֵר. אֲמַר לֵיהּ רַב הַמְנוּנָא: אֶלָּא מֵעַתָּה, קָאָזֵיל בְּפַקְתָּא דַּעֲרָבוֹת, וּפַסְקוּהּ גַּנָּבֵי לְרֵישֵׁיהּ, הָכִי נָמֵי דְּלָא לִיטַמֵּא לֵיהּ?
human_translation: Rav Ḥisda said Rav said: the head of his father, was severed, he may not become impure to him. What is the reason The verse states: for his father” when is whole, and not when he is lacking. Rav Hamnuna said to If that is so, was walking in the valley [ pakta ] of Aravot, and robbers severed his head, also does not become impure to him
llm_translation: Rav Ḥisda said in the name of Rav: If the head of his father is severed, it does not render him impure. What is the reason? The verse states, "to his father," when he is whole, but not when he is lacking. Rav Hamnuna said to him: Rather, from now on, he goes into the breach of the evenings, and the thieves cut it off for themselves, is it not so that he does not become impure for him?

hebrew_text: אֲמַר לֵיהּ: מֵת מִצְוָה קָאָמְרַתְּ? הַשְׁתָּא יֵשׁ לוֹמַר: בְּאַחְרִינֵי מִיחַיַּיב, בְּאָבִיו לֹא כׇּל שֶׁכֵּן?
human_translation: said to him: you speak a corpse with no one to bury it [ met mitzva ]? now one can say to others, he is obligated with regard to his father not all the more so
llm_translation: He said to him: "Is it a mitzvah to die?" Now you can say: "In other matters he is obligated, all the more so in the case of his father?"

hebrew_text: וְהַאי מֵת מִצְוָה הוּא? וְהָתַנְיָא: אֵיזֶהוּ מֵת מִצְוָה — כֹּל שֶׁאֵין לוֹ קוֹבְרִין. קוֹרֵא וַאֲחֵרִים עוֹנִין אוֹתוֹ — אֵין זֶה מֵת מִצְוָה. וְהָא אִית לֵיהּ בְּרָא! כֵּיוָן דְּקָאָזֵיל בְּאוֹרְחָא — כְּמִי שֶׁאֵין לוֹ קוֹבְרִים דָּמֵי.
human_translation: And is this a met mitzva ? But isn’t it taught Which is a met mitzva anyone who does not have to bury him he call, others would answer him, that is not a met mitzva . And has a son Since walking along the way, he is considered like one who does not have to bury
llm_translation: And this one who is dead, is it a mitzvah? And it was taught: Who is a mitzvah dead — anyone who has no one to bury him. He reads the Shema and others respond after him — this is not a mitzvah dead. But does he have a son? Since he is walking on the road — he is considered as one who has no one to bury him.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: ״לָהּ יִטַּמָּא״, לָהּ הוּא מִטַּמֵּא, וְאֵינוֹ מִטַּמֵּא לְאֵיבָרֶיהָ. לְפִי שֶׁאֵינוֹ מִטַּמֵּא לְאֵבֶר מִן הַחַי שֶׁל אָבִיו. אֲבָל מְחַזֵּיר הוּא עַל עֶצֶם כִּשְׂעוֹרָה.
human_translation: raises an objection for her he becomes impure” to her he becomes impure, but he does not become impure to her limbs. because he may not become impure to a limb from living that of father. However, he may search for a bone that is a barley-grain-bulk.
llm_translation: Challenger: "She shall become impure," she herself becomes impure, but does not render impure to her limbs. Because she does not render impure to a limb from the living father. But she returns to the bone like the skin.

hebrew_text: מַאי ״מְחַזֵּיר הוּא עַל עֶצֶם כִּשְׂעוֹרָה״? לָאו לְמֵימְרָא דְּאִי מִיחַסַּר פּוּרְתָּא?
human_translation: What is He may search for a bone that is a barley-grain-bulk? Isn’t this to say that if is lacking a small
llm_translation: What is "he restores it to its original state"? Is it not to say that if it is lacking a barley grain?

hebrew_text: לָא, הָהִיא רַבִּי יְהוּדָה הִיא. דְּתַנְיָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לָהּ מִיטַּמֵּא, וְאֵינוֹ מִיטַּמֵּא לְאֵבָרֶיהָ. שֶׁאֵינוֹ מִיטַּמֵּא עַל אֵבֶר מִן הַחַי שֶׁל אָבִיו, אֲבָל מִיטַּמֵּא הוּא לְאֵבֶר מִן הַמֵּת שֶׁל אָבִיו.
human_translation: No, that is Rabbi Yehuda. As it is taught Rabbi Yehuda says: to her he becomes impure but he does not become impure to her limbs, as he does not become impure to a limb from living that of father. However, he does become impure to a limb from his dead father.
llm_translation: Not, that, she, Rabbi Yehuda, she. For, it was taught, Rabbi Yehuda says: to her, she becomes impure, but does not become impure to her limbs. Because he does not become impure from a limb of his living father, but he does become impure from a limb of his deceased father.

hebrew_text: וְהָתַנְיָא, רַב כָּהֲנָא בְּרַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן יַעֲקֹב: לָהּ מִיטַּמֵּא, וְאֵינוֹ מִיטַּמֵּא לְאֵבָרִים. פְּרָט לִכְזַיִת מִן הַמֵּת, וּכְזַיִת נֶצֶל, וּמְלֹא תַרְווֹד רָקָב.
